:$\forall m, n \in \N: \ds \size {\sum_{k \mathop = m}^{m + n} \paren {\frac k p} } < \sqrt p \, \ln p$
where $\paren {\dfrac k p}$ is the Legendre symbol.

65d72377-44bb-47ef-8d93-2eabdfe12434.text:
Let $S \subseteq \R$.
Let $\sequence {f_n}$ be a sequence of real functions $S \to \R$.
Let $\sequence {f_n}$ be uniformly convergent on $S$.
Then $\sequence {f_n}$ is uniformly Cauchy on $S$.

718c86dd-a343-456a-b36a-f01c827f517c.text:
Let $H_n^{\paren r}$ denote the general harmonic number:
:$\displaystyle H_n^{\paren r} = \sum_{k \mathop = 1}^n \frac 1 {k^r}$
for $r \in \R_{>0}$.
Let $r > 1$.
Then as $n \to \infty$, $H_n^{\paren r}$ is convergent with an upper bound of $\dfrac {2^{r - 1} } {2^{r - 1} - 1}$.

a6f8c6a4-e4b4-4b36-9635-b1039bdf3ed1.text:
The set $\R_{>0}$ of strictly positive real numbers is closed under division:
:$\forall a, b \in \R_{>0}: a \div b \in \R_{>0}$

efe6c05e-309f-4efb-9de3-7300787dfe28.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be a group.
Then:
:$\forall a \in G: H = \set {a^n: n \in \Z} \le G$
That is, the subset of $G$ comprising all elements possible as powers of $a \in G$ is a subgroup of $G$.

2e8dad91-379b-490f-8313-239de3f8629e.text:
Let $\mathbb S = \family {\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha} }_{\alpha \mathop \in I}$ be an indexed family of non-empty topological spaces for $\alpha$ in some indexing set $I$.
Let $\ds T = \struct{S, \tau} = \ds \prod_{\alpha \mathop \in I} \struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha}$ be the product space of $\mathbb S$.
For each $\alpha \in I$, let $\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha}$ be a $T_3$ space.
Then $T$ is a $T_3$ space.

ff99237e-c644-4e2f-96f9-3469ba8a3e59.text:
Let $L = \struct {S, \vee, \preceq}$ be a bounded below join semilattice.
Let $P = \struct {\map {\operatorname {Ids} } L, \precsim}$ be an inclusion ordered set
where
:$\map {\operatorname {Ids} } L$ denotes the set of all ideals in $L$,
:$\mathord\precsim = \mathord\subseteq \cap \paren {\map {\operatorname {Ids} } L \times \map {\operatorname {Ids} } L}$
Let $x \in \map {\operatorname {Ids} } L$
Then $x$ is compact element {{iff}} $x$ is principal ideal in $L$.

0d1fb440-b822-40ac-8a6c-30f87bb9f88b.text:
:$\map {\dfrac \d {\d x} } {\csc x} = -\csc x \cot x$
where $\sin x \ne 0$.

fef8a851-10e1-4ec0-82b7-b65c6ee3713e.text: Two cyclic groups of the same order are isomorphic to each other.

a0a4cc7b-122a-496d-967d-babbe28b4c48.text:
Let $\struct {\Q_{>0}, /}$ denote the algebraic structure consisting of the set of (strictly) positive rational numbers $\Q_{>0}$ under the operation $/$ of division.
We have that $\struct {\Q_{>0}, /}$ is not a group.

0a6420c9-e4db-4c69-a804-fbd275ef1f8a.text:
Let $\Omega$ denote the first uncountable ordinal.
Let $\closedint 0 \Omega$ denote the closed ordinal space on $\Omega$.
Then $\closedint 0 \Omega$ is not a first-countable space.

fa2a9b03-bab8-4a4b-927e-9ba82d66216f.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $\struct {\map \Gamma S, \circ}$ be the symmetric group on $S$, where $\circ$ denotes the composition operation.
Let $\struct {H, \circ}$ be a set of permutations of $S$ which forms a group under $\circ$.
Then $\struct {H, \circ}$ is a subgroup of $\struct {\map \Gamma S, \circ}$.

aec97def-29f8-4c5a-9796-7f4c09006ebf.text:
Let $T = \struct {\CC, \tau_d}$ be the Cantor space.
Then $T$ is not locally connected.

494339db-79bc-4bb0-b619-0765763b39f6.text:
Let $\left({T, \le}\right)$ be an ordered set, and let $S$ be a set.
Let $f: S \to T$ be an injection.
Then $\le_f$, the ordering induced by $f$, is an ordering.

ceeb3245-cea0-45ad-8c86-4333ed53e1cc.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Let $U_1, U_2, \ldots, U_n$ be open sets in $M$.
Then $\ds U = \bigcap_{i \mathop = 1}^n U_i$ is open in $M$.
That is, a finite intersection of open subsets is open.

ec03c64f-4c0a-471f-9623-36b2c7c75441.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=X|prop=29|qual=Lemma 2|body=To find two square numbers such that their sum is not square.}}

1458a958-66df-474e-9e36-ca5cf6937220.text:
Let $\mathcal R$ be a relation on a set $S$.
{{TFAE|def = Reflexive Transitive Closure}}

f4f34b50-827e-469f-a922-cd37c4c8c362.text:
Let $s$ be the the series:
:$\ds s = \sum_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty a_n = a_0 + a_1 + a_2 + a_3 + \cdots$
Let $\map G z$ be the generating function for the sequence $\sequence {a_n}$.
Let $\sequence {c_n}$ denote the sequence of partial sums of $s$.
Then the generating function for $\sequence {c_n}$ is given by:
:$\ds \dfrac 1 {1 - z} \map G z = \sum_{n \mathop \ge 0} c_n z^n$

c59f061b-7381-44ca-bbf7-9b265c552d4f.text:
Let $x \in \R_{> 0}$ be a (strictly) positive real number.
Let $q$ be a rational number.
Then $x^q$ is  well-defined.

6fcd7327-c573-4a2b-8a19-3fafc24c0d46.text:
Let $\RR$ be a relation on a set $S$.
If $\RR$ is antitransitive, then so is $\RR^{-1}$.

09a8ceb3-215f-4222-aa70-cc52c434c514.text:
Let $\ln x$ be the natural logarithm function.
Then:
:$\map {D^3_x} {\ln x} = \dfrac 2 {x^3}$

4de0c4e4-b5e2-46a0-9c91-72326bf64485.text:
Let $\left({S, \preceq}\right)$ be a preordered set.
Let $A, B$ be subset of $S$ such that
:$A \subseteq B$
Then $A$ is coarser than $B$.

fc7651ef-bfa8-4bb2-b47d-2277f5b75e66.text:
Let $\struct {R, \norm {\, \cdot \,} }$ be a normed division ring.
Let $\CC$ be the ring of Cauchy sequences over $R$
Let $\NN$ be the set of null sequences.
For all $\sequence {x_n} \in \CC$, let $\eqclass {x_n} {}$ denote the left coset $\sequence {x_n} + \NN$
Let $\norm {\, \cdot \,}_1: \CC \,\big / \NN \to \R_{\ge 0}$ be defined by:
:$\ds \forall \eqclass {x_n} {} \in \CC \,\big / \NN: \norm {\eqclass {x_n} {} }_1 = \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} \norm {x_n}$
Then:
:$\struct {\CC \,\big / \NN, \norm {\, \cdot \,}_1 }$ is a normed division ring.

dfaa2a4c-1d46-4208-80fc-f0920c5ac4a8.text:
Let $\N$ be the natural numbers.
Let $m, n \in \N$.
Then:
:$n \le m \implies n^+ \le m^+$

49c77129-1ca4-443c-8767-1e66d6e2e9ea.text:
Let $u = \tan \dfrac \theta 2$.
Then:
:$\dfrac 1 {p + q \sin a x} = \dfrac {u^2 + 1} {p u^2 + 2 q u + p}$

f0daba3e-8666-4210-837d-9c1e396e92f5.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $H \subseteq S$ be closed in $T$.
Let $K \subseteq S$ be compact in $T$.
Then $H \cap K$ is compact in $T$.

33c2bdad-57a0-495f-a930-350ae642e17f.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Then $A$ is closed in $M$.

0d9b8ec7-0da7-4b77-87fd-d472c3ef9a75.text:
Let $T \in \map {\DD'} \R$ be a distribution.
Then there exists a distribution $S \in \map {\DD'} \R$ such that in the distributional sense:
:$S' = T$
Furthermore, $S$ is unique up to an arbitrary constant.

e379d56d-cbd6-4c1e-84b7-b66b9c6b0836.text:
Let $L = \left({S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}\right)$ be a bounded below continuous lattice.
Then $L$ is meet-continuous.

8282998a-4011-45e1-9266-629d0d3b35d7.text:
Let $\exp: \R \to \R$ be the exponential function:
:$\map \exp x = e^x$
Then $\exp$ is an injection.

b2f5e1a3-4366-4b4f-ad77-e5ed0ba79c15.text:
Let $f: \R \to \R$ be the real function defined as:
:$\forall x \in \R: \map f x = x - \dfrac 1 2$
Then $f$ is a replicative function.

890e3980-3831-49d6-8f92-596623460389.text:
The operation of multiplication on the set of integers $\Z$ is distributive over addition:
:$\forall x, y, z \in \Z: x \times \paren {y + z} = \paren {x \times y} + \paren {x \times z}$
:$\forall x, y, z \in \Z: \paren {y + z} \times x = \paren {y \times x} + \paren {z \times x}$

b3385a91-2dcf-4e0c-96bb-42bb0e752f97.text:
:$e^{\tan x} = 1 + x + \dfrac {x^2} 2 + \dfrac {x^3} 2 + \dfrac {3 x^4} 8 + \cdots$
for all $x \in \R$ such that $\size x < \frac \pi 2$.

8a6bc19f-4517-47c7-a475-0e751dc713cc.text:
Let $\family {\struct {X_i, \tau_i} }_{i \mathop \in I}$ be an indexed family of topological spaces where $I$ is an arbitrary index set.
Let $X$ be the cartesian product of $\family {X_i}_{i \mathop \in I}$:
:$\ds X := \prod_{i \mathop \in I} X_i$
Let $\tau$ be the product topology on $X$.
Let $\tau'$ be the box topology on $X$.
Then:
:$\tau \subseteq \tau'$

cd5b0af4-d1f2-4c73-99e7-95b0284e3cf7.text:
Let $\struct{S, \vee_1, \wedge_1, \preceq_1}$ be a lattice.
Let $\struct{T, \vee_2, \wedge_2, \preceq_2}$ be a complete lattice.
Let $f: S \to T$ be a mapping such that
:$\forall x \in S: \map f x = \sup \leftset{ \map f w : w \in S \land w \preceq_1 x \land w}$ is compact$\rightset{}$
Then $f$ is increasing.

4de0c1b9-fd38-4828-abf0-1afa384ffc1e.text:
Let $G$ and $H$ be a $K$-vector space.
Let $\phi: G \to H$ be a linear transformation.
Then $\phi$ is a monomorphism {{iff}} for every linearly independent sequence $\sequence {a_n}$ of vectors of $G$, $\sequence {\map \phi {a_n} }$ is a linearly independent sequence of vectors of $H$.

4d88d1fa-4a5c-48d8-a8bc-13b2e5a298aa.text:
Let $\mathbf C$ be a metacategory.
Let $P \in \mathbf C_0$ be a projective object of $\mathbf C$.
Let $e: E \twoheadrightarrow P$ be an epimorphism.
Then $e$ is a split epimorphism, i.e. it admits a retraction $f: P \to E$.

d2389741-1c5f-4c7e-953f-2a6666cbd748.text:
The operation of multiplication on the set of complex numbers $\C$ is associative:
:$\forall z_1, z_2, z_3 \in \C: z_1 \paren {z_2 z_3} = \paren {z_1 z_2} z_3$

bf27a40a-5554-48c2-a4de-c72ec76fdb25.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space which is regular and paracompact.
Then it is not necessarily the case that $T$ is metrizable.

fcbf342d-e517-4130-b66d-b4df9dbc5831.text:
Let $F$ be a set of sets.
Let $S$ be a set or class.
Suppose that:
:$\forall A \in F: A \cap S \ne \O$
Then:
:$\ds F = \bigcup_{x \mathop \in S} \set {A \in F: x \in A}$

2388a28a-d395-46be-acb6-039bc071d57e.text:
Let $f: \R \to \R$ be a real function.
Let $\Delta$ denote the forward difference operator.
Let $x^{\underline m}$ be the $m$th falling factorial of $x$
Then:
:$\map \Delta {x^{\underline m} } = m x^{\underline {m - 1} }$

40ad7bff-de63-4747-98bb-490b00f11a73.text: The power set of the empty set $\O$ is the set $\set \O$.

b16faec3-298f-4529-b165-ca7d8466f2ac.text:
Let $n \in \Z_{>0}$ be a power of $2$.
Then:
:$\map {\sigma_1} n = 2 n - 1$

1090a370-9d43-44f8-8713-8ecad403ea89.text:
Let $\psi$ be a non-trivial Dirichlet character modulo $q$.
Let $\map L {s, \chi}$ be the Dirichlet $L$-function associated to $\chi$.
Then $\map L {1, \chi} \ne 0$.

03dbcd61-3bb9-404a-b83c-3a6cc7525a21.text:
Let $x$ and $y$ be real numbers.
Then:
:$\ds \min \set {x, y} = \frac 1 2 \paren {\paren {x + y} - \size {x - y} }$

a0e1bf42-f4be-43a8-b76a-a8898ee84907.text:
Let $A$ be a commutative ring with unity.
Let $\left({1}\right)$ be its unit ideal.
Then its radical equals $(1)$:
:$\operatorname{Rad} \left({\left({1}\right)}\right) = \left({1}\right)$.

31c6450f-3e27-4c7b-a28f-5cd5bf21dc16.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau_p}$ be a Fortissimo space.
Then $T$ is not sequentially compact.

c242a0f4-ed3b-453a-863c-e9449fe492d9.text:
Consider the subset $S$ of the complex plane defined as:
:$S := \set {\dfrac i n : n \in \Z_{>0} }$
That is:
:$S := \set {i, \dfrac i 2, \dfrac i 3, \dfrac i 4, \ldots}$
where $i$ is the imaginary unit.
The set $S$ is countably infinite.

81719282-e6d2-4caa-862d-d1e91cd40d4e.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Then $T$ is a partition space {{iff}}:
:$\forall U \subseteq S: U \in \tau \iff \relcomp S U \in \tau$
That is, a topological space is a partition space {{iff}} all open sets are closed, and all closed sets are also open.

1d53629b-6946-438f-ac22-10c05b8a4d5f.text:
Let $n$ be a finite ordinal.
Let $x \subsetneq n$.
Then for some finite ordinal $m < n$:
:$m \sim x$
where $m \sim x$ denotes that $m$ is (set) equivalent to $x$.
That is, every proper subset of a finite ordinal $n$ is equivalent to some finite ordinal smaller than $n$.

1d2f4ee9-459a-48f6-aa20-db5c26bf1361.text:
Let $L_k$ be the $k$th Lucas number.
Let $F_k$ be the $k$th Fibonacci number.
Then:
:$\ds \forall n \in \N_{>0}: \sum_{j \mathop = 1}^n 2^{j - 1} L_j = 2^n F_{n + 1} - 1$
That is:
:$2^0 L_1 + 2^1 L_2 + 2^2 L_3 + \cdots + 2^{n - 1} L^n = 2^n F_{n + 1} - 1$

b2d9c66e-79b9-4dd8-bc78-6a6b083ff361.text:
Let $\struct {B, \preceq, \wedge, \vee}$ be a non-empty Boolean algebra.
Let $\struct {U, \tau}$ be the Stone space of $B$.
Then $\struct {U, \tau}$ is a topological space.

5e1b9f91-f85c-40ba-9ccb-8958bb31b413.text:
The following ordered quadruples of consecutive integers have divisor sum values which are strictly increasing:
:$61, 62, 63, 64$
:$73, 74, 75, 76$

d4aa2387-5586-4dbb-9443-eb5a53d7d3c2.text:
Let $\R_{> 0}$ be the set of strictly positive real numbers.
For all $x \in \R_{> 0}$, let $B_x$ be the closed real interval $\closedint 0 x$.
Then:
:$\ds \bigcap_{x \mathop \in \R_{> 0} } B_x = \set 0$

2a51e083-ac48-4b7f-970e-a14befa90a6b.text:
:$\ds \int \tanh^2 x \rd x = x - \tanh x + C$
where $C$ is an arbitrary constant.

ee2db3e8-fca4-4856-872e-9611d46a8643.text:
Let $\left({S, \preceq}\right)$ be an ordered set.
Let $L$ be a lower bound for $S$.
Let $\left({T, \preceq}\right)$ be a subset of $\left({S, \preceq}\right)$.
Then $L$ is a lower bound for $T$.

882305ba-5eaa-498d-9bfe-adc3d4485f29.text:
The intersection of any set with the empty set is itself the empty set:
:$S \cap \O = \O$

08f1af3f-ef9f-4b28-8466-58f975eb36fc.text:
Let $x$ and $y$ be ordinals.
Then:
:$x \in y \iff x^+ \subseteq y$

d3f58d8d-fa49-48fe-8849-e7892f922a81.text:
Let $X = \Spec A$ be the spectrum of a noetherian commutative ring $A$.
Let $\FF$ be a quasi-coherent sheaf on $X$.
Then for all $i \in \Z$ with $i > 0$ the $i$-th sheaf cohomology $\map {H^i} {X, \FF} = 0$.

f857ec80-2577-4e73-9270-f4b96c8e40c9.text: The following definitions of a deficient number are equivalent:

5dc6e70c-8d17-4ed7-8938-d82d62102a8a.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preccurlyeq}$ be an ordered set.
Let $\map m S$ be the number of minimal elements of $\struct {S, \preccurlyeq}$.
Then $\map m S$ is an order property.

29e65d52-1a5b-4198-8d60-ee00e8480665.text:
Let $\struct {k, +, \cdot}$ be a field with unity $1$ and zero $0$.
Then the following are equivalent:
:$(1): \quad$ There exists a total ordering $\le$ on $k$ such that $\struct {k, \le}$ is an ordered field
:$(2): \quad$ $-1$ cannot be written as a sum of squares of elements of $k$
:$(3): \quad$ $0$ cannot be written as a non-empty sum of squares of non-zero elements of $k$

f2dc278b-3d74-4cbf-86c2-dff188b1b776.text:
Let $S$ and $T$ be sets.
Let $\RR \subseteq S \times T$ be a relation.
Let $T_1$ and $T_2$ be subsets of $T$.
Then:
:$\RR^{-1} \sqbrk {T_1 \cup T_2} = \RR^{-1} \sqbrk {T_1} \cup \RR^{-1} \sqbrk {T_2}$

6cf4988e-701c-449e-8877-22f223c67ae8.text:
Let $g_n$ be the sum of the first $n$ Fibonacci numbers.
Then:
:$\forall n \ge 2: g_n = g_{n - 1} + g_{n - 2} + 1$

a2164e5a-64e9-4082-b7e4-668fe6218ceb.text:
Let $S \subset \R$ be a symmetric set of real numbers:
:$\forall x \in S: -x \in X$
Let $f, g: X \to \R$ be two odd functions.
Let $f \cdot g$ denote the pointwise product of $f$ and $g$.
Then $\paren {f \cdot g}: S \to \R$ is an even function.

02920d7e-7577-4503-959d-f1f720cd9f91.text:
Let $n$ be a natural number.
Let $\map f n$ denote the number of integer partitions of $n$ where the parts are consecutive prime numbers.
For example:
:$\map f {41} = 3$
because:
:$41 = 11 + 13 + 17 = 2 + 3 + 5 + 7 + 11 + 13$
Then:
:$\ds \lim_{x \mathop \to \infty} \dfrac 1 x \sum_{n \mathop = 1}^x \map f n = \ln 2$

0c4756a4-3e53-43a0-81e2-cf88eb409f66.text:
Let $L = \left({S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}\right)$ be a bounded below meet-continuous lattice.
Let $\mathit{Ids}$ be the set of all ideals in $L$.
Let for all $I \in \mathit{Ids}$: $m_I: S \to \mathit{Ids}$ be a mapping:
:$\forall x \in S: x \preceq \sup I \implies m_I\left({x}\right) = \left\{ {x \wedge i: i \in I}\right\}$
and
:$\forall x \in S: x \npreceq \sup I \implies m_I\left({x}\right) = x^\preceq$
where $x^\preceq$ denotes the lower closure of $x$.
Let $x \in S$.
Then
:$\displaystyle \bigcap \left\{ {m_I \left({x}\right): I \in \mathit{Ids} }\right\} = x^\ll$
where $x^\ll$ denotes the way below closure of $x$.

847000ed-c6e1-4323-96e8-4e863e9cc3d3.text:
Let $\GF$ be a Galois field.
Then the characteristic of $\GF$ is non-zero.

e7617527-db4f-478c-8593-d9114543d74d.text:
Let $G$ be a group.
Let $H$ and $K$ be subgroups of $G$ such that:
:$\order H = 25$
:$\order K = 36$
where $\order {\, \cdot \,}$ denotes the order of the subgroup.
Then:
:$\order {H \cap K} = 1$

048a5357-d944-455f-a0ab-9e968f8a5116.text:
Let $S$ be a set whose cardinality is $n$.
Let $x \in S$.
The number $N$ of possible different commutative binary operations such that $x$ is an identity element that can be applied to $S$ is given by:
:$N = n^{\frac {n \paren {n - 1} } 2}$

93c14042-e33f-4f91-96a9-46d026eef96f.text:
:$\ds \sum_{k \mathop = 1}^n \dfrac {x^k} k = H_n + \sum_{k \mathop = 1}^n \dbinom n k \dfrac {\paren {x - 1}^k} k$
where:
:$H_n$ denotes the $n$th harmonic number
:$\dbinom n k$ denotes a binomial coefficient.

0bb9e03d-0152-471b-95dc-bbe4a20cffcd.text:
Let $T_1 = \struct {S_1, \tau_1}$ and $T_2 = \struct {S_2, \tau_2}$ be topological spaces.
Let $T = \struct {T_1 \times T_2, \tau}$ be the product space of $T_1$ and $T_2$, where $\tau$ is the product topology on $S$.
Let $\pr_1: T \to T_1$ and $\pr_2: T \to T_2$ be the first and second projections from $T$ onto its factors.
Let $K \subseteq S_1 \times S_2$ be closed in $T$.
Then $\pr_1 \sqbrk K$ is not necessarily closed in $T_1$.

e9d01d7a-1f38-4a78-a15a-ef6c26e2de78.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a ring with unity $1_R$.
Let $U_R$ be the set of units in $R$.
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $\struct {R^S, +', \circ'}$ be the ring of mappings on the set of mappings $R^S$.
Then:
:$f \in R^S$ is a unit of $R^S$ {{iff}} $\Img f \subseteq U_R$
where $\Img f$ is the image of $f$.
In this case, the inverse of $f$ is the mapping $f^{-1} : S \to U_R$ defined by:
:$\forall x \in S : \map {f^{-1} } x = \map f x^{-1}$

80f2ec84-e4c7-49a1-a2cc-54cb4e38dce8.text: It is possible to construct a regular hepadecagon (that is, a regular polygon with $17$ sides) using a compass and straightedge construction.

de37750a-1902-465c-bc23-f0ff5bfe7a6c.text:
Suppose the Goldbach Conjecture holds:
:Every even integer greater than $2$ is the sum of two primes.
Then Goldbach Conjecture/Marginal follows:
:Every integer greater than $5$ can be written as the sum of three primes.

bd0015c8-d8f0-4329-9785-4b05288f54a9.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau_{\bar p} }$ be a countable excluded point space.
Then $T$ is a separable space.

e599e33d-b516-4890-8ed5-2676581889d7.text:
:$\map \cos {a - b} = \cos a \cos b + \sin a \sin b$
where $\sin$ denotes the sine and $\cos$ denotes the cosine.

362eb7bf-124d-4f8f-8f55-64fe27b4baaa.text:
Let $L = \left({S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}\right)$ be a complete lattice.
Then $\operatorname{Closure}\left({L}\right)$ and $\operatorname{ClSystems}\left({L}\right)^{-1}$ are order isomorphic
where
:$\operatorname{Closure}\left({L}\right)$ denotes the ordered set of closure operators of $L$,
:$\operatorname{ClSystems}\left({L}\right)$ denotes the ordered set of closure systems oj $L$,
:$\operatorname{ClSystems}\left({L}\right)^{-1}$ denotes the dual to $\operatorname{ClSystems}\left({L}\right)$.

e23e1eaa-c012-4f53-ac79-936c4f302905.text:
Let $\struct {S_1, \RR_1}$, $\struct {S_2, \RR_2}$ and $\struct {S_3, \RR_3}$ be relational structures.
Let:
:$\phi: \struct {S_1, \RR_1} \to \struct {S_2, \RR_2}$
and:
:$\psi: \struct {S_2, \RR_2} \to \struct {S_3, \RR_3}$
be relation isomorphisms.
Then $\psi \circ \phi: \struct {S_1, \RR_1} \to \struct {S_3, \RR_3}$ is also a relation isomorphism.

05a9d935-8da8-480f-a6a4-d5ee7618aa55.text:
Let $L = \struct {S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}$ be a lattice.
Let $x \in S$.
Let
: $x^\succeq \setminus \left\{ {x}\right\}$ be a filter in $L$.
Then $x$ is meet irreducible.

03a1f8fd-f815-48e8-acd0-2f698597db8c.text:
Let $\mathcal L$ be the straight line defined by the equation:
:$a x - b y = c$
Let $p_1$ and $p_2$ be lattice points on $\mathcal L$.
Then the shortest possible distance $d$ between $p_1$ and $p_2$ is:
:$d = \dfrac {\sqrt {a^2 + b^2} } {\gcd \set {a, b} }$
where $\gcd \set {a, b}$ denotes the greatest common divisor of $a$ and $b$.

831a0fdb-25fa-4306-849b-bbfdec478514.text:
Let $M$ be a countably compact metric space.
Then $M$ is sequentially compact.

d49ec4fd-e90e-4f89-9f48-8dc4844c84a8.text:
:$\ds \paren {\sum \cmod {w_i}^2} \paren {\sum \cmod {z_i}^2} \ge \cmod {\sum w_i z_i}^2$
where all of $w_i, z_i \in \C$.

33b8c2e6-1c3d-4da1-a419-be2d427c1d7b.text:
Let $\struct {\mathbb K, \norm {\,\cdot\,} }$ be a valued field.
Let $\ds \prod_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty a_n$ converge absolutely.
Let $\ds \prod_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty b_n$ converge absolutely.
Then $\ds \prod_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty a_nb_n$ converges absolutely.

603ffdd2-a1de-485c-bc1a-4f21e3e04522.text:
Let $f : \N \to\C$ be an arithmetic function.
Let $g : \N \to \C$ be an Dirichlet inverse of $f$.
Let $F, G$ be their Dirichlet series.
Let $s \in \C$ such that both $F(s)$ and $G(s)$ converge absolutely.
Then $F(s) \cdot G(s) = 1$.

77fbc62a-71c1-41c4-9284-270b78199b05.text:
Let $X$ be a set.
Let $\Sigma$ be the set of countable and co-countable subsets of $X$.
Then $\Sigma$ is a $\sigma$-algebra.

1c8e2395-db50-48ed-8901-97e79e077499.text: The intersection of two transitive relations is also a transitive relation.

4eacb9b2-6928-4044-be84-e0ac3d7c444d.text:
Let $\struct {S, \RR_1}$ and $\struct {T, \RR_2}$ be relational structures.
Let $\struct {S, \RR_1}$ and $\struct {T, \RR_2}$ be (relationally) isomorphic.
Then $\RR_1$ is a symmetric relation {{iff}} $\RR_2$ is also a symmetric relation.

ef30f3d3-7d51-421f-8844-a615a4019b8c.text:
The Dirichlet functions are periodic by Dirichlet Function is Periodic.
However, they do not admit a period.
That is, there does not exist a smallest value $L \in \R_{> 0}$ such that:
:$\forall x \in \R: \map D x = \map D {x + L}$

8eb3c2f6-136b-40b8-bb22-ea188a1b8684.text:
Let $\struct {F, +, \times}$ be a field whose zero is $0_F$.
Let $a \in F$ such that $a \ne 0_F$.
Let $a^{-1}$ be the multiplicative inverse of $a$.
Then $\paren {a^{-1} }^{-1} = a$.

8e851d73-1362-4be9-b063-3db6d898e3f6.text:
Let $I$ and $J$ be real intervals.
Let:
:$(1): \quad g: I \to J$ be a real function which is continuous on $I$
:$(2): \quad f: J \to \R$ be a real function which is continuous on $J$.
Then the composite function $f \circ g$ is continuous on $I$.

effae932-bd17-41e1-ae1d-23b50f88b24a.text:
Let $\sequence {E_n}_{n \mathop \in \N}$ be a sequence of sets.
Then:
:$\ds \map \complement {\limsup_{n \mathop \to \infty} \ E_n} = \liminf_{n \mathop \to \infty} \ \map \complement {E_n}$
where $\limsup$ and $\liminf$ denote the limit superior and limit inferior, respectively.

b8c6150f-3510-428b-9f4f-d30e2102244c.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ, \le}$ be an ordered ring whose zero is $0_R$ and whose unity is $1_R$.
Let $x, y \in \struct {R, +, \circ, \le}$ such that $0_R \le x, y$.
Then:
:$x \le y \implies x \circ x \le y \circ y$
When $R$ is one of the standard sets of numbers, that is $\Z, \Q, \R$, then this translates into:
:If $x, y$ are positive then $x \le y \implies x^2 \le y^2$.

748fa508-58e2-4e2a-a3a9-125700267845.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a non-trivial discrete topological space.
$T$ is not path-connected.

813192e5-c9b0-4023-abe9-c48276c99096.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=XI|prop=5|body=If a straight line be set up at right angles to three straight lines which meet one another, at their common point of section, the three straight lines are in one plane.}}

a2d8aa34-03de-454c-9328-de6e27600100.text:
Consider proper fractions of the form $\dfrac 3 n$ expressed in canonical form.
Let Fibonacci's Greedy Algorithm be used to generate a sequence $S$ of Egyptian fractions for $\dfrac 3 n$.
Then $S$ consists of $3$ terms, where $2$ would be sufficient {{iff}} the following conditions hold:
:$n \equiv 1 \pmod 6$
:$\exists d: d \divides n$ and $d \equiv 2 \pmod 3$

ef9b2b05-ed9c-46cc-9d84-fde8dd11d613.text:
Let $\struct {D, +, \circ}$ be an integral domain whose zero is $0_D$.
Let $D^*$ denote $D \setminus \set {0_D}$, that is, $D$ without its zero.
Let $a \in D^*$.
Then:
:$\forall x, y \in D: a \circ x = a \circ y \implies x = y$
That is, all elements of $D^*$ are cancellable for the ring product.

5192cb2a-e708-48f4-be3c-23b65f8d5675.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be a group whose identity is $e$.
Let $g \in G$ be an element of $G$ such that:
:$\order g = n$
where $\order g$ denotes the order of $g$.
Then:
:$\forall m \in \Z: \order {g^m} = \dfrac n {\gcd \set {m, n} }$
where $\gcd \set {m, n}$ denotes the greatest common divisor of $m$ and $n$.

b89ad1e6-a4df-4fda-93b1-71d5610a3f1c.text:
Let $n$ be an integer which has at least $3$ digits when expressed in decimal notation.
Let the digits of $n$ be divided into groups of $3$, counting from the right, and those groups added.
Then the result is equal to a multiple of $999$ {{iff}} $n$ is divisible by $999$.

1f349f42-1cbe-48c9-89d0-8eac089d725c.text:
Let $\struct {\R, \tau_d}$ be the the real number line with the usual (Euclidean) topology.
Then $\struct {\R, \tau_d}$ fulfils all separation axioms:
:$\struct {\R, \tau_d}$ is a $T_0$ (Kolmogorov) space
:$\struct {\R, \tau_d}$ is a $T_1$ (Fréchet) space
:$\struct {\R, \tau_d}$ is a $T_2$ (Hausdorff) space
:$\struct {\R, \tau_d}$ is a semiregular space
:$\struct {\R, \tau_d}$ is a $T_{2 \frac 1 2}$ (completely Hausdorff) space 
:$\struct {\R, \tau_d}$ is a $T_3$ space 
:$\struct {\R, \tau_d}$ is a regular space
:$\struct {\R, \tau_d}$ is an Urysohn space
:$\struct {\R, \tau_d}$ is a $T_{3 \frac 1 2}$ space
:$\struct {\R, \tau_d}$ is a Tychonoff (completely regular) space
:$\struct {\R, \tau_d}$ is a $T_4$ space
:$\struct {\R, \tau_d}$ is a normal space
:$\struct {\R, \tau_d}$ is a $T_5$ space 
:$\struct {\R, \tau_d}$ is a completely normal space
:$\struct {\R, \tau_d}$ is a perfectly $T_4$ space
:$\struct {\R, \tau_d}$ is a perfectly normal space

fdbd6ca0-e236-4065-bd9a-2f70209470ef.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a discrete topological space.
Consider the set $\CC$ of all singleton subsets of $S$:
:$\CC := \set {\set x: x \in S}$
Then $\CC$ is an open cover of $T$ which is locally finite.
This cover is the finest cover on $S$.
That is, if $\VV$ is a cover of $T$, then $\CC$ is a refinement of $\VV$.

bb5235ad-a4c3-4415-b5d4-e687862cc2a4.text:
For all $n \in \Z_{> 1}$:
 
:$\ds \int \map {\tan^n} x \rd x = \frac {\map {\tan^{n - 1} } x} {n - 1} - \int \map {\tan^{n - 2} } x \rd x$

be53fb39-5031-42eb-8f9a-ce912aa65ae4.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Let $\struct {\Q_p, \norm {\,\cdot\,}_p}$ be the $p$-adic numbers.
Let $a \in \Q_p$.
For all $\epsilon \in \R_{>0}$: 
:Let $\map {B_\epsilon} a$ denote the open $\epsilon$-ball of $a$
:Let $\map {B^-_\epsilon} a$ denote the closed $\epsilon$-ball of $a$. 
Then:
:$\forall n \in Z : \map {B_{p^{-n} } } a = \map {B^-_{p^{-\paren {n + 1} } } } a$

73a081b6-c52a-4a43-a039-6720a6347b8b.text:
Let $\struct {D, +, \circ}$ be a Division Ring whose zero is $0$.
Let $\struct {J, +, \circ}$ be a maximal ideal of $D$.
Then:
:$J = \set 0$

e77951f4-ab5b-48eb-96bd-d8eddeff1c1c.text:
Let $q$ be an odd prime.
Let $\sequence {L_n}_{n \mathop \in \N}$ be the recursive sequence in $\Z / \paren {2^q - 1} \Z$ defined by:
:$L_0 = 4, L_{n + 1} = L_n^2 - 2 \pmod {2^q - 1}$
Then $2^q - 1$ is prime {{iff}} $L_{q - 2} = 0 \pmod {2^q - 1}$.

8776db39-5ccc-4d43-9d04-82bb58915df1.text:
Let $m \in \N$ be a natural number.
Let $n \in \N_{>0}$ be a non-zero natural number.
Let $\RR_{m, n}$ be the relation on $\N$ defined as:
:$\forall x, y \in \N: x \mathrel {\RR_{m, n} } y \iff \begin {cases} x = y \\ m \le x < y \text { and } n \divides \paren {y - x} \\  m \le y < x \text { and } n \divides \paren {x - y} \end {cases}$
Then $\RR_{m, n}$ is an equivalence relation which is compatible with both addition and multiplication.

1db62601-0b91-4520-8dbc-81f4388f4939.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq, \tau}$ be a generalized ordered space.
Let $p \in S$.
Then:
:$p^\prec$ and $p^\succ$ are $\tau$-open
where:
:$p^\prec$ is the strict lower closure of $p$
:$p^\succ$ is the strict upper closure of $p$.

3ba47e8b-15a9-4e99-b8e2-7be6f73d1cf1.text:
Let $f$ be a complex function.
Let $z_0$ be a point in $\C$.
Let $\Gamma$ be a circle in $\C$ with center at $z_0$ and radius in $\R_{>0}$.
Let $f$ be analytic on $\Gamma$.
Then $f$ is bounded on $\Gamma$.

d3eb70c0-8ee2-4d63-8e23-4b4d7ede997c.text:
The real sequence:
:$\ds \sequence {\sum_{k \mathop = 1}^n \frac 1 k - \ln n}$
converges to a limit.
This limit is known as the Euler-Mascheroni constant.

38c7f6ba-971e-426c-9fe4-ef3baa0a079d.text:
Let $T: \R^n \to \R^m, \mathbf x \mapsto \map T {\mathbf x}$ be a linear transformation.
Then:
:$\map T {\mathbf x} = \mathbf A_T \mathbf x$
where $\mathbf A_T$ is the $m \times n$ matrix defined as:
:$\mathbf A_T = \begin {bmatrix} \map T {\mathbf e_1} & \map T {\mathbf e_2} & \cdots & \map T {\mathbf e_n} \end {bmatrix}$
where $\tuple {\mathbf e_1, \mathbf e_2, \cdots, \mathbf e_n}$ is the standard ordered basis of $\R^n$.

f66db4b0-96f5-46c4-8179-6629f0297b74.text:
:$\lcm \set {a, b} \times \gcd \set {a, b} = \size {a b}$
where:
:$\lcm \set {a, b}$ denotes the lowest common multiple of $a$ and $b$
:$\gcd \set {a, b}$ denotes the greatest common divisor of $a$ and $b$.

4f728261-dbfd-4a33-86f8-4a264dfbf7cd.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a countable discrete topological space.
Then $T$ is $\sigma$-compact.

d5d45205-f1f9-4300-a40f-be1b1943aad9.text:
Let $G$ be a group.
Let $H, K$ be subgroups of finite index of $G$.
Then:
:$\index H {H \cap K} \le \index G K$
where $\index G K$ denotes the index of $K$ in $G$.
Equality happens {{iff}} $G = H K$.

9f2cc1b1-8a44-4fc3-93d3-9623436cbdbf.text:
Let $x \in \R$ be a real number.
Let $\cot x$ be the cotangent of $x$.
Then, whenever $\cot x$ is defined:
:$\map \cot {-x} = -\cot x$
That is, the cotangent function is odd.

c2e73c2d-ade2-428c-b3a2-40a4a647f232.text:
Let $T = \left({S, \tau}\right)$ be a Hausdorff space with no isolated points.
Let $U \subseteq S$ be a non-empty open set in $T$.
Let $x \in S$.
Then there is a non-empty open subset $V \subseteq U$ such that $x \notin V^-$, where $V^-$ is the closure of $V$.

9f38de20-46ca-4896-9c09-73d0ddef871d.text:
Let $T_A = \struct {A, \tau_A}$ and $T_B = \struct {B, \tau_B}$ be topological spaces.
Let $b \in B$ be any point in $B$.
Let $f_b: A \to B$ be the constant mapping defined by:
:$\forall x \in A: \map {f_b} x = b$
Then $f_b$ is continuous.

e1479642-99f4-4835-8e68-d76bec2b0883.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $A, B$ be subsets of $S$.
Then:
:$\partial A \cup \partial B = \map \partial {A \cup B} \cup \map \partial {A \cap B} \cup \paren {\partial A \cap \partial B}$
where $\partial A$ denotes the boundary of $A$.

f2504689-5110-4595-880f-e1afc8537a6b.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be a magma.
Let $\sigma: S \to S$ be a permutation on $S$.
Let $\circ_\sigma$ be the operation on $S$ induced by $\sigma$:
:$\forall x, y \in S: x \circ_\sigma y := \map \sigma {x \circ y}$
Then $\circ_\sigma$ is closed on $S$.

72bc0384-7e12-4957-910d-637954a83cf6.text:
Let $V_n$ be the Vandermonde matrix of order $n$ given by:
:$V_n = \begin{pmatrix}
  x_1 & x_2 & \cdots & x_n \\
  x_1^2 & x_2^2 & \cdots & x_n^2 \\
\vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\
  x_1^n & x_2^n & \cdots & x_n^n
\end{pmatrix}$
Let $V_n^{-1}$ be its inverse, from Inverse of Vandermonde Matrix:
:$b_{i j} = \begin {cases}
\paren {-1}^{j - 1} \paren {\dfrac {\ds \sum_{\substack {1 \mathop \le m_1 \mathop < \ldots \mathop < m_{n - j} \mathop \le n \\ m_1, \ldots, m_{n - j} \mathop \ne i} } x_{m_1} \cdots x_{m_{n - j} } } {x_i \ds \prod_{\substack {1 \mathop \le m \mathop \le n \\ m \mathop \ne i} } \paren {x_m - x_i} } } & : 1 \le  j < n \\
\qquad \qquad \qquad \dfrac 1 {x_i \ds \prod_{\substack {1 \mathop \le m \mathop \le n \\ m \mathop \ne i} } \paren {x_i - x_m} } & : j = n
\end{cases}$
The sum of all the elements of $V_n^{-1}$ is:
:$\ds \sum_{1 \mathop \le i, \ j \mathop \le n} b_{i j} = 1 - \prod_{k \mathop = 1}^n \paren {1 - \dfrac 1 {x_k} }$

cc5660b0-38be-4d2e-b887-cea1786abb21.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=VII|prop=12|body=If there be as many numbers as we please in proportion, then, as one of the antecedents is to one of the consequents, so are all the antecedents to all of the consequents.}}

704bdf0d-406e-4007-8506-58d5b3fe6e03.text:
Let $f: S \to \R$ be a real function on some subset $S$ of $\R$.
Let $I \subseteq S$ be a real interval.
Let $f: I \to \R$ be continuous on $I$.
Then $f$ is a Darboux function.
That is:
Let $a, b \in I$.
Let $k \in \R$ lie between $\map f a$ and $\map f b$.
That is, either:
:$\map f a < k < \map f b$
or:
:$\map f b < k < \map f a$
Then $\exists c \in \openint a b$ such that $\map f c = k$.
Let $0 \in \R$ lie between $\map f a$ and $\map f b$.
That is, either:
:$\map f a < 0 < \map f b$
or:
:$\map f b < 0 < \map f a$
Then $f$ has a root in $\openint a b$.
This result rigorously proves the intuitive truth that:
: ''if a continuous real function defined on an interval is sometimes positive and sometimes negative, then it must have the value $0$ at some point.''
{{AuthorRef|Bernhard Bolzano}} was the first to provide this proof in $1817$, but because of incomplete understanding of the nature of the real numbers it was not completely satisfactory.
Hence many sources refer to this as '''Intermediate Value Theorem'''.
The first completely successful proof was provided by {{AuthorRef|Karl Weierstrass}}, hence its soubriquet the Intermediate Value Theorem.

f8ad6db5-b8ba-4b65-9d7d-db6c7cfcf228.text:
Let $A$ be a star convex subset of a vector space $V$ over $\R$ or $\C$.
Then $A$ is path-connected.

4f1d06cf-a899-42c3-a7a3-350c37deff40.text:
The kernel of a group homomorphism is a subgroup of its domain:
:$\map \ker \phi \le \Dom \phi$

870f98c1-f08b-4471-90a2-fc1cc5ee57a8.text: :$\map {\dfrac \d {\d x} } {\sech a x} = -a \sech a x \tanh a x$

83f0b81c-e778-4717-8103-15b90fe85ad6.text:
Let $\N$ denote the set of natural numbers.
By application of the comprehension principle, $\N$ can be derived as a valid object in Frege set theory.

c2d29bf1-403f-4c00-a32b-33ae868b9b46.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let the path components of open sets of $T$ be also open in $T$.
Then
:$T$ has a basis consisting of path-connected sets in $T$.

70b117ec-89d2-47b7-b07e-ef30b2841488.text:
:$\ds \lim_{x \mathop \to \infty} \map {\mathrm C} x = \frac 1 2$
where $\mathrm C$ denotes the Fresnel cosine integral function.

17332c61-30a6-4f04-a165-67c89a156bb0.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be a semigroup.
For $a \in S$, let $\circ^n a = a^n$ denote the $n$th power of $a$.
Let $a, b \in S$ such that $a$ commutes with $b$:
:$a \circ b = b \circ a$
Then:
:$\forall m, n \in \N_{>0}: \paren {\circ^m a} \circ \paren {\circ^n b} = \paren {\circ^n b} \circ \paren {\circ^m a}$
That is:
:$\forall m, n \in \N_{>0}: a^m \circ b^n = b^n \circ a^m$

04ff1cdd-3c4c-4f54-832a-623178cdf22c.text:
Let $M_1, M_2$ be metric spaces whose metrics are $d_1, d_2$ respectively.
Let $f: M_1 \to M_2$ be a continuous mapping.
Let $S \subseteq M_1$ be a path-connected subspace of $M_1$.
Then $f \sqbrk S$ is a path-connected subspace of $M_2$.

aed1841a-f45b-4e3a-9bb3-17f316d0dbda.text:
Let $M = \struct {X, d}$ be a metric space.
Then:
:$\forall x, y, z \in X: \size {\map d {x, z} - \map d {y, z} } \le \map d {x, y}$

3c0a0104-e867-4b98-8c67-c01d5532cdaa.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $A$ be a subset of $S$.
Then
:$A' \subseteq A^-$
where
:$A'$ denotes the derivative of $A$
:$A^-$ denotes the closure of $A$.

da4721a4-8b89-4fdc-81f2-47c52379dbbe.text:
Let $M$ be a smooth manifold.
Let $m \in M$ be a point. 
Let $V$ be an open neighborhood of $m$. 
Let $\map {C^\infty} {V, \R}$ be defined as the set of all smooth mappings $f: V \to \R$.
{{TFAE|def = Tangent Vector}}

0e667899-e0c9-435d-8f97-07a3f49deda5.text:
Let $L_1 = \struct {S_1, \preceq_1}$, $L_2 = \struct {S_2, \preceq_2}$ and $L_3 = \struct {S_3, \preceq_3}$ be ordered sets.
Let:
:$g_1: S_1 \to S_2, g_2: S_2 \to S_3, d_1: S_2 \to S_1, d_2: S_3 \to S_2$
be mappings such that:
:$\tuple {g_1, d_1}$ and $\tuple {g_2, d_2}$
are Galois connections.
Then $\tuple {g_2 \circ g_1, d_1 \circ d_2}$ is also a Galois connection.

c951addb-5177-4f88-8104-a654ddc412b1.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $\tau$ be the indiscrete topology on $S$.
:$\tau$ is a topology on $S$.

7e8eaa2d-82ab-427c-8a69-0d13ee764bd6.text:
Let $G$ be a group whose order is $35$.
Then $G$ is cyclic.

7ec798d3-4e3a-4130-9309-a82b27297a2f.text:
Let $I$ be an index set.
Let $\family {S_i}_{i \mathop \in I}$ and $\family {T_i}_{i \mathop \in I}$ be indexed families of sets over the same index set.
Then:
:$\ds \paren {\prod_{i \mathop \in I} S_i} \cap \paren {\prod_{i \mathop \in I} T_i} = \prod_{i \mathop \in I} \paren {S_i \cap T_i}$
where $\ds \prod$ denotes Cartesian product.

6e558d47-f19a-4425-9c14-fe85a0c13775.text:
Let $\AA$ be an algebra of sets.
Let $f: \AA \to \overline \R$ be an additive function on $\AA$.
Then $\map f \O = 0$.

bfaf7e85-04cd-4e4d-91b2-7fea2d2790a1.text:
:$\ds \arctan x = x \, {}_2 \map {F_1} {\frac 1 2, 1; \frac 3 2; -x^2}$
where:
:$x$ is a real number with $\size x < 1$
:$\arctan$ denotes the arctangent function
:${}_2 F_1$ denotes the Gaussian hypergeometric function.

4e11b16c-ebf9-491c-ac7b-f78444c537b6.text:
Let $f: S \to T$ be a surjection.
Then the direct image mapping of $f$:
:$f^\to: \powerset S \to \powerset T$
is a surjection.

155cc099-eb73-48eb-9f8f-fb241025508b.text: A mapping that is strictly increasing is an increasing mapping.

16e074e1-9d5b-4547-87e8-04790c4a6513.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a discrete topological space.
Then:
:$\map w T = \size S$
where:
:$\map w T$ denotes the weight of $T$
:$\card S$ denotes the cardinality of $S$.

015a4424-ecb9-4988-aa7b-97b3d1a0c6fd.text:
Let $x, y \in \R$ be real numbers.
Let $\size x$ denote the absolute value of $x$.
Then:
:$\size {x + y} \le \size x + \size y$

6c68f645-0b8f-478f-8aa7-6b141190be39.text:
Let $f : \openint 0 \infty \to \R$ be a continuous function such that: 
:for each $x \in \openint 0 \infty$, the sequence $\sequence {\map f {n x} }$ converges to $0$.
Then:
:$\ds \lim_{x \mathop \to \infty} \map f x = 0$

76895bfe-5789-45f5-a29b-946f01f244e9.text:
Let $\struct {X, \Sigma, \mu}$ be a measure space.
Let $E_n \subseteq \Sigma$ be a countable collection of measurable sets.
If:
:$\ds \sum_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty \map \mu {E_n} < \infty$
then:
:$\ds \map \mu {\limsup_{n \mathop \to \infty} E_n} = 0$
where $\limsup$ denotes limit superior of sets.
{{refactor}}
As each probability space $\struct {X, \Sigma, \Pr}$ is a measure space, the result carries over to probability theory.
Hence, given any countable sequence of events $E_n$, the sum of whose probabilities is finite, the probability that infinitely many of the events occur is zero.

c5fe6eb5-0dd6-4cad-9d8c-a550141706ac.text:
Let $\map f x$ be an even real function defined on the interval $\openint {-\lambda} \lambda$.
Then the Fourier series of $\map f x$ can be expressed as:
:$\map f x \sim \dfrac {a_0} 2 + \ds \sum_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty a_n \cos \frac {n \pi x} \lambda$
where for all $n \in \Z_{\ge 0}$:
:$a_n = \dfrac 2 \lambda \ds \int_0^\lambda \map f x \cos \frac {n \pi x} \lambda \rd x$

e42d0fdd-98ca-45ca-ae5c-6f11e5d68583.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be a group.
Let $H$ be a subgroup of $G$.
Let:
:$x H$ denote the left coset of $H$ by $x$
:$H y$ denote the right coset of $H$ by $y$.
Then:
:$\order {\set {x H: x \in G} } = \order {\set {H y: y \in G} }$
That is:
:The number of right cosets is the same as the number of left cosets of $G$ with respect to $H$.
:The left and right coset spaces are equivalent.

74ebdb72-ddc9-4a9b-a758-63294bc5cb28.text:
Let $z_1$ and $z_2$ be complex numbers expressed as vectors such taht $z_1$ is not parallel to $z_2$.
Let $a, b \in \R$ be real numbers such that:
:$a z_1 + b z_2 = 0$
Then $a = 0$ and $b = 0$.

81208e67-1383-455a-9202-752b3b02722d.text:
Let $G$ be a group.
Let $I$ be an indexing set.
Let $\family {N_i}_{i \mathop \in I}$ be a non-empty indexed family of normal subgroups of $G$.
Then $\ds \bigcap_{i \mathop \in I} N_i$ is a normal subgroup of $G$.

c10bb3ff-4f66-4264-b2b9-d63cd524dd5c.text:
Let $\struct {F, +, \times}$ be a field whose unity is $1_F$.
Let $F_n \sqbrk X$ be the ring of polynomials over $F$ whose degree is less than $n$.
Then the dimension of the vector space $F_n \sqbrk X$ is $n$.

81c6c175-0ada-42b9-87ad-ea22a86ef299.text:
Let $\struct {\R \setminus \Q, \tau_d}$ be the irrational number space under the Euclidean topology $\tau_d$.
Then $\struct {\R \setminus \Q, \tau_d}$ is separable.

cdac858a-38d1-48c7-9f04-769062a121ca.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Then the empty set $\O$ is closed in $M$.

d0c8860e-e29c-44f9-91eb-b050cebc7802.text:
Let $x \in \R$ be a real number.
Let $\sec x$ be the secant of $x$.
Then, whenever $\sec x$ is defined:
:$\map \sec {-x} = \sec x$
That is, the secant function is even.

7aaaacef-ce28-48b7-b53d-a0ae80d72779.text:
Let $F$ be a field whose zero is $0_F$ and whose unity is $1_F$.
Let the characteristic of $F$ be $p$ where $p \ne 0$.
Let $\phi: F \to F$ be the mapping on $F$ defined as:
:$\forall x \in F: \map \phi x = x^p$
Then $\phi$ is a (field) monomorphism.

9326b282-3ca0-40b5-a5c9-b064e61bcd94.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=XII|prop=10|body=Any cone is a third part of the cylinder which has the same base with it and equal height.}}

1fc9b74f-04a6-4558-86f5-c3b8944f63b6.text:
Let $X$ be a set.
Let $\GG \subseteq \powerset X$ be a collection of subsets of $X$.
Then $\map \delta \GG \subseteq \map \sigma \GG$.
Here $\delta$ denotes generated Dynkin system, and $\sigma$ denotes generated $\sigma$-algebra.

f2fc651b-ba96-4c50-ae2b-c0c219b8d22a.text:
:$\displaystyle \int \frac {\d x} {x^2 \paren {\sqrt {x^2 - a^2} }^3} = \frac {-\sqrt {x^2 - a^2} } {a^4 x} - \frac x {a^4 \sqrt {x^2 - a^2} } + C$
for $\size x > a$.

daa08483-bdc3-4236-b10f-e64118b03a5a.text:
Let $\Lambda$ be von Mangoldt's function.
Let $\mu$ be the Möbius function.
Then for $y, z \ge 1$ and $n > z$:
:$\ds \map \Lambda n = \sum_{\substack {d \mathop \divides n \\ d \mathop \le y}} \map \mu d \map \ln {\frac n d} - \mathop {\sum \sum}_{\substack {d c \mathop \divides n \\ d \mathop \le y, \, c \mathop \le z}} \map \mu d \map \Lambda c + \mathop {\sum \sum}_{\substack {d c \mathop \divides n \\ d \mathop > y, \, c \mathop > z} } \map \mu d \map \Lambda c$
where $\divides$ denotes divisibility.

cb832102-dbac-498a-a93e-2e0909ac4345.text:
Let $\family {S_i}_{i \mathop \in I}$ be a family of sets indexed by $I$.
Then for all sets $X$:
:$\ds \paren {\forall i \in I: S_i \subseteq X} \implies \bigcup_{i \mathop \in I} S_i \subseteq X$
where $\ds \bigcup_{i \mathop \in I} S_i$ is the union of $\family {S_i}$.

f76f707e-e713-4f87-bf50-c750a73fa734.text:
Let $G$ be a finite group.
Let $H$ be a subgroup of $G$.
Then:
: $\order H$ divides $\order G$
where $\order G$ and $\order H$ are the order of $G$ and $H$ respectively.
In fact:
:$\index G H = \dfrac {\order G} {\order H}$
where $\index G H$ is the index of $H$ in $G$.
When $G$ is an infinite group, we can still interpret this theorem sensibly:
:A subgroup of finite index in an infinite group is itself an infinite group.
:A finite subgroup of an infinite group has infinite index.

d3c6474f-9060-4ad2-972f-85e069cdde87.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {\cos a x} = \frac 1 a \ln \size {\sec a x + \tan a z}$

2166f135-6f8f-4d39-8e03-b2adfc55a06a.text:
Let $S \subseteq \R$.
Let $\sequence {f_n}$ be a sequence of real functions $S \to \R$.
Then the infinite series: 
:$\ds \sum_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty f_n$
converges uniformly on $S$ {{iff}} for all $\varepsilon \in \R_{> 0}$ there exists $N \in \N$ such that:
:$\ds \size {\sum_{k \mathop = m + 1}^n \map {f_k} x} < \varepsilon$
for all $x \in S$ and $n > m > N$.

6a360fdb-fb3d-4e47-ae2b-12acbd8f3f56.text:
Let $n \in \Z$.
Then:
:$\hat \phi^n = F_n \hat \phi + F_{n - 1}$
where:
:$F_n$ denotes the $n$th Fibonacci number
:$\hat \phi$ denotes the $1$ minus the golden mean:
::$\hat \phi := 1 - \phi$

50876d69-2ed5-4a17-b81a-e25dfe7ea2c4.text:
Let $\struct {D, +, \circ}$ be an integral domain whose unity is $1_D$.
Then every element of $D$ is a divisor of itself:
:$\forall x \in D: x \divides x$

d869b4a3-3472-4d10-aa56-1a3783686c6b.text:
Let $P$ be a polygon embedded in the complex plane $\C$.
Denote the boundary of $P$ as $\partial P$.
Then there exists a simple closed contour $C$ such that:
: $\operatorname{Im} \left({C}\right) = \partial P$
where $\operatorname{Im} \left({C}\right)$ denotes the image of $C$.

b1b7a1c2-0418-4764-8053-5f48210908be.text:
Let $n \in \Z_{> 0}$ be a (strictly) positive integer.
Then there exists either one or two Fibonacci numbers between $n$ and $2 n$ inclusive.

21abb04c-1659-4c73-bbbe-0f067262c13f.text:
Let $K$ be a division ring.
Let $\struct {G, +_G, \circ}_K$ be a $K$-vector space.
Let $M$ and $N$ be finite-dimensional subspaces of $G$.
Then the sum $M + N$ and intersection $M \cap N$ are finite-dimensional, and:
:$\map \dim {M + N} + \map \dim {M \cap N} = \map \dim M + \map \dim N$

e3db2355-f451-4cdd-b24f-8efaacb530a7.text:
Let $S$ and $T$ be sets.
Let $f: S \to T$ be a bijection.
Let $f^{-1}: T \to S$ be the inverse of $f$.
Then the codomain of $f^{-1}$ equals the domain of $f$.

6909a2cb-b2c4-43e9-b016-eb82671f33d5.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \preceq, \tau}$ be a up-complete topological lattice with Scott topology.
Let $x \in S$.
Then:
:$\set x^- = x^\preceq$
where
:$\set x^-$ denotes the topological closure of $\set x$
:$x^\preceq$ denotes the lower closure of $x$.

c6008f80-99cf-4b60-8d8c-a787a099b054.text:
:$\ds \int \cos^2 x \rd x = \frac {x + \sin x \cos x} 2 + C$
where $C$ is an arbitrary constant.

839c95da-ea39-4382-9399-33e1954bb7c1.text:
Let $\struct {R, 
orm {\,\cdot\,} }$ be a non-Archimedean normed division ring with zero $0_R$.
Let $\mathcal O$ be valuation ring induced by $
orm{\,\cdot\,}$.
Then $\mathcal O$ is a both open and closed in the metric induced by $
orm{\,\cdot\,}$.

26453682-3b4d-4b19-985f-5a68b38f32f3.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau_p}$ be a Fortissimo space.
Then $T$ is not weakly countably compact.

c4ad043f-97c3-4dde-bf04-993438a835aa.text:
Let $T$ be a square matrix of order $n$.
Let $\norm {T - I} < 1$ in the norm on bounded linear operators, where $I$ the identity matrix.
Then there is a square matrix $S$ such that:
:$e^S = T$
where $e^S$ is the matrix exponential.

2356367a-6dfd-4d2b-80ee-1bdbe3cead73.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Let $\epsilon \in \R_{> 0}$.
Then:
:$\exists n \in \Z : p^{-\paren {n + 1} } < \epsilon \le p^{-n}$

1601ae55-f0d3-4bb7-b103-8930344b6c9f.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a ring.
Let $n \in \N_{>0}$ be a strictly positive integer.
Let $x \in R$.
Then:
:If $n$ is even:
:::$\map {\circ^n} {-x} = \map {\circ^n} x$
:If $n$ is odd:
:::$\map {\circ^n} {-x} = -\map {\circ^n} x$

08947aee-9d7b-49e1-b402-90424077f8d3.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be the either-or space.
Then $T$ is a $T_0$ (Kolmogorov) space.

7f4c1584-3295-46af-a9b8-87aaa9f520f2.text:
Let $S$ be an ordinal.
Let $T \subset S$ also be an ordinal.
Then $\exists a \in S: T = S_a$, where $S_a$ is the initial segment of $S$ determined by $a$.
That is, $T = S_a = a \in S$.

2fb0a8b4-8dac-4381-87ab-16c687472617.text: {{TFAE|def = Transitive Closure (Relation Theory)|view = Transitive Closure|context = Relation Theory}}

f2205dc0-6fb1-4040-a5d6-35523b2c9053.text:
Let $S \subseteq \R: S \ne \O$ be a non-empty subset of the set of real numbers $\R$.
Let $S$ be bounded above.
Let $z \in \R: z > 0$ be a positive real number.
Then:
:$\ds \map {\sup_{x \mathop \in S} } {z x} = z \map {\sup_{x \mathop \in S} } x$

5fd865aa-de07-4e4a-ac68-c62f36b67566.text:
Let $\left({S, \mathcal N}\right)$ be a neighborhood space.
Let $\left({S, \tau}\right)$ be the topological space induced by $\left({S, \mathcal N}\right)$.
Then $\left({S, \tau}\right)$ is a topological space.

94de2f29-6479-4721-a96a-827a7f701b3d.text:
For all $\theta$ such that $\theta \ne 0, \pm \pi, \pm 2 \pi \ldots$
:$\dfrac {\sin 4 \theta} {\sin \theta} = 2 \cos 3 \theta + 2 \cos \theta$
where $\sin$ denotes sine and $\cos$ denotes cosine.

eb14ca99-a00f-4c67-b829-99038bc34cdc.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a non-empty topological space.
Let $p$ be a new element not in $S$.
Let $S^* := S \cup \set p$.
Let $T^* = \struct {S^*, \tau^*}$ be the Alexandroff extension on $S$.
Let $T^*$ be a $T_2$ (Hausdorff) space.
Then $T^*$ is a $T_4$ space.

1dbf9aeb-ccb5-426c-98ae-d57c3a0cde10.text: The infinite cardinal class $\mathcal N’$ is a proper class.

2b0a198d-fdcd-40e5-bff1-f0480ca052a1.text:
Let $p$ be an odd prime.
Let $G$ be a non-abelian group of order $2 p$.
Then $G$ has at least one element of order $p$.

f6fa976d-5cb9-4892-883b-7ea3afa4137a.text:
Let the axiom of countable choice be accepted.
Then it can be proved that a countable union of countable sets is countable.

a021e95c-dfc8-4845-bf19-bfcffc9903f4.text:
Let $R$ be a ring.
Let $S_0 \subseteq S_1 \subseteq S_2 \subseteq \dotsb \subseteq S_i \subseteq \dotsb$ be ideals of $R$.
Then the increasing union $S$:
:$\ds S = \bigcup_{i \mathop \in \N} S_i$
is an ideal of $R$.

5292ef52-94a7-4def-8ca4-054d1ceff352.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a countable complement topology on an uncountable set $S$.
Let $T \times D$ be the double pointed topology on $T$.
Then $T \times D$ is weakly countably compact.

b65ba6c0-26fc-474d-9a82-e0a32356ed3f.text:
Let $z_1$ and $z_2$ be complex numbers.
Then:
:$\map \arg {\dfrac {z_1} {z_2} } = \map \arg {z_1} - \map \arg {z_1} + 2 k \pi$
where:
:$\arg$ denotes the argument of a complex number
:$k$ can be $0$, $1$ or $-1$.

1b8f1c8b-4bdd-4b63-a2ab-322979ec7a45.text:
There exists a minimal uncountable well-ordered set.
That is, there exists an uncountable well-ordered set $\Omega$ with the property that every initial segment in $\Omega$ is countable.

6ccf1680-c3e6-4cf0-bd2a-b8daed852429.text:
Let $R$ be a commutative ring with unity.
Let $G$ be an $R$-module.
Let $G^*$ be the algebraic dual of $G$.
Let $G^{**}$ be the double dual of $G^*$.
Let the mapping $J: G \to G^{**}$ be the evaluation linear transformation from $G$ into $G^{**}$ defined as:
:$\forall x \in G: \map J x = x^\wedge$
where for each $x \in G$, $x^\wedge: G^* \to R$ is defined as:
:$\forall t \in G^*: \map {x^\wedge} t = \map t x$
 
Then $J$ is a linear transformation.

e278de27-0a48-46b0-9394-044a076afc87.text:
Let $\Z \sqbrk {\sqrt 2}$ denote the set of quadratic integers over $2$:
:$\Z \sqbrk {\sqrt 2} := \set {a + b \sqrt 2: a, b \in \Z}$
that is, all numbers of the form $a + b \sqrt 2$ where $a$ and $b$ are integers.
Then the mapping $\phi: \Z \sqbrk {\sqrt 2} \to \Z \sqbrk {\sqrt 2}$ defined as:
:$\forall x = a + b \sqrt 2 \in \Z \sqbrk {\sqrt 2}: \map \phi {a + b \sqrt 2} = a - b \sqrt 2$
is a ring automorphism.

8276c00e-ac59-4719-93bf-92b7ac82f400.text:
Let $S$ and $T$ be sets.
Let $\powerset S$ be the power set of $S$.
Let $\mathbb S$ be a subset of $\powerset S$.
Then:
:$\ds \paren {\forall X \in \mathbb S: X \subseteq T} \implies \bigcup \mathbb S \subseteq T$

1b80c0f7-be83-4b73-baa1-90659475bdbc.text:
Let $\mathbf C$ be a metacategory.
Let $f: C \to D$ be an isomorphism.
Then $f: C \twoheadrightarrow D$ is epic.

ee6b17a4-f076-4dd0-ac42-5ce43ea8bd7b.text:
Let $\R$ denote the set of real numbers.
Let $\Z \sqbrk {\sqrt 3} \subseteq \R$ denote the  set of quadratic integers over $3$:
:$\Z \sqbrk {\sqrt 3} = \set {a + b \sqrt 3: a, b \in \Z}$
Then $\struct {\Z \sqbrk {\sqrt 3}, +, \times}$ is an integral domain.

a126b570-58f7-4c0f-944e-c4ebf2b71959.text:
Let $\struct {S, +, \times}$ be a ring with unity.
Let $\struct {\map {\MM_S} 2, +, \times}$ denote the ring of square matrices of order $2$ over $S$.
Let:
:$G = \set {\begin{bmatrix}
x & 0 \\
y & 0
\end{bmatrix} : x, y \in S }$
Then:
:$G$ is a left ideal of $\struct {\map {\MM_S} 2, +, \times}$.

9f5f7d11-dd4f-419d-834b-f1061fec8a47.text:
Let $M = \struct {X, d}$ be a metric space.
Let $M' = \struct {Y, d_Y}$ be a subspace of $M$.
Let $M'$ be bounded in $M$.
Then:
:$\forall a' \in X: \exists K' \in \R: \forall x \in Y: \map d {x, a} \le K'$
That is, if there is one element of $X$ which satisfies the condition for $Y$ to be bounded in $M$, they ''all'' do.

a37e0d09-08e8-425d-9375-67ff7329c15b.text:
Let $R$ be a division ring.
Let $
orm {\, \cdot \,}_1: R 	o \R_{\ge 0}$ and $
orm {\, \cdot \,}_2: R 	o \R_{\ge 0}$ be norms on $R$.
Let $d_1$ and $d_2$ be the metrics induced by the norms $
orm {\, \cdot \,}_1$ and $
orm {\, \cdot \,}_2$ respectively.
Let $
orm {\, \cdot \,}_1$ and $
orm {\, \cdot \,}_2$ satisfy:
:$\exists \alpha \in \R_{\gt 0}:  orall x \in R: 
orm x_1 = 
orm x_2^\alpha$
Then $d_1$ and $d_2$ are topologically equivalent metrics.

b9a542de-4091-4861-b662-e851c5097b89.text:
Let $\RR$ be a ring of sets.
Let $A_1, A_2, \ldots, A_n \in \RR$.
Then:
:$\ds \bigcup_{j \mathop = 1}^n A_j \in \RR$

218f997e-6f8c-4b32-9ba8-d0edaac423a2.text:
Spence's function has a power series expansion: 
:$\ds \map {\Li_2} z = \sum_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty \frac {z^n} {n^2}$
This converges for $\size z \le 1$.
{{explain|The domain needs to be clarified. As it stands, the notation and construction of the proof suggests $\R$.}}

bc51d00b-9064-4527-807d-3f76ac319004.text:
Let $P_1$ and $P_2$ be connectedness properties and let:
:$P_1 \implies P_2$
mean:
:If a topological space $T$ satsifies property $P_1$, then $T$ also satisfies property $P_2$.
Then the following sequence of implications holds:
{|
|-
| align="center" | ||
| align="center" | ||
| align="center" | Ultraconnected ||
|-
| align="center" | ||
| align="center" | ||
| align="center" | $\Big\Downarrow$ ||
|-
| align="center" | Arc-Connected ||
| align="center" | $\implies$ ||
| align="center" | Path-Connected ||
|-
| align="center" | ||
| align="center" | ||
| align="center" | $\Big\Downarrow$ ||
|-
| align="center" | Irreducible ||
| align="center" | $\implies$ ||
| align="center" | Connected ||
|-
|}

09da3e3e-658a-47da-84d0-1b9b3a80ed85.text:
Let $A$ be an $n \times n$ positive definite symmetric matrix over $\RR$.
Then:
:there exists an invertible matrix $C$ such that $A = C^\intercal C$.

e0f9d432-d2c4-4d7d-a383-f9fe042ad1e2.text:
Let $n \in \Z: n > 1$.
Then $n$ has a primitive root {{iff}} one of the following holds:
: $n = 2$
: $n = 4$
: $n = p^k$
: $n = 2 p^k$
where $p > 2$ is prime and $k \ge 1$.

47ae4c11-303b-492b-92b3-d8771d6159ee.text:
Let $C_n$ be the cyclic group of order $n$.
Then:
:$C_n \cong \dfrac {\struct {\Z, +} } {\struct {n \Z, +} } = \dfrac \Z {n \Z}$
where:
:$\Z$ is the additive group of integers
:$n \Z$ is the additive group of integer multiples
:$\Z / n \Z$ is the quotient group of $\Z$ by $n \Z$.
Thus, every cyclic group is isomorphic to one of:
:$\Z, \dfrac \Z \Z, \dfrac \Z {2 \Z}, \dfrac \Z {3 \Z}, \dfrac \Z {4 \Z}, \ldots$

ccb102d0-28e0-414d-918f-bcb5dc041900.text:
Let $\R^n$ denote the real Euclidean space of $n$ dimensions.
Let $\mathbf a = \tuple {a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n}$ and $\mathbf b = \tuple {b_1, b_2, \ldots, b_n}$ be points in $\R^n$.
There exists an isometry $f: \R^n \to \R^n$ such that $\map f {\mathbf a} = b$.

555120d2-6357-44b7-8e12-3e7ca1ff4b31.text:
Let $t > 0$ be wholly real.
Let $t^{i x}$ be $t$ to the power of $i x$ defined on its principal branch.
Then:
:$\cmod {t^{ix} } = 1$

651d93e7-2eb2-4003-a440-fcb31d0d7306.text:
Let $I$ be an indexing set.
Let $\family {S_\alpha}_{\alpha \mathop \in I}$ be a family of sets indexed by $I$.
Let $\family {I_\gamma}_{\gamma \mathop \in J}$ be a partitioning of $I$.
Then there exists a bijection:
:$\ds \phi: \prod_{\gamma \mathop \in J} \paren {\prod_{\alpha \in \mathop I_\gamma} S_\alpha} \to \prod_{\alpha \mathop \in I} S_\alpha$

9669a83a-f46a-4869-80f0-5b118def5861.text:
Let $S \subseteq \R$ be a countable set.
Then $\map \lambda S = 0$, where $\lambda$ is Lebesgue measure.
That is, $S$ is a $\lambda$-null set.

79a1d77a-1dd9-492f-8d9f-c9db3f9fd57b.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Let $\norm {\,\cdot\,}_p$ be the $p$-adic norm on the rational numbers $\Q$.
Let $\struct {\Q_p, \norm {\,\cdot\,}_p}$ be the $p$-adic numbers.
Let $\sequence{\beta_n}$ be a Cauchy sequence in $\struct {\Q, \norm {\,\cdot\,}_p}$ such that:
:$\forall j \in \N : \exists \mathop {\map N j} \ge j : \forall m, n \in \N: m, n \ge \map N j : \norm {\beta_n - \beta_m} \le p^{-\paren {j + 1} }$
Let $\sequence{\alpha_n}$ be a Cauchy sequence in $\struct {\Q, \norm {\,\cdot\,}_p}$ such that:
:$\forall j \in \N: \norm {\alpha_j - \beta_{\map N j} }_p \le p^{-\paren {j + 1} }$
Then: 
:$\sequence {\alpha_n}$ and $\sequence {\beta_n}$ are representatives of the same $p$-adic number in $\Q_p$.

c77ed06e-edea-41a0-ab6f-0bb712a197e5.text:
Let $\C$ be the set of complex numbers.
The structure $\struct {\C, +}$ is an infinite abelian group.

630fe496-c85d-42a8-a73c-04c8b46471e2.text:
Let $p$ and $q$ be distinct odd primes.
Then:
:$\paren {\dfrac p q} \paren {\dfrac q p} = \paren {-1}^{\dfrac {\paren {p - 1} \paren {q - 1} } 4}$
where $\paren {\dfrac p q}$ and $\paren {\dfrac q p}$ are defined as the Legendre symbol.
An alternative formulation is:
$\paren {\dfrac p q} = \begin{cases}
\quad \paren {\dfrac q p} & : p \equiv 1 \lor q \equiv 1 \pmod 4 \\
-\paren {\dfrac q p} & : p \equiv q \equiv 3 \pmod 4
\end{cases}$
The fact that these formulations are equivalent is immediate.
This fact is known as the '''Law of Quadratic Reciprocity''', or '''LQR''' for short.

d9a679a3-b376-4784-bc21-a4a64d15d216.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $f: S \to S$ be an involution.
Then $f$ is a permutation.

79f31e5b-a8c1-48ba-9a63-1e544dcc34eb.text:
Let $L = \struct {S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}$ be a bounded below algebraic lattice.
Let $x, y \in S$ such that
:$y \npreceq x$
Then
:$\exists p \in S: p$ is completely irreducible $\land ~x \preceq p \land y \npreceq p$

b0576b86-d30e-4d57-8e75-c3eca53304e2.text:
Let $C$ be a contour.
Let $f: \Img C \to \C$ be a continuous complex function, where $\Img C$ denotes the image of $C$.
Then:
:$\ds \size {\int_C \map f z \rd z} \le \max_{z \mathop \in \Img C} \size {\map f z} \map L C$
where $\map L C$ denotes the length of $C$.

0953edc8-ab2c-4d8c-9f49-baa9fe558b88.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be a totally ordered set.
Let $a, b \in S$.
Then:
:$a^\succ \cap b^\succ = \paren {\map \max {a, b} }^\succ$
where:
:$a^\succ$ denotes strict upper closure of $a$
:$\max$ denotes the max operation.

c6428562-d3d9-4e21-92af-c97af23aaf46.text:
Let $S$ be a set whose cardinality is $n$.
The number $N$ of possible different commutative binary operations that can be applied to $S$ is given by:
:$N = n^{\frac {n \paren {n + 1} } 2}$

f3834e74-d049-453d-9e3f-9b573e6e0232.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ, \le}$ be a totally ordered ring without proper zero divisors whose zero is $0_R$.
Let $x, y \in R$ be positive, that is, $0_R \le x, y$.
Then $x \le y \iff x \circ x \le y \circ y$.
That is, the square mapping is an order embedding of $\struct {R_{\ge 0}, \le}$ into itself.
When $R$ is one of the standard sets of numbers $\Z, \Q, \R$, then this translates into:
:If $x, y$ are positive, then $x \le y \iff x^2 \le y^2$.

58eac99d-ad36-4ff5-9c9b-6c266518307b.text:
Let $T = \struct {\R, \tau}$ be the compact complement topology on $\R$.
Then $T$ is a sequentially compact space.

ee35f6d6-4741-48b9-bc47-cd5f38c229e8.text:
Let $\struct {S, \prec}$ be a relational structure such that $\prec$ is a strict weak ordering on $S$.
Then $S$ can be partitioned into equivalence classes whose equivalence relation is "is non-comparable".
That is, each of the partitions $A$ of $S$ is a relational structure $\struct {\mathbb S, <}$ such that:
:$\mathbb S$ is the set of these partitions of $S$;
:$<$ is the strict total ordering on $\mathbb S$ '''induced by''' $\prec$.

df6b3142-e840-4ed1-bbc3-fb3b91a009b5.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $A \subseteq B \subseteq S$.
Let $T_B = \struct {B, \tau_B}$ be the topological space where $\tau_B$ is the subspace topology on $B$.
Then
:$A$ is connected in $T_B$ {{iff}} $A$ is connected in $T$.

d93b3ff3-d01d-4529-861c-28dff227d91f.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {\sin^3 a x} = \frac {-\cos a x} {2 a \sin^2 a x} + \frac 1 {2 a} \ln \size {\tan \frac {a x} 2} + C$

aaa602e4-d932-4861-bfd7-59a0e6172345.text:
Let $\struct {S, \RR}$ be a relational structure.
Let $T \subseteq S$ be a subset of $S$.
Let $m \in T$ be a strictly maximal element of $T$ under $\RR$.
Then $m$ is a maximal element of $T$ under $\RR$.

5e4ee8a4-7aa8-4f01-b703-6aca402dc7dc.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a ring with unity $1_R$.
Let $U_R$ be the set of units in $R$.
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $\struct {R^S, +', \circ'}$ be the ring of mappings on the set of mappings $R^S$.
Let $f \in R^S$ be a unit of $R^S$.
Then:
:$\Img f \subseteq U_R$
where $\Img f$ is the image of $f$.
In which case, the inverse of $f$ is the mapping $f^{-1} : S \to U_R$ defined by:
:$\forall x \in S : \map {f^{-1} } x = \map f x^{-1}$

a3e84bab-3512-4957-8926-1dc46548150d.text:
Let $\mathbb S = \family {\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha} }_{\alpha \mathop \in I}$ be an indexed family of non-empty topological spaces for $\alpha$ in some indexing set $I$.
Let $\ds T = \struct{S, \tau} = \prod_{\alpha \mathop \in I} \struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha}$ be the product space of $\mathbb S$.
Let $T$ be a $T_3$ space.
Then for each $\alpha \in I$, $\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha}$ is a $T_3$ space.

fa77c984-6ac3-4902-ad3d-5191ca65cb95.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space which is totally disconnected.
Then $T$ is punctiform.

9617a962-6934-4055-a6ad-6ea0ca2b7c2a.text: Recall the symmetry group of the square:

2365fed0-c5ff-42c7-a660-e162791399ea.text:
Let $n \in \Z_{>0}$ be a (strictly) positive integer.
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Let $\map \phi n$ denote the Euler $\phi$ function of $n$.
Let $p$ be a divisor of $n$.
Then $p - 1$ is a divisor of $\map \phi n$.

f7db71bf-d0d1-4a29-a61b-d5a0ce8c1b45.text: The set of rational numbers $\Q$ forms an ordered field under addition and multiplication: $\struct {\Q, +, \times, \le}$.

6bda99f7-ea1f-4b2d-8a5f-9ec2291b0968.text:
Let $a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n$ be integers.
Then $\gcd \set {a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n} = 1$ {{iff}} there exists an integer combination of them equal to $1$:
:$\exists m_1, m_2, \ldots, m_n \in \Z: \ds \sum_{k \mathop = 1}^n m_k a_k = 1$

319e5506-9758-4213-997d-09a072339b24.text:
Let $a \in \R_{\ne 0}$.
Then:
:$\ds \int \frac {x^2 \rd x} {\sqrt {a x^2 + b x + c} } = \frac {2 a x - 3 b} {4 a^2} \sqrt {a x^2 + b x + c} + \frac {3 b^2 - 4 a c} {8 a^2} \int \frac {\d x} {\sqrt {a x^2 + b x + c} }$

93fd053b-bb29-4a26-8e64-3a90407b2c94.text:
Any smooth, compact, path-connected manifold of dimension $2$ is diffeomorphic to the sphere $\mathbb S^2$, a connected sum of tori $\mathbb T^2$, or a connected sum of projective spaces $\mathbb{RP}^2$.
Any such $2$-manifold with boundary is diffeomorphic to the sphere $\mathbb S^2$, a connected sum of tori $\mathbb T^2$, or a connected sum of projective spaces $\mathbb{RP}^2$, with a number of open disks removed.
The Euler characteristic, orientability, and number of boundary curves suffice to describe a surface.

9dc25c42-52e6-4414-b6e2-1af9c0b70181.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ denote the Arens-Fort space.
Then $T$ is zero dimensional.

9482ffa6-93eb-4696-9e6b-205246891ba9.text:
Let $M_1 = \struct {A_1, d_1}$ and $M_2 = \struct {A_2, d_2}$ be metric spaces.
Let $f_c: A_1 \to A_2$ be the constant mapping from $A_1$ to $A_2$:
:$\exists c \in A_2: \forall a \in A_1: \map {f_c} a = c$
That is, every point in $A_1$ maps to the same point $c$ in $A_2$.
Then $f_c$ is continuous throughout $A_1$ with respect to $d_1$ and $d_2$.

058b85b9-8620-4a6b-a27a-a1fa2d55057a.text:
Let $L = \struct {S, \preceq, \tau}$ be a continuous topological lattice with Scott topology.
Let $p \in S, A \subseteq S$ such that
:$A$ is open and $p \in A$.
Then
:$\exists q \in A: q \ll p$

15a7544c-1f19-424f-8c2a-4e65e3f97e13.text:
Let $\map \delta x$ denote the Dirac delta function.
Let $g$ be a continuous real function.
Then:
:$\ds \int_0^{+ \infty} \map \delta x \map g x \rd x = \map g 0$

870fdaf0-c09c-48b0-9653-f01bb44232db.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be the trivial ring over an underlying set.
Let $\map {\MM_R} n$ denote the $n \times n$ matrix space over $R$.
Then (conventional) matrix multiplication is commutative over $\map {\MM_R} n$:
:$\forall \mathbf A, \mathbf B \in \map {\MM_R} n: \mathbf {A B} = \mathbf {B A}$

21b31e7f-11aa-44c9-a120-bb83adf7d915.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be the either-or space.
Then $T$ is not a locally arc-connected space.

7202e16c-ca5c-4ec4-bc2b-d54dcf8fd678.text:
The smallest $5$ consecutive primes in arithmetic sequence are:
:$9 \, 843 \, 019 + 30 n$
for $n = 0, 1, 2, 3, 4$.
Note that while there are many longer arithmetic sequences of far smaller primes, those primes are not consecutive.

6abf484d-efe3-42df-a15e-1196b8ac84a9.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ, *}$ be an algebraic structure.
Let the operation $\circ$ be left distributive over the operation $*$.
Let $\circ$ be commutative.
Then $\circ$ is distributive over $*$.

25774ea4-2440-403c-ae91-f1fffbdbb8a6.text:
Let $\struct {S_1, \preceq_1}$, $\struct {S_2, \preceq_2}$ be meet semilattices.
Let $f: S_1 \to S_2$ be a mapping.
Let $f$ preserve finite infima and preserve filtered infima.
Then $f$ also preserves all infima

874b8faf-4f35-48ca-8f35-af179270289d.text: The set of transcendental real numbers is uncountable.

5e9cd24c-345f-495d-91e3-860eabbc9594.text:
:$\ds \int x^2 \arcsec \frac x a \rd x = \begin{cases}
\dfrac {x^3} 3 \arcsec \dfrac x a - \dfrac {a x \sqrt {x^2 - a^2} } 6 - \dfrac {a^3} 6 \map \ln {x + \sqrt {x^2 - a^2} } + C & : 0 < \arcsec \dfrac x a < \dfrac \pi 2 \\
\dfrac {x^3} 3 \arcsec \dfrac x a + \dfrac {a x \sqrt {x^2 - a^2} } 6 + \dfrac {a^3} 6 \map \ln {x + \sqrt {x^2 - a^2} } + C & : \dfrac \pi 2 < \arcsec \dfrac x a < \pi \\
\end{cases}$

9a013e44-64ef-4bfe-adb5-5e94a3df0af3.text:
Let $x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n \in \R_{> 0}$ be strictly positive real numbers.
Let $G_n$ be the geometric mean of $x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n$.
Let $H_n$ be the harmonic mean of $x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n$.
Then $G_n \ge H_n$.

2c70a959-1232-4692-b09c-58f06f3949cf.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $\struct {\powerset S, \subseteq}$ be the relational structure defined on $\powerset S$ by the subset relation $\subseteq$.
Then $\struct {\powerset S, \subseteq}$ is a lattice.

84796c10-45e3-43e9-8952-1dc175bc3091.text:
Let $\mathbf C$ be a metacategory.
Let $f: C \to D$ be a morphism in $\mathbf C$ such that $f$ is a monomorphism and a split epimorphism.
Then $f: C \to D$ is a split monomorphism.
{{explain|What are $C$ and $D$?}}

53af6c8b-e4ee-4080-8cc4-01b76d0adba2.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \times}$ be a ring, or a field.
Let $a, b \in R$ and $m, n \in \Z$.
Then:
:$(1): \quad \paren {m + n} \cdot a = \paren {m \cdot a} + \paren {n \cdot a}$
:$(2): \quad m \cdot \paren {a + b} = \paren {m \cdot a} + \paren {m \cdot b}$
where $m \cdot a$ is as defined in integral multiple.

bb58a29f-9f91-4bf6-bb18-d433e9ab214a.text:
Let $\struct {F, +, \circ}$ be a field.
Let $\mathbb K$ be a non-empty set of subfields of $F$.
Let $\bigcap \mathbb K$ be the intersection of the elements of $\mathbb K$.
Then $\bigcap \mathbb K$ is the largest subfield of $F$ contained in each element of $\mathbb K$.

b7c9fdcd-d205-4306-90bc-beb5d2f0379f.text:
Let $T$ be a topological space.
Let $\mathbb B$ be the set of all bases of $T$.
The following definitions of the weight of $T$ are equivalent:

09dffbea-407a-4690-a1c0-cba5bf2f1a5c.text:
Let $T$ be a topological space.
Let $\FF \subseteq \powerset T$ such that 
:every element of $\FF$ is dense-in-itself.
Then the union $\bigcup \FF$ is also dense-in-itself.

5a29b8b1-a2f7-4993-a903-2f01012028fd.text:
Let $I = \closedint a b$.
Let $\map \CC I$ be the set of continuous functions on $I$. 
Let $\map \DD I$ be the set of continuous functions on $I$ that are differentiable at a point.
Let: 
:$\ds A_{n, \, m} = \set {f \in \map \CC I: \text {there exists } x \in I \text { such that } \size {\frac {\map f t - \map f x} {t - x} } \le n \text { for all } t \text { with } 0 < \size {t - x} < \frac 1 m}$
and:
:$\ds A = \bigcup_{\tuple {n, \, m} \in \N^2} A_{n, \, m}$
Then:
:$\map \DD I \subseteq A$

78ec36f9-9a62-4578-b50b-cf2e93365606.text:
Let $A$ and $B$ be ordinals that are order isomorphic.
Then $A = B$.

16b7e1e1-88dd-4432-b8bb-024168ffdbe6.text:
Let $\Q \sqbrk X$ be the ring of polynomial forms over the field of rational numbers in the indeterminate $X$.
Let $\map f X \in \Q \sqbrk X$.
Then:
:$\map f X = \cont f \, \map {f^*} X$
where:
:$\cont f$ is the content of $\map f X$
:$\map {f^*} X$ is a primitive polynomial.

dfa5c28b-423e-4414-97a9-d8c0bd06f152.text:
Let $L = \struct {S, \wedge, \preceq}$ be meet semilattice.
Let $F$ be filter in $L$.
Let $X$ be non empty finite subset of $S$.
Let $x \in S$ such that
: $x \in \paren {\map {\operatorname{fininfs} } {F \cup X} }^\succeq$
where
:$\operatorname{fininfs}$ denotes the finite infima set,
:$X^\succeq$ denotes the upper closure of $X$.
Then there exists $a \in S$: $a \in F \land x \succeq a \wedge \inf X$

dc3eb8b9-ce4f-4ecd-89ae-6ade0edaa3f4.text:
Let $\sequence {E_n}$ be the sequence of real functions $E_n: \R \to \R$ defined as:
:$\map {E_n} x = \paren {1 + \dfrac x n}^n$
Then, for each $x \in \R$ and for sufficiently large $n \in \N$, $\map {E_n} x$ is positive.
That is:
:$\forall x \in \R: \forall n \in \N: n \ge \ceiling {\size x} \implies \map {E_n} x > 0$
where $\ceiling x$ denotes the ceiling of $x$.

e1f03ec4-fa84-4704-a78f-89b10f0e575a.text:
Let $n$ be a positive integer.
Let $\map {\sigma_1} n$ denote the divisor sum function of $n$.
Then:
:$\ds \sum_{d \mathop \divides n} \frac 1 d = \frac {\map {\sigma_1} n} n$
where $\dfrac {\map {\sigma_1} n} n$ is the abundancy index of $n$.

92c5cce3-49b0-46ea-8657-f226409fa4c6.text:
The center of a group is the intersection of all the centralizers of the elements of that group:
:$\ds \map Z G = \bigcap_{g \mathop \in G} \map {C_G} g$

704d0b49-0e1f-49ff-8291-251c0e31d244.text:
Let $a \in \R_{\ne 0}$.
Then:
:$\displaystyle \int \frac {\d x} {x \paren {a x^2 + b x + c}^2} = \frac 1 {2 c \paren {a x^2 + b x + c} } - \frac b {2 c} \int \frac {\d x} {\paren {a x^2 + b x + c}^2} + \frac 1 c \int \frac {\d x} {x \paren {a x^2 + b x + c} }$

681c6965-795a-40f1-aa29-439ede82d6e7.text:
Let $S$ be a neighborhood space.
Let $I$ be an indexing set.
Let $\family {U_\alpha}_{\alpha \mathop \in I}$ be a family of open sets of $\struct {S, \NN}$ indexed by $I$.
Then their union $\ds \bigcup_{\alpha \mathop \in I} U_i$ is an open set of $\struct {S, \NN}$.

8fe4e339-624a-4549-adb5-4c0749a8f732.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {x \paren {x^3 + a^3}^2} = \frac 1 {3 a^3 \paren {x^3 + a^3} } + \frac 1 {3 a^6} \ln \size {\frac {x^3} {x^3 + a^3} }$

41c11deb-b910-4fa4-93bc-569a2be00969.text:
:$\ds \int_0^{\pi/2} \sec x \map \ln {\frac {1 + b \cos x} {1 + a \cos x} } \rd x = \frac 1 2 \paren {\paren {\arccos a}^2 - \paren {\arccos b}^2}$
where $a$ and $b$ are real numbers with $-1 < a, b < 1$.

4bc51ed1-489b-4bcd-9b33-4d1de671fd5f.text: :$\ds \int \cot^n a x \rd x = \frac {-\cot^{n - 1} a x} {\paren {n - 1} a} - \int \cot^{n - 2} a x \rd x + C$

8e26752f-87fb-418b-b783-b7b8d98bf028.text:
Let $S$ be the set of straight lines in the plane.
For $l_1, l_2 \in S$, let $l_1 \parallel l_2$ denote that $l_1$ is parallel to $l_2$.
Then $\parallel$ is a reflexive relation on $S$.

e3e90bd8-f7cd-4180-8e6e-2888ca5f536d.text:
Let $\Bbb F$ be a field, usually one of the standard number fields $\Q$, $\R$ or $\C$.
Let $n \in \Z_{>0}$ be a (strictly) positive integer.
Let $\map \MM n$ denote the matrix space of order $n$ square matrices over $\Bbb F$.
Let $\mathbf B$ be an inverse matrix of $\mathbf A$.
Then $\mathbf B$ is the only inverse matrix of $\mathbf A$.

dfbc1ce3-e6c6-41fb-a8b0-eff2efc58c10.text:
For every pair of integers $a, b$ where $b > 0$, there exist unique integers $q, r$ such that $a = q b + r$ and $0 \le r < b$:
:$\forall a, b \in \Z, b > 0: \exists! q, r \in \Z: a = q b + r, 0 \le r < b$
In the above equation:
:$a$ is the '''dividend'''
:$b$ is the '''divisor'''
:$q$ is the '''quotient'''
:$r$ is the '''principal remainder''', or, more usually, just the '''remainder'''.

71e5c7e1-303f-414b-add1-2adf070d4331.text:
Let $a \in \Z$ be an integer such that:
:$(1): \quad a$ is not a power of $2$
:$(2): \quad \dfrac a 2$ is an even integer.
Then $a$ is both even-times even and even-times odd.
{{EuclidPropStatement|book=IX|prop=34|body=If a number neither be one of those which are continually doubled from a dyad, nor have its half odd, it is both even-times even and even-times odd.}}

463e3e43-0d8e-4d0c-8a3a-e0fda89a8a29.text:
:$\ds \int \sec a x \rd x = \frac 1 a \ln \size {\sec a x + \tan a x} + C$
where $\sec a x + \tan a x \ne 0$.

2a016604-2f7d-41cf-a365-5e876be1cdbe.text:
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ be a sequence in $\R$.
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ be decreasing and unbounded below.
Then $x_n \to -\infty$ as $n \to \infty$.

37ed7a16-5d6b-4985-9bf1-65116f517db6.text:
Let $M_1 = \struct {A_1, d_1}$ and $M_2 = \struct {A_2, d_2}$ be metric spaces.
Let $f: A_1 \to A_2$ be a uniformly continuous mapping on $A_1$.
Then $M_1$ does not necessarily have to be a compact metric space.

d362f073-669a-4eca-9b10-de5f30097736.text:
Consider the one-parameter family of curves:
:$(1): \quad x^2 + y^2 = 2 c x$
which describes the loci of circles tangent to the $y$-axis at the origin.
Its family of orthogonal trajectories is given by the equation:
:$x^2 + y^2 = 2 c y$
which describes the loci of circles tangent to the $x$-axis at the origin.
:600px

189884dd-bbcd-46aa-9d29-ed771a3d6b5b.text:
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ be the real sequence defined as $x_n = n^{1/n}$, using exponentiation.
Then $\sequence {x_n}$ converges with a limit of $1$.

24b4da07-5f43-4bb5-8bee-5e5498b4b77c.text:
Let $\mathbf A, \mathbf B$ be square matrices of order $n$ over a commutative ring with unity $\left({R, +, \circ}\right)$.
Suppose that:
: $\mathbf A \mathbf B = \mathbf I_n$
where $\mathbf I_n$ is the unit matrix of order $n$.
Then $\mathbf A$ and $\mathbf B$ are invertible matrices, and furthermore:
:$\mathbf B = \mathbf A^{-1}$
where $\mathbf A^{-1}$ is the inverse of $\mathbf A$.

426da930-345b-47ea-86a0-f4b4b4af1f93.text:
Let $\struct {S, \tau_{_S} }$ be a topological space.
Let $\struct {R, +, *, \tau_{_R} }$ be a topological ring.
Let $\lambda \in R$.
Let $f: \struct {S, \tau_{_S} } \to \struct {R, \tau_{_R} }$ be a continuous mapping.
Let $\lambda + f: S \to R$ be the mapping defined by:
:$\forall x \in S: \map {\paren {\lambda + f} } x = \lambda + \map f x$
Then 
:$\lambda + f: \struct {S, \tau_{_S} } \to \struct {R, \tau_{_R} }$ is continuous.

f9ba5671-192d-430b-adf3-f9eafb9413ba.text: The Gamma function is never equal to $0$.

d7db076f-a423-4ad5-83ea-f0ce51b739d6.text:
Let $\exp: \R \to \R$ be the exponential function:
:$\map \exp x = e^x$
Then the restriction of the codomain of $\exp$ to the strictly positive real numbers:
:$\exp: \R \to \R_{>0}$
is a surjective restriction.
Hence:
:$\exp: \R \to \R_{>0}$
is a bijection.

1e79319e-9cb2-45a5-b585-fc014b6cf5b0.text:
The closed-form expression for the $n$th triangular number is:
:$\ds T_n = \sum_{i \mathop = 1}^n i = \frac {n \paren {n + 1} } 2$

5f74369e-eac6-4135-a221-53315fba9144.text:
Let $\left({S, \preceq}\right)$ ne an ordered set.
Let $s$ be an element of $S$.
Then $s^\preceq$ is ideal in $\left({S, \preceq}\right)$
where $s^\preceq$ denotes the lower closure of $s$.

e2492922-105e-4496-8866-6869b87fd4d0.text:
Let $m \in \Z$ be an integer such that $m > 2$.
Let $\Z_m$ be the set of integers modulo $m$:
:$\Z_m = \left\{{\left[\!\left[{0}\right]\!\right]_m, \left[\!\left[{1}\right]\!\right]_m, \ldots, \left[\!\left[{m - 1}\right]\!\right]_m}\right\}$
Then there exists at least one residue in $\Z_m$ which is not the product modulo $m$ of a residue with itself:
:$\exists p \in \Z_M: \forall x \in \Z_m: x \cdot_m x \ne p$

ae689439-b7f0-4cfd-a034-9febfe39930f.text:
Let $\left({S, \preceq}\right)$ be an ordered set.
Let $T \subseteq S$ be a lower set.
Then $T$ is convex in $S$.

5f8a74fa-94da-4422-abe2-707da20c0553.text:
Let $\struct {\Q, \tau_d}$ be the rational number space under the Euclidean topology $\tau_d$.
Let $p$ be a new element not in $\Q$.
Let $\Q^* := \Q \cup \set p$.
Let $T^* = \struct {\Q^*, \tau^*}$ be the Alexandroff extension on $\struct {\Q, \tau_d}$.
Then $T^*$ is a $T_1$ (Fréchet) space.

cbf9d5e5-4df0-4b61-acc8-e904a597584a.text:
Let $A$ be a $*$-algebra.
Let $A'$ be constructed from $A$ using the Cayley-Dickson construction.
Then $A'$ is not a real algebra.

ad724b2a-0f4a-4a77-9c38-d2b17c03e18d.text:
Let $\struct {X, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $Y$ be a non-empty subset of $X$.
Let $\iota: Y \to X$ be the inclusion mapping.
Let $\tau_Y$ be the initial topology on $Y$ with respect to $\iota$.
Then $\struct {Y, \tau_Y}$ is a topological subspace of $\struct {X, \tau}$.
That is:
:$\tau_Y = \set {U \cap Y: U \in \tau}$

a426398f-44fd-4527-a7fa-4428c64d86fe.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $\RR \subseteq S \times S$ be a reflexive relation on $S$.
Let $T \subseteq S$ be a subset of $S$.
Let $\RR {\restriction_T} \subseteq T \times T$ be the restriction of $\RR$ to $T$.
Then $\RR {\restriction_T}$ is a reflexive relation on $T$.

4719201f-d9a8-415b-a0b0-ebc93a1c73bb.text:
Let $P = \sequence {a_j}_{0 \mathop \le j \mathop \le n}$ be a geometric sequence of integers of length $n$.
Let $a_0$ not be a divisor of $a_1$.
Then:
:$\forall j, k \in \set {0, 1, \ldots, n}, j \ne k: a_j \nmid a_k$
That is, if the initial term of $P$ does not divide the second, no term of $P$ divides any other term of $P$.
{{EuclidPropStatement|book = VIII|prop = 6|body = If there be as many numbers as we please in continued proportion, and the first do not measure the second, neither will any other measure any other.}}

ee279555-452c-4c95-b2df-ca509524b6b0.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be a monoid whose identity is $e_S$.
Let $x, y \in S$ such that $x$ and $y$ are both invertible.
Then $x \circ y \circ x^{-1} = y$ {{iff}} $x$ and $y$ commute.

6ba27b3c-553f-49dc-8688-14cfa6dfed59.text:
Let $\On$ be the ordinal class.
Then:
:$\forall x, y \in \On: x + y \in \On$
That is: the sum $x+y$ is an ordinal.

5ef5fb82-519d-419e-aee4-e3600c0804ef.text:
:$\ds \sum_{i \mathop = 0}^n \binom n i = 2^n$
where $\dbinom n i$ is a binomial coefficient.

3b7210d7-40c9-4305-9132-9bae3a4edba4.text:
Let $\alpha$ be a cut.
Let $0^*$ denote the rational cut associated with the (rational) number $0$.
Then:
:$\alpha 0^* = 0^*$
where $\alpha 0^*$ denote the product of $\alpha$ and $0^*$.

946b8713-ffae-40a2-bc58-e98812bab769.text:
Let $L/K$ be a field extension and $\alpha_1,\ldots,\alpha_n \in L$ algebraic over $K$.
Then $K \left({\alpha_1, \ldots, \alpha_n}\right) / K$ is a finite field extension.

fb14155b-28a7-43d6-9e54-e7869e33f7e6.text:
Let $P$ be a propositional function on the natural numbers $\N$.
Suppose that:
:$(1): \quad \forall n \in \N: \map P {2^n}$ holds.
:$(2): \quad \map P n \implies \map P {n - 1}$.
Then $\map P n$ holds for all $\forall n \in \N$.
The proof technique based on this result is called '''backwards induction'''.

5785f101-4460-49b0-b618-a1963704ed3c.text:
Let $\CC$ be a double napped right circular cone with apex $O$.
Let $\PP$ be a plane which intersects $\CC$ such that:
:$\PP$ does not pass through $O$
:$\PP$ is not perpendicular to the axis of $\CC$.
Let $\EE$ be the conic section arising as the intersection between $\PP$ and $\CC$.
Let $\SS$ and $\SS'$ be the Dandelin spheres with respect to $\PP$.
