Let $A \sqcup B$ be the disjoint union of $A$ and $B$.
Then the free monoid $\map M {A \sqcup B}$ on $A \sqcup B$ is the coproduct of $\map M A$ and $\map M B$ in $\mathbf {Mon}$.

87afd24c-a394-4078-932c-f2af688c9155.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Then:
:$\ds S = \bigcup_{X \mathop \in \powerset S} X$
where $\powerset S$ denotes the power set of $S$.

fe22b8ce-4fd9-4739-91d2-c5799d1cf3f7.text:
Let $m, n \in \Z_{\ge 0}$.
:$\ds \sum_k \binom {m - n} {m + k} \binom {m + n} {n + k} {m + k \brack k} = {n \brace n - m}$
where:
:$\dbinom {m - n} {m + k}$ etc. denote binomial coefficients
:$\ds {m + k \brack k}$ denotes an unsigned Stirling number of the first kind
:$\ds {n \brace n - m}$ denotes a Stirling number of the second kind.

dceeacf7-ca48-45d5-a0b5-b571e4b76692.text:
Let $A$ be a class.
Let $\RR$ be a set-like endorelation on $A$.
Let $B \subseteq A$ be a set.
Then $\map {\RR^{-1} } B$, the inverse image of $B$ under $\RR$, is also a set.

fcdf3497-17cd-43c7-86b9-f458df04033d.text:
Let $u$ be a differentiable real function of $x$.
Let $e^u$ be the exponential function of $u$.
Then:
:$\map {\dfrac \d {\d x} } {e^u} = e^u \dfrac {\d u} {\d x}$

1cd104cd-cdfc-4920-9b7a-cd23fee10088.text:
{{EuclidPropStatement|book=V|prop=8|body=Of unequal magnitudes, the greater has to the same a greater ratio than the less has; and the same has to the less a greater ratio than it has to the greater.}}
That is:
:$a > b \implies a : c > b : c$
:$a > b \implies c : a < c : b$

ceaee923-2dd4-4377-8755-efd38043d785.text:
The set of rational numbers less zero is closed under division:
:$\forall a, b \in \Q_{\ne 0}: a / b \in \Q_{\ne 0}$

79e42e7e-562e-4c98-987c-b1af38469ab4.text:
Let $G$ be a group, and let:
:$H, N$ be normal subgroups of $G$
:$N$ be a subset of $H$.
Then:
:$(1): \quad H / N$ is a normal subgroup of $G / N$
:::where $H / N$ denotes the quotient group of $H$ by $N$
:$(2): \quad \dfrac {G / N} {H / N} \cong \dfrac G H$
:::where $\cong$ denotes group isomorphism.
Let $G$ be a group.
Let $N$ be a normal subgroup of $G$.
Let $q: G \to \dfrac G N$ be the quotient epimorphism from $G$ to the quotient group $\dfrac G N$.
Let $K$ be the kernel of $q$.
Then:
:$\dfrac G N \cong \dfrac {G / K} {N / K}$
Let $G$ and $H$ be groups whose identities are $e_G$ and $e_H$ respectively.
Let $\phi: G \to H$ be a group homomorphism.
Let $K$ be the kernel of $\phi$.
Let $N$ be a normal subgroup of $G$.
Let $q: G \to \dfrac G N$ be the quotient epimorphism from $G$ to the quotient group $\dfrac G N$.
Then $N \subseteq K$ {{iff}} there exists a group homomorphism $\psi: \dfrac G N \to H$ such that:
:$\phi = \psi \circ q$
and:
:$\dfrac G K \cong \dfrac {G / N} {K / N}$

5cdf7ceb-ba53-4e5e-a9b1-4e8e508fc1b5.text:
Let $f: \R \to \R$ be a real function.
Then:
:$(1): \quad \ds \lim_{x \mathop \to +\infty} \map f x = +\infty \implies \lim_{x \mathop \to +\infty} -\map f x = -\infty$
:$(2): \quad \ds \lim_{x \mathop \to -\infty} \map f x = +\infty \implies \lim_{x \mathop \to -\infty} -\map f x = -\infty$

38f173bc-1af2-4ed1-a2ce-a97bcf14e9c1.text:
Let $G$ be a non-trivial abelian group.
Then $G$ is simple {{iff}} $G$ is a prime group.

1d18e3d6-c1ab-412e-be21-05ffa8223996.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be a finite semigroup.
For every element in $\struct {S, \circ}$, there is a power of that element which is idempotent.
That is:
:$\forall x \in S: \exists i \in \N: x^i = x^i \circ x^i$

c0d03aa1-540a-4ccc-b0e7-60ae7d85c4a9.text:
Let $\SS$ be an algebra of sets.
Let $A_1, A_2, \ldots, A_n$ be finite sets which are pairwise disjoint.
Let $f: \SS \to \R$ be an additive function.
Then:
:$\ds \map f {\bigcup_{i \mathop = 1}^n A_i} = \sum_{i \mathop = 1}^n \map f {A_i}$

25e1d7ee-c921-49e1-8f2a-ca1361204383.text:
:$\sin x - \cos x = \sqrt 2 \, \map \cos {x - \dfrac {3 \pi} 4}$
where $\sin$ denotes sine and $\cos$ denotes cosine.

e2f60140-38de-4a26-add1-83940f3db1d6.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be an algebraic structure.
Let $\struct {T, \circ} \subseteq \struct {S, \circ}$.
Let $x \in T$ be left cancellable in $S$.
Then $x$ is also left cancellable in $T$.

f9d19e2e-8a7a-42d6-a36e-ea4e54829dc2.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be a group whose identity is $e$.
Let $\RR$ be a congruence relation for $\circ$.
Let $H = \eqclass e \RR$, where $\eqclass e \RR$ is the equivalence class of $e$ under $\RR$.
Then:
:$(1): \quad \struct {H, \circ \restriction_H}$ is a normal subgroup of $G$
:$(2): \quad \RR$ is the equivalence relation $\RR_H$ defined by $H$
:$(3): \quad \struct {G / \RR, \circ_\RR}$ is the subgroup $\struct {G / H, \circ_H}$ of the semigroup $\struct {\powerset G, \circ_\PP}$.

4c9c89c9-8239-48ea-a377-70c5853b55a1.text:
Let $m, n \in \Z_{>0}$ be (strictly) positive integers.
Let $\struct {\Z_m, +}$ denote the additive group of integers modulo $m$.
The number of distinct homomorphisms $\phi: \struct {\Z_m, +} \to \struct {\Z_n, +}$ is $\gcd \set {m, n}$.

a0bd26c6-704e-47e8-b6a4-f66ce632032c.text:
Let $\struct {\Z, +}$ denote the additive group of integers.
Let $\struct {\Z_m, +}$ denote the additive group of integers modulo $m$.
Let $\phi: \struct {\Z, +} \to \struct {\Z_m, +}$ be the homomorphism defined as:
:$\forall k \in \Z: \map \phi k = \eqclass {n k} m$
for some $n \in \Z$.
Let $d := \gcd \set {m, n}$, where $\gcd \set {m, n}$ denotes the GCD of $m$ and $n$.
Let $c := \dfrac m d = \dfrac m {\gcd \set {m, n} }$.
Then $\phi$ can be decomposed into the form:
:$\phi = \alpha \beta \gamma$
in the following way:
:$\alpha: \struct {d \, \Z_c, +} \to \struct {\Z_m, +}$ is defined as:
::$\forall x \in d \, \Z_c: \map \alpha x = x$
:where $d \, \Z_c := \set {0, d, 2 d, \ldots, \paren {c - 1} d}$
:$\beta: \Z_c \to d \, \Z_c$ is defined as:
::$\forall \eqclass x c \in \Z_c: \map \beta {\eqclass x c} = \eqclass {n x} m$
:$\gamma: \Z \to \Z_c$ is defined as:
::$\forall x \in \Z: \map \gamma x = \eqclass {x \bmod c} c$
:where $\bmod$ denotes the modulo operation.

9d3cc7c1-ea01-454a-9960-3877bc72e252.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ and $\struct {T, *}$ be algebraic structures.
Let $\phi: \struct {S, \circ} \to \struct {T, *}$ be an isomorphism.
If $\struct {S, \circ}$ is a group, then so is $\struct {T, *}$.

722a9b05-b6b6-4e70-bfbd-2b708dc6393d.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=X|prop=106|body=A straight line commensurable with that which produces with a rational area a medial whole is a straight line which produces with a rational area a medial whole.}}

847d8c83-f6ff-4b66-a053-0c69fdcf991e.text:
Let $\mu^*$ be an outer measure on a set $X$.
Then the set of $\mu^*$-measurable sets is an algebra of sets.

3cb0d88d-4fbd-4f3b-b87d-6f3178f18a75.text:
Let $T_1 = \left({S, \preceq, \tau_1}\right)$ and $T_2 = \left({S, \preceq, \tau_2}\right)$ be relational structures with lower topologies.
Then:
: $\tau_1 = \tau_2$

f5c5e51e-858b-473f-98f8-626b0d05ff91.text:
:$\ds \int_0^\infty e^{-x^2} \ln x \rd x = -\frac {\sqrt \pi} 4 \paren {\gamma + 2 \ln 2}$
where $\gamma$ denotes the Euler-Mascheroni constant.

7a3d6bf5-847a-4f5d-bcc7-87c63b452cb2.text:
For all numbers $a, b$ where $a, b$ in $\N, \Z, \Q$ or $\R$:
:$\min \set {a, b} = \dfrac 1 2 \paren {a + b - \size {a - b} }$

0226128d-0ea7-4408-bcc5-6f120e683da2.text:
Let $\left({S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}\right)$ and $\left({T, \vee_2, \wedge_2, \precsim}\right)$ be bounded below continuous lattices.
Let $f: S \to T$ be a mapping such that
:$f$ preserves directed suprema.
Let $x \in S$.
Then $f\left({x}\right) = \sup \left\{ {f\left({w}\right): w \in S \land w \ll x}\right\}$

d35e89e6-5efe-450a-89a5-aa74f2fbb53d.text:
The intersection of a set and its complement is the empty set:
:$S \cap \map \complement S = \O$

01472b5f-6c68-42c3-a317-b3887ef0784a.text:
Let $\struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $f: S \to S$ be a continuous involution.
Then $f$ is a homeomorphism.

004c6bc1-6a24-4252-970e-4a826dc09cbb.text:
Let $S$ and $T$ be sets that are equinumerous to their cardinal number.
Let $\left|{S}\right|$ denote the cardinal number of $S$.
Suppose $S$ is infinite.
Suppose $T > 0$.
Then:
:$\left|{S \times T}\right| = \max\left({\left|{S}\right|, \left|{T}\right| }\right)$

61d95d16-3fd4-4b7e-9517-86709ebb2b3e.text:
Denote with $\mathbf{Set}$ the category of sets.
Let $A, B$ be sets, and let $f: A \to B$ be a mapping.
Let $V \subseteq B$ be a subset of $B$.
Denote with $i: V \to B$ the inclusion mapping.
Let $f^{-1} \left({V}\right) \subseteq A$ be the preimage of $V$ under $f$.
Denote with $j: f^{-1} \left({V}\right) \to A$ the inclusion mapping.
Denote with $\bar f = f \restriction_{f^{-1} \left({V}\right)}$ the restriction of $f$ to $f^{-1} \left({V}\right)$.
Then:
::$\begin{xy}\xymatrix{
 f^{-1} \left({V}\right)
  \ar[r]^*+{\bar f}
  \ar[d]_*+{j}
&
 V
  \ar[d]^*+{i}
\\
 A
  \ar[r]_*+{f}
&
 B
}\end{xy}$
is a pullback diagram in $\mathbf{Set}$.

b9f51854-e284-4bdd-926d-da9981de7ab9.text:
Let $\struct {S, \vee, \preceq}$ be a join semilattice.
Then $\vee$ is idempotent.

d0c3e1ea-0ced-4254-ad32-85cb48ef7018.text:
Let $L = \left({S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}\right)$ be a bounded below algebraic distributive lattice.
Assume that
:for every element $p$ of $S$ if $p$ is pseudoprime element, then $p$ is prime element.
Then $L$ is arithmetic.

098e3798-38d1-4bfd-aa96-2b4bf9c4274c.text:
Let $N \in \N$ be expressed as:
:$N = a_0 + a_1 10 + a_2 10^2 + \cdots + a_n 10^n$
Then $N$ is divisible by $11$ {{iff}} $\displaystyle \sum_{r \mathop = 0}^n \paren {-1}^r a_r$ is  divisible by $11$.
That is, a divisibility test for $11$ is achieved by alternately adding and subtracting the digits and taking the result modulo $11$.

8c205abe-003a-402c-bbaf-cd42866fa06f.text:
Let $G$ be an abelian group.
Let $a, b \in G$.
Then:
:$\order {a b} \divides \lcm \set {\order a, \order b}$
where:
:$\order a$ denotes the order of $a$
:$\divides$ denotes divisibility
:$\lcm$ denotes the lowest common multiple.

ed6724f8-554f-4c84-b291-c8121c0f95e4.text:
Let $\mathbf A = \sqbrk a_n$ be a square matrix of order $n$.
Let $\map \det {\mathbf A}$ be the determinant of $\mathbf A$.
Let $\mathbf B$ be the matrix resulting from one column of $\mathbf A$ having been multiplied by a constant $c$.
Then:
:$\map \det {\mathbf B} = c \map \det {\mathbf A}$
That is, multiplying one column of a square matrix by a constant multiplies its determinant by that constant.

fefe6c75-bcd1-4875-9f9e-ffb11be1da09.text:
{{Expand|Include the exponents $0, -\infty, +\infty$}}
Let $p, q \in \R_{\ne 0}$ be non-zero real numbers with $p < q$.
Let $x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n \ge 0$ be real numbers.
If $p < 0$, then we require that $x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n > 0$.
Then the Hölder mean satisfies the inequality:
:$\map {M_p} {x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n} \le \map {M_q} {x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n}$
Equality holds {{iff}} $x_1 = x_2 = \cdots = x_n$.

c8d10d36-42a6-49b8-8b35-2e54e6ab1303.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {\cos^n a x} = \frac {\sin a x} {a \paren {n - 1} \cos^{n - 1} a x} + \frac {n - 2} {n - 1} \int \frac {\d x} {\cos^{n - 2} a x}$

a72b761b-6860-47d0-9319-b19d0de1c88b.text:
Let $f: S \to T$ be a mapping.
Let $\mathcal R_f \subseteq S \times S$ be the relation induced by $f$:
:$\tuple {s_1, s_2} \in \mathcal R_f \iff \map f {s_1} = \map f {s_2}$
Let $f$ be a surjection.
Then there are $\card T$ different $\mathcal R_f$-classes.

637a0be9-24eb-4e40-83c8-386cdf7f8bb6.text:
Let $X$ be a set, and let $\DD$ be a Dynkin system on $X$.
Then the empty set $\O$ is an element of $\DD$.

7a48b54f-5d07-4ad2-ae54-639831e8d73b.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $\mathcal R \subseteq S \times S$ be a relation on $S$.
Let $\mathcal R$ be antitransitive.
Then $\mathcal R$ is also antireflexive.

69476a9d-371a-44f1-b4f5-2eb7edd7bb16.text:
Let $\left({S. \preceq}\right)$ be an ordered set.
Let $s$ be an element of $S$.
Then:
:$\sup \left({s^\preceq}\right) = s$
where $s^\preceq$ denotes the lower closure of $s$.

2bd62cfa-7ea5-490a-b0ac-02c4554cde5e.text:
Let $E$ be a vector space of $n$ dimensions.
Let $H$ be a linearly independent subset of $E$.
$H$ is a basis for $E$ {{iff}} it contains exactly $n$ elements.

b2dddca8-2432-42ad-bf84-2e735ac49a2e.text:
$239$ cannot be expressed as the sum of fewer than $19$ fourth powers:
:$239 = 13 \times 1^4 + 4 \times 2^4 + 2 \times 3^4$

b5d50cb1-230f-4436-a62a-0e538b8921c6.text:
Let $F$ be an algebraically closed field.
Then $F$ is perfect.

27b52980-9ee2-4795-858f-6d57dc1f747e.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a Hausdorff space which is compact.
Then $\tau$ is the minimal subset of the power set $\powerset S$ such that $T$ is a Hausdorff space.

71188e2f-30c4-4dae-8716-6ab94507467c.text:
Let $\ds \map f x := \sum_{n \mathop = 0}^\infty a_n \paren {x - \xi}^n$ be a power series about a point $\xi$.
Let $R$ be the radius of convergence of $S$.
Then $\map f x$ is a continuous function on $\set {x: \size {x - \xi} < R}$.

396a1e72-c125-47ca-8962-f63402580fad.text:
Let $T_1, T_2$ be subsets of a universe $\mathbb U$.
Then:
:$\overline {T_1 \cap T_2} = \overline T_1 \cup \overline T_2$
where $\overline T_1$ is the set complement of $T_1$.
It is arguable that this notation may be easier to follow:
:$\map \complement {T_1 \cap T_2} = \map \complement {T_1} \cup \map \complement {T_2}$

6f48a57c-1b07-4b47-9a0f-28cca6bb2b20.text:
Let $\ds \sum_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty a_n$ be an absolutely convergent series in $\R$.
Then $\ds \sum_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty a_n$ is convergent.

833af665-132f-4f52-a74a-7d633ff248d1.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Let $\struct {\Q_p, \norm {\,\cdot\,}_p}$ be the $p$-adic numbers.
Let $\Z_p$ be the $p$-adic integers.
Let $a \in \Q_p$.
For all $\epsilon \in \R_{>0}$:
:let $\map {S_\epsilon} a$ denote the sphere of $a$ of radius $\epsilon$. 
:let $\map {B_\epsilon} a$ denote the open ball of $a$ of radius $\epsilon$. 
Then:
:$\forall n \in Z : \map {S_{p^{-n} } } a = \displaystyle \bigcup_{i \mathop = 1}^{p - 1} \map {B_{p^{-n} } } {a + i p^n}$

c4760253-f7b7-4ae8-b3cc-3c5669e8e3f7.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a partition space.
Then $T$ is zero dimensional.

eb23d556-a3ca-4c4e-8b8c-c3846779721d.text:
Let $\tuple {x, y, z}$ be a primitive Pythagorean triple.
Then:
:$x \perp y$
:$y \perp z$
:$x \perp z$
That is, all elements of $\tuple {x, y, z}$ are pairwise coprime.

b6bad3a3-9bb0-4d4f-97fa-3e7d8b3c6af6.text:
Let $G$ be a finite group.
Let $\mathbb S = \set {S \subseteq G: \card S = p^n}$ where $p$ is prime.
That is, the set of all subsets of $G$ whose cardinality is the power of a prime number.
Let $G$ act on $\mathbb S$ by the group action defined in Group Action on Sets with k Elements:
:$\forall S \in \mathbb S: g * S = g S = \set {x \in G: x = g s: s \in S}$.
Then:
:$\Stab S$ is a $p$-subgroup of $G$.

3ef79025-f12b-4551-9812-6bb75470010f.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ, \norm {\, \cdot \,} }$ be a normed division ring.
Let $\struct {R^\N, +, \circ}$ be the ring of sequences over $R$ with unity $\tuple {1, 1, 1, \dotsc}$.
Let $\CC \subset R^\N$ be the set of Cauchy sequences on $R$.
Then:
:$\struct {\CC, +, \circ}$ is a subring of $R^\N$ with unity $\tuple {1, 1, 1, \dotsc}$.

de851a42-f38f-4061-bcf9-c40cc26c0a76.text:
Let $\struct {S_1, \circ_1}$ and $\struct {S_2, \circ_2}$ be algebraic structures with identities $e_1, e_2$ respectively.
The canonical injections:
:$\inj_1: \struct {S_1, \circ_1} \to \struct {S_1, \circ_1} \times \struct {S_2, \circ_2}: \forall x \in S_1: \map {\inj_1} x = \tuple {x, e_2}$
:$\inj_2: \struct {S_2, \circ_2} \to \struct {S_1, \circ_1} \times \struct {S_2, \circ_2}: \forall x \in S_2: \map {\inj_2} x = \tuple {e_1, x}$
are monomorphisms.

de9240e9-56cf-43a0-ba84-3a992d48ec97.text:
Let $\struct {\R \setminus \Q, \tau_d}$ be the irrational number space under the Euclidean topology $\tau_d$.
Then $\struct {\R \setminus \Q, \tau_d}$ is a completely normal space.

5b7c719d-1c8c-402b-a675-5c0cf22a3d91.text:
Let $T = \left({S, \tau}\right)$ be a compact space.
Then $T$ is a weakly locally compact.

f9f05145-bd90-40d8-b521-adb333906c32.text:
Let $\Omega$ denote the first uncountable ordinal.
Let $\Gamma$ be a limit ordinal which strictly precedes $\Omega$.
Let $\closedint 0 \Gamma$ denote the closed ordinal space on $\Gamma$.
Then $\closedint 0 \Gamma$ is a metrizable space.

9d00325f-11ef-4389-b49e-d53adef3c574.text:
Let $L = \left({S, \preceq}\right)$ be an ordered set.
Then $\operatorname{ClSystems}\left({L}\right)$ is an ordered set,
where $\operatorname{ClSystems}\left({L}\right)$ denotes the ordered set of closure systems.

dd024d45-6a4b-4d57-aae2-9971a2a8d5ca.text:
Let $X$ be a set.
Let $\Sigma$ be a $\sigma$-algebra on $X$.
Let $E \subseteq X$ be a subset of $X$.
Then the trace $\sigma$-algebra $\Sigma_E$ is a $\sigma$-algebra on $E$.

7ae38b3c-7d88-4547-a5a9-0f46e7a0fe9a.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \set {\O, S} }$ be an indiscrete topological space.
Let $H \subseteq S$ such that $H \ne \O$.
Then $H$ is everywhere dense.

7c3be836-8640-48d2-8240-8220c55867d3.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \set {\O, S} }$ be an indiscrete topological space .
Then $T$ is a $T_3$ space.

c00aafd7-956d-4765-bc3a-5db1d0a52617.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau_p}$ be the fortissimo space on an uncountable set $S$.
Then $T$ is not a separable space.

b37bcee3-8d65-4792-8e2c-2a99cb733766.text:
Let $k \in \Z$, $r \in \R$.
:$\dbinom r k \dbinom {r - \frac 1 2} k = \dfrac {\dbinom {2 r} k \dbinom {2 r - k} k} {4^k}$
where $\dbinom r k$ denotes a binomial coefficient.

0004e111-72a5-4059-9240-06b3bcef07a3.text:
Let $x \in \R$ be a strictly positive real number.
Let $a \in \R$ be a real number such that $a > 1$.
Let $r \in \R$ be any real number.
Let $\ln x$ be the natural logarithm of $x$.
Then:
:$\map \ln {x^r} = r \ln x$

7b47951f-35d3-4fcb-91ab-ff2ca16ee7ab.text:
:$\arccos x = 2 \map \arctan {\sqrt {\dfrac {1 - x} {1 + x} } }$
where $x$ is a real number with $-1 < x \le 1$

af26f996-d87d-4296-88b3-b719e471dc31.text:
:$\cos x - \sin x = \sqrt 2 \, \map \sin {x + \dfrac {3 \pi} 4}$
where $\sin$ denotes sine and $\cos$ denotes cosine.

15d488ca-2b4f-4753-b184-f22d038255b5.text:
Let $M = \struct {S, d}$ be the standard discrete metric space on a set $A$.
Let $H \subseteq S$ be a subset of $S$.
Then $H$ has no limit points.

2385217d-345b-4415-9bb5-085039b067db.text:
Let $G$ be a group.
Let $H$ be a subgroup of $G$ with the property that:
:$\forall x \in G: x^2 \in H$
The quotient group $G / H$ is abelian.

cbe2fd73-d587-4993-a1c3-09a1e50b5a99.text:
Let $S$ be a subset of the set of real numbers $\R$.
Let $x \in \R$ be a real number.
Let $\map d {x, S}$ be the distance between $x$ and $S$.
Then:
:$x \in S \implies \map d {x, S} = 0$

2a1d60c6-746e-45e9-812f-c4ac15363737.text:
Let $L = \left({S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}\right)$ be a lattice.
Let $p \in S$.
Let $p$ be a prime element of $L$.
Then $p$ is meet irreducible in $L$.

3294671d-1e2f-46b3-976f-899b4ca2f534.text: :$\map {\dfrac \d {\d x} } {\csch a x} = -a \csch a x \coth a x$

f7f38303-8f36-40d8-ac61-1832c672ccd6.text:
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ be a sequence in $\R$.
Let $l \in A$ such that $\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} x_n = l$.
Then $\sequence {x_n}$ is bounded.

91d0ef4e-3754-4c30-a5b0-b68a50e8c29e.text:
Multiplication modulo $m$ is distributive over addition modulo $m$:
:$\forall \eqclass x m, \eqclass y m, \eqclass z m \in \Z_m$:
:: $\eqclass x m \times_m \paren {\eqclass y m +_m \eqclass z m} = \paren {\eqclass x m \times_m \eqclass y m} +_m \paren {\eqclass x m \times_m \eqclass z m}$
:: $\paren {\eqclass x m +_m \eqclass y m} \times_m \eqclass z m = \paren {\eqclass x m \times_m \eqclass z m} +_m \paren {\eqclass y m \times_m \eqclass z m}$
where $\Z_m$ is the set of integers modulo $m$.
That is, $\forall x, y, z, m \in \Z$:
: $x \paren {y + z} \equiv x y + x z \pmod m$
: $\paren {x + y} z \equiv x z + y z \pmod m$

6b6deac5-7fd2-4411-970d-62ddb111ab99.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a discrete topological space.
Let $\sequence {x_n}_{n \mathop \in \N}$ be a sequence in $S$.
Let $\sequence {x'_n}_{n \mathop \in \N}$ be a sequence of distinct terms in $S$.
Then $\sequence {x'_n}_{n \mathop \in \N}$ is not convergent in $T$.

c6bd7c78-cbe4-4200-ab39-d1e4974574ec.text: :$\ds \int \arccot \frac x a \rd x = x \arccot \frac x a + \frac a 2 \map \ln {x^2 + a^2} + C$

7385e45d-356e-49cf-a584-9cb0c2fa48b6.text:
Let $P_n$ be the $n$th pentagonal number.
Then:
:$P_n = T_n + 2 T_{n - 1}$
where $T_n$ is the $n$th triangular number.

7ce55c9e-70ff-4ca6-b88a-da0353905a71.text:
Let $\struct {\XX, \norm {\, \cdot \, } }$ be a normed vector space.
Let $\sequence {C_n}_{n \mathop \in \N}$ be a sequence of sets in $\XX$.
The inner limit of $\sequence {C_n}_{n \mathop \in \N}$ is:
:$\ds \liminf_n C_n = \set {x \in X: \lim_n \map d {x, C_n} = 0}$
where $d$ stands for the point-to-set distance mapping.

1e9b4d31-69b6-4dac-8495-b85414e02b25.text:
:$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {p^2 + q^2 \sin^2 a x} = \frac 1 {a p \sqrt {p^2 + q^2} } \arctan \frac {\sqrt {p^2 + q^2} \tan a x} p + C$
where $C$ is an arbitrary constant.

824bf668-d893-4564-8899-4cb81f6944d9.text:
Let $z \in \C$ be a complex number.
Let $\cmod z$ be the modulus of $z$.
Then:
: $\cmod {z^2} = \cmod z^2$

86643a26-e8d4-4565-9f9e-2e5ea173dcd8.text:
Let $\mathbb S, \mathbb T$ be sets of sets.
Suppose that for each $S \in \mathbb S$ there exists a $T \in \mathbb T$ such that $S \subseteq T$.
Then $\bigcup \mathbb S \subseteq \bigcup \mathbb T$.

168088f7-d59f-4905-a7e6-b9ebaf31e9d9.text:
Let $S$ be an uncountable set.
Let $T = \struct {S, \set {\O, S} }$ be the indiscrete topological space on $S$.
Let $\sequence {s_n}$ be a sequence in $T$.
Then every sequence in $T$ has an uncountable number of limit points.

81fc2bc9-db6d-4d69-b900-dc5aaae76295.text:
Let $P = \tuple {a, b, c, d}$ be a geometric sequence of integers.
Let $a$ be a cube number.
Then $d$ is also a cube number.
{{EuclidPropStatement|book = VIII|prop = 23|body = If four numbers be in continued proportion, and the first be cube, the fourth will also be cube.}}

59bac1b6-69c2-41ad-90ed-dcd0757081ea.text:
Two integers are coprime {{iff}} there exists an integer combination of them equal to $1$:
:$\forall a, b \in \Z: a \perp b \iff \exists m, n \in \Z: m a + n b = 1$

95c2290f-a828-481d-b268-d7ce9bc00d2e.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ_1, \circ_2, \ldots, \circ_n}$ be an algebraic structure.
Let:
:$\phi: \struct {S, \circ_1, \circ_2, \ldots, \circ_n} \to \struct {S, \circ_1, \circ_2, \ldots, \circ_n}$
:$\psi: \struct {S, \circ_1, \circ_2, \ldots, \circ_n} \to \struct {S, \circ_1, \circ_2, \ldots, \circ_n}$
be endomorphisms.
Then the composite of $\phi$ and $\psi$ is also an endomorphism.

ecefa286-f260-4f55-83ee-c3029c99c2b8.text:
Let $G$ be a group.
Let $H$ be a normal subgroup of $G$.
Let $G / H$ denote the quotient group of $G$ by $H$.
Then $G / H$ is abelian {{iff}} $H$ contains every element of $G$ of the form $a b a^{-1} b^{-1}$ where $a, b \in G$.

987edc39-1785-46de-956d-3dd62306d7c7.text:
Let $z \in \C$ be a complex number.
Then:
:$e^{i z} = \cos z + i \sin z$

f77d2e08-c491-4eef-9f2c-3e0d88e9e800.text:
Let $\struct {\Z, +, \times}$ be the ring of integers.
Let $\struct {\Z_m, +_m, \times_m}$ be the ring of integers modulo $m$.
Let $\phi: \struct {\Z, +, \times} \to \struct {\Z_m, +_m, \times_m}$ be the mapping defined as:
:$\forall x \in \Z: \map \phi x = \eqclass x m$
where $\eqclass x m$ is the residue class modulo $m$.
Then $\phi$ is a ring epimorphism, but specifically not a ring monomorphism.
The image of $\phi$ is $\struct {\Z_m, +_m, \times_m}$.
The kernel of $\phi$ is $m \Z$, the set of integer multiples of $m$.

bad2a13f-38e7-43eb-a7ed-25b29809be16.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be a magma.
Let the $\paren {2 - 3}$ parastrophe of $\struct {S, \circ}$ be a magma.
Then $\struct {S, \circ}$ is a left quasigroup.

936286c3-6d04-49d1-88bc-3013e6550337.text:
{{explain|If $A$ is a proper class, then its union may be the class of all ordinals, which we do not consider an ordinal.}}
Let $A$ be a class of ordinals.
That is, $A \subseteq \On$, where $\On$ denotes the ordinal class.
Then $\bigcup A$ is an ordinal.

9cee74a9-7792-418a-9a85-7a8a8d5f0c09.text:
Let $A$ and $B$ be sets of real numbers such that $A \subseteq B$.
Let $B$ be bounded below.
Then:
:$\inf A \ge \inf B$
where $\inf$ denotes the infimum.

eb7d2d85-5451-4ccf-bd7f-760b2274af70.text:
:$\ds {}_2 \map {F_1} {-p, 1; 1; -x} = \paren {1 + x}^p$
where:
:$x$ and $p$ are real numbers with $\size x < 1$
:${}_2 F_1$ denotes the Gaussian hypergeometric function.

ebec3c35-bf6e-440b-8e60-9a0c26e806b0.text:
Let $a \in \R$ be a real number such that $a > 1$.
Let $r \in \Q_{> 0}$ be a strictly positive rational number such that $r < 1$.
Then:
:$1 < a^r < 1 + a r$
{{explain|See whether there is a proof of this based on Bernoulli's Inequality}}

312bcbb2-4dac-4d09-9031-d44f36d5b9db.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ and $\struct {T, *}$ be algebraic structures.
Let $\phi: \struct {S, \circ} \to \struct {T, *}$ be an isomorphism.
Then $\circ$ has an identity $e_S$ {{iff}} $\map \phi {e_S}$ is the identity for $*$.

46f54bbb-b4c0-476d-890a-978fbd3d45c6.text:
Let:
:$\struct {R_1, +_1, \circ_1}$
:$\struct {R_2, +_2, \circ_2}$
:$\struct {R_3, +_3, \circ_3}$
be rings.
Let:
:$\phi: \struct {R_1, +_1, \circ_1} \to \struct {R_2, +_2, \circ_2}$
:$\psi: \struct {R_2, +_2, \circ_2} \to \struct {R_3, +_3, \circ_3}$
be (ring) epimorphisms.
Then the composite of $\phi$ and $\psi$ is also a (ring) epimorphism.

17daaabb-53db-4929-a9db-52cf3f33205b.text:
:$\ds \int_0^\infty \frac {\sin m x} {e^{2 \pi x} - 1} \rd x = \frac 1 4 \coth \frac m 2 - \frac 1 {2 m}$
where:
:$m$ is a non-zero real number
:$\coth$ is the hyperbolic cotangent function.

457fbcb7-ac3b-4254-8612-e342ad197ca0.text:
Let $x$ be a rational number such that $0 < x < \dfrac {\pi^2} 6 - 1$.
Then $x$ can be expressed as the sum of a finite number of reciprocals of distinct squares.

9dabb290-32f7-4e79-8b9e-009a734eb20f.text:
Let $S$ be a set and let $\powerset S$ be its power set.
Consider the algebraic structure $\struct {\powerset S, \cap}$, where $\cap$ denotes set intersection.
Then the empty set $\O$ serves as the zero element for $\struct {\powerset S, \cap}$.

74b0a148-4e14-4ae8-8316-8225959a7ddd.text:
The set difference with the intersection is just the set difference.
Let $S, T$ be sets.
Then:
:$S \setminus \paren {S \cap T} = S \setminus T$

68cbd840-2c55-41a3-96bb-4f8a0ebc7dfe.text:
Let $\struct {S, \tau_{_S} }$ be a topological space.
Let $\struct {R, +, *, \norm {\,\cdot\,} }$ be a normed division ring.
Let $\tau_{_R}$ be the topology induced by the norm $\norm {\,\cdot\,}$.
Let $\lambda \in R$.
Let $f: \struct {S, \tau_{_S} } \to \struct {R, \tau_{_R} }$ be a continuous mapping.
Let $\lambda + f : S \to R$ be the mapping defined by:
:$\forall x \in S: \map {\paren {\lambda + f} } x = \lambda + \map f x$
Then 
:$\lambda + f: \struct {S, \tau_{_S} } \to \struct {R, \tau_{_R} }$ is continuous.

55548607-a136-41e5-8ecf-83f17377347f.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be the Arens-Fort space.
Let $q \in S: q \ne \tuple {0, 0}$.
Then $\set q$ is both open and closed in $T$.
$\set {\tuple {0, 0} }$ itself is closed, but not open.

f879b2d8-1db2-4c43-a6ac-6b8b2497aa87.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be a group whose identity is $e$.
Let $*$ be the conjugacy action on $G$ defined by the rule:
:$\forall g, h \in G: g * h = g \circ h \circ g^{-1}$
Let $x \in G$.
Then the stabilizer of $x$ under this conjugacy action is:
:$\Stab x = \map {C_G} x$
where $\map {C_G} x$ is the centralizer of $x$ in $G$.

90137011-3f27-40f3-9ecf-7320fe855935.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Let $x \in A$.
Let $\BB_x$ be the set of all open balls of $M$ centered on $x$.
That is:
:$\BB_x = \set {\map {B_\epsilon} x : \epsilon \in \R_{>0}}$
Then $\BB$ is a local basis of $x$.

4e09a605-8b53-4e82-8bbd-d2df742aa514.text:
Let $\sequence {a_k}$ be a geometric sequence whose terms are rational.
Then the common ratio of $\sequence {a_k}$ is rational.

d6ace7a3-9f03-47f5-82a5-4303d0f8f912.text:
Let $m \in \Z_{>0}$ be a positive integer expressed in decimal notation.
Let $\map r m$ be the reverse-and-add process on $m$.
Let $r$ be applied iteratively to $m$.
The $2$-digit integers $m$ which need the largest number of iterations before reaching a palindromic number are $89$ and $98$, both needing $24$ iterations.

569e1a83-4a63-4afd-9df1-b28abd806b21.text:
Let $\mathbf a$, $\mathbf b$ and $\mathbf c$ be differentiable vector-valued functions in Cartesian $3$-space.
The derivative of their vector triple product is given by:
:$\map {\dfrac \d {\d x} } {\mathbf a \times \paren {\mathbf b \times \mathbf c} } = \dfrac {\d \mathbf a} {\d x} \times \paren {\mathbf b \times \mathbf c} + \mathbf a \times \paren {\dfrac {\d \mathbf b} {\d x} \times \mathbf c} + \mathbf a \times \paren {\mathbf b \times \dfrac {\d \mathbf c} {\d x} }$

f08aa14d-3c9c-4594-9d59-73a2f77da566.text:
To show that $\struct {T, \circ}$ is a submonoid of a monoid $\struct {S, \circ}$, we need to show that:
:$(1): \quad T \subseteq S$
:$(2): \quad \struct {T, \circ}$ is a magma (that is, that it is closed)
:$(3): \quad \struct {T, \circ}$ has an identity.

c913809d-f394-4e17-883f-25f707abc644.text:
The only solution to:
:$1 + 2^n = a^b$
is:
:$\tuple {n, a, b} = \tuple {3, 3, 2}$
for positive integers $n, a, b$ with $b > 1$.

9cb3dc47-ab35-4924-839c-2f43693d9389.text:
Let $T_1 = \struct {S_1, \tau_1}$ and $T_2 = \struct {S_2, \tau_2}$ be topological spaces.
Let $H \subseteq S_1$ be a subset of $S_1$.
Let $\map \cl H$ denote the closure of $H$.
Let $f: T_1 \to T_2$ be a continuous mapping.
Let $f \sqbrk {\map \cl H}$ be closed in $T_2$.
Then:
:$f \sqbrk {\map \cl H} = \map \cl {f \sqbrk H}$

8beab9b4-e492-4137-bf3a-2e5f03f9ccd7.text:
Let $\xi \in \C$ be a complex number.
Let $\ds \map S z = \sum_{n \mathop = 0}^\infty a_n \paren {z - \xi}^n$ be a (complex) power series about $\xi$.
Then the radius of convergence $R$ of $\map S z$ is given by:
:$\ds \dfrac 1 R = \limsup_{n \mathop \to \infty} \cmod {a_n}^{1/n}$
If:
:$\ds \limsup_{n \mathop \to \infty} \cmod {a_n}^{1/n} = 0$
then the radius of convergence is infinite, and $\map S z$ is absolutely convergent for all $z \in \C$.

70805fb0-62b2-47ce-abbf-615820c908cc.text:
Let $\struct{S, \tau_{_S}}$ be a topological space.
Let $\struct{R, +, *, \tau_{_R}}$ be a topological ring.
Let $f, g: \struct{S, \tau_{_S}} \to \struct{R, \tau_{_R}}$ be continuous mappings.
Let $f + g : S \to R$ be the mapping defined by:
:$\forall x \in S: \map {\paren{f + g}} x = \map f x + \map g x$
Then:
:$f + g: \struct {S, \tau_{_S} } \to \struct {R, \tau_{_R} }$ is continuous.

4b0b0013-d38d-49f4-8af1-855de90e733a.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a countable complement topology on an uncountable set $S$.
Then $T$ is pseudocompact.

035ef3dc-c8a4-48f1-89bc-b23ebcf0598c.text:
Let $\xi \in \R$ be a real number.
Let $\ds \map S x = \sum_{n \mathop = 0}^\infty a_n \paren {x - \xi}^n$ be a power series about $\xi$.
Then the interval of convergence of $\map S x$ is a real interval whose midpoint is $\xi$.

f170a1f7-f53e-46f6-a9ae-2f33ba03122f.text:
Let $\struct {M, d}$ be a metric space.
Let $x \in M$ and $S \subseteq M$.
Then:
:$\map d {x, S} \ge 0$
where $\map d {x, S}$ is the distance between $x$ and $S$.

4e293b54-3db3-46e0-b20f-f6e8b87638db.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be the Arens-Fort space.
Then $T$ is a $T_5$ space.

c551315d-d35c-4299-a45a-8c770776dd87.text:
Let $x$ be an irrational number.
Let $\sequence {p_n}_{n \mathop \ge 0}$ and $\sequence {q_n}_{n \mathop \ge 0}$ be the numerators and denominators of its continued fraction expansion.
Let $\dfrac {p_n} {q_n}$ be the $n$th convergent.
Let $\dfrac a b$ be any rational number such that $0 < b < q_{n + 1}$.
Then:
:$\forall n > 1: \size {q_n x - p_n} \le \size {b x - a}$
The equality holds only if $a = p_n$ and $b = q_n$.

fb0fd925-a703-4965-9a60-e8cfa0d2e08a.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \set {\O, S} }$ be an indiscrete topological space.
Let $H \subseteq S$.
$H$ is an open set of $T$ {{iff}} either $H = S$ or $H = \O$.

b7a7e5e6-4941-42fc-a1bc-6ec8a28d9fd5.text:
Let $k$ be a real number.
Let $I \subseteq \R$ be a real interval.
Let $f : I \to \R$ be an absolutely continuous real function.
Then $k f$ is absolutely continuous.

49e925f8-8868-441d-9697-6882a9c74cdc.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be a magma.
Let $\struct {\powerset S, \circ_\PP}$ be the algebraic structure consisting of the power set of $S$ and the operation induced on $\powerset S$ by $\circ$.
Then $\struct {\powerset S, \circ_\PP}$ is a magma.

668e960e-b4c4-4330-b1e7-0ba1ed6fe0ff.text:
Let $\mathbf A_1, \mathbf A_2, \ldots, \mathbf A_n$ be matrices.
Let the order of $\mathbf A_j$ be $d_j \times d_{j + 1}$.
Let $\ds \mathbf C := \prod_{j \mathop = 1}^n \mathbf A_j = \mathbf A_1 \mathbf A_2 \cdots \mathbf A_n$ be the (conventional) matrix product of $\mathbf A_1, \mathbf A_2, \ldots, \mathbf A_n$.
Then:
:$(1): \quad \ds \map c {i_1, i_{n + 1} } = \sum_{i_n \mathop = 1}^{d_n} \dotsm \sum_{i_3 \mathop = 1}^{d_3} \sum_{i_2 \mathop = 1}^{d_2} \map {a_1} {i_1, i_2} \map {a_2} {i_2, i_3} \dotsm \map {a_{n - 1} } {i_{n - 1}, i_n} \map {a_n} {i_n, i_{n + 1} }$
where:
:$\map {a_1} {i_1, i_2}$ (for example) denotes the element of $\mathbf A_1$ whose indices are $i_1$ and $i_2$
:the order of $\mathbf C$ is $d_1 \times d_{n+1}$.

93f6ee39-b16c-4525-a6ad-49439bbb83c2.text:
Let $S$ be the set of all real functions $f: \R \to \R$ of the form:
:$\forall x \in \R: \map f x = r x + s$
where $r \in \R_{\ne 0}$ and $s \in \R$
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be the algebraic structure formed from $S$ and the composition operation $\circ$.
Then $\struct {S, \circ}$ is a group.

5a45e9f9-1469-4832-abd4-fb214968b0ec.text:
Let $\struct {S, \RR}$ be a relational structure.
Then $\RR$ is a strictly well-founded relation {{iff}} there is no infinite sequence $\sequence {a_n}$ of elements of $S$ such that:
:$\forall n \in \N: a_{n + 1} \mathrel \RR a_n$

a542fa8e-9ec5-4a05-833c-93e4d215adfc.text:
Let $f: \R \to \R$ be a function.
Let $c \in \R_{>0}$ be a positive constant real number.
Let $\map {\delta_c} t$ be the Dirac delta function.
Let $\MM$ be the Mellin transform.
Then:
:$\map {\MM \set {\map {\delta_c} t \map f t} } s = c^{s - 1} \map f c$

d1d926b8-a040-4f8d-bd6d-e11cf47256d6.text: The multiplication operation on order types is well-defined.

7f68a474-a96a-4e95-b450-f6a4d0536c27.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Let $H \subseteq A$ be a suibset of $A$.
Let $M_H = \struct {H, d_H}$ be the subspace of $M$ induced by $d$.
Let $H$ be closed and bounded.
Then it is not necessarily the case that $M_H$ is compact.

87593db5-b97a-490b-b1a4-c71db95c8d7e.text:
Let $\struct {\Z_m, \times_m}$ denote the algebraic structure such that:
:$\Z_m$ is the set of integers modulo $m$
:$\times_m$ denotes the operation of multiplication modulo $m$.
Then $\struct {\Z_m, \times_m}$ is a commutative monoid.

46d4d712-0ba1-4158-986a-a6538127211d.text:
Let $\mathbf A$ be a complex-valued matrix.
Let $\mathbf A^*$ denote the Hermitian conjugate of $\mathbf A$.
Then the operation of Hermitian conjugate is an involution:
:$\paren {\mathbf A^*}^* = \mathbf A$

c2f624fb-6918-4d94-af6e-96f1065ce90d.text: The product of the number of edges, edges per face and faces of a tetrahedron is $72$.

6d0c4d4e-a442-4654-9705-9544f2a55ec0.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {x^2 \paren {x^3 + a^3}^2} = \frac {-1} {a^6 x} - \frac {x^2} {3 a^6 \paren {x^3 + a^3} } - \frac 4 {3 a^6} \int \frac {x \rd x} {x^3 + a^3}$

63e422d1-ec56-4ef1-8d34-aecae1f80dd3.text:
Let $A$ be a class satisfying the following conditions:
* $\O \in A$
* $\forall x \in A: x^+ \in A$
* If $y$ is a limit ordinal, then $\paren {\forall x < y: x \in A} \implies y \in A$
where $x^+$ denotes the successor of $x$.
Then $\On \subseteq A$.

244a7b12-ed54-46bf-9718-0cc95b3457c2.text:
Let $\N$ be the natural numbers.
Let $T$ be a set.
Let $a \in T$.
Let $g: T \to T$ be a mapping.
Then there exists exactly one mapping $f: \N \to T$ such that:
:$\forall x \in \N: \map f x = \begin{cases}
a & : x = 0 \\
\map g {\map f n} & : x = n + 1
\end{cases}$

52d5d91c-eec7-4fd8-8fea-3de73c97775b.text:
Let $\left({D, +, \circ}\right)$ be an integral domain.
Then $D$ is reduced.

aba4b24a-42bd-4064-986c-3232f5e6a651.text:
Let $\struct {D, +, \times}$ be a Euclidean domain whose zero is $0$ and whose unity is $1$.
Let $\nu: D \setminus \set 0 \to \N$ be the Euclidean valuation on $D$.
Let $a, b \in D$ such that $a$ and $b$ are not both equal to $0$.
Let $\gcd \set {a, b}$ be the greatest common divisor of $a$ and $b$.
Then:
:$\exists x, y \in D: a \times x + b \times y = \gcd \set {a, b}$
such that $\gcd \set {a, b}$ is the element of $D$ such that:
:$\forall c = a \times x + b \times y \in D: \map \nu {\gcd \set {a, b} } \le \map \nu c$
There are sources which suggest that Bézout's Lemma was first noticed by {{AuthorRef|Claude Gaspard Bachet de Méziriac}}.
{{AuthorRef|Étienne Bézout}}'s contribution was to prove a more general result, for polynomials.
Category:Euclidean Domains
Category:Greatest Common Divisor
Category:Bézout's Lemma

65e0066b-e82f-4732-a588-5d7b261a16ba.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ be a Cauchy sequence in $M$.
Then it is not necessarily the case that $M$ is a convergent sequence in $M$.

bfbb2dcb-c5e6-43c8-aced-5b85a883125e.text:
Let $\left({S, \preceq}\right)$ be an ordered set.
Then $\preceq$ is an approximating relation on $S$.

7b614175-f153-4d63-b9bb-d7e715e21b31.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ, \le}$ be an ordered ring with unity $1_R$ and zero $0_R$.
Let $x, y \in R$.
Suppose that $x > 0_R$ and $y > 1_R$.
Then $x \circ y > x$ and $y \circ x > x$.

c7b5e934-0815-40bb-982d-ffe7b61930c3.text:
Let $P = \sequence {a_j}_{0 \mathop \le j \mathop \le n}$ be a geometric sequence of integers of length $n + 1$.
Let $a_0$ be coprime to $a_n$.
Then there exist geometric sequences of integers $Q_1$ and $Q_2$ of length $n + 1$ such that:
:the initial term of both $Q_1$ and $Q_2$ is $1$
:the final term of $Q_1$ is $a_0$
:the final term of $Q_2$ is $a_n$.
{{EuclidPropStatement|book = VIII|prop = 9|body = If two numbers be prime to one another, and numbers fall between them in continued proportion, then, however many numbers fall between them in continued proportion, so many will also fall between each of them and an unit in continued proportion.}}

d229e67d-4a01-4187-b066-ba8d295629b7.text:
Let $L = \struct {S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}$ be a bounded below arithmetic lattice.
Let $p \in S$.
Then if $p$ is pseudoprime element, then $p$ is prime element.

6d528f0c-2f1a-491c-a7e9-ef2cd9a8e919.text:
Let $\struct {S_1, d_1}$ and $\struct {S_2, d_2}$ be metric spaces.
Let $f: S_1 \to S_2$ be an isometry.
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ be a Cauchy sequence in $S_1$.
Let $\sequence {y_n} = \sequence {\map f {x_n} }$ be the image of $\sequence {x_n}$ under $f$.
Then $\sequence {y_n}$ is a Cauchy sequence.

4ff2324d-70ba-44e3-afea-1aae9bba581f.text:
Let $m \in \N$ be a natural number.
Let $n \in \N_{>0}$ be a non-zero natural number.
Let $\RR_{m, n}$ be the relation on $\N$ defined as:
:$\forall x, y \in \N: x \mathrel {\RR_{m, n} } y \iff \begin {cases} x = y \\ m \le x < y \text { and } n \divides \paren {y - x} \\  m \le y < x \text { and } n \divides \paren {x - y} \end {cases}$
We have that $\RR_{m, n}$ is an equivalence relation which is compatible with both addition and multiplication.
Let $\map D {m, n} := \N / \RR_{m, n}$ be the quotient set of $\N$ induced by $\RR_{m, n}$.
Let $+_{m, n}$ be the operation induced on $\map D {m, n}$ by addition on $\N$.
Let $\phi_{m, n}$ be the canonical surjection from $\N$ onto $\map D {m, n}$.
The restriction of $\phi_{m, n}$ to $N_{< \paren {m + n} }$ is an isomorphism from the semigroup $\struct {N_{< \paren {m + n} }, +_{m, n} }$ onto $\struct {\map D {m, n}, +_{m, n} }$.

8d9592f2-5507-499f-9649-efa7c7eed738.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $H_1$ and $H_2$ be subsets of $S$.
Let ${H_1}^\circ$ and ${H_2}^\circ$ denote the interiors of $H_1$ and $H_2$ respectively.
Then it is not necessarily the case that:
:$\left({H_1 \cup H_2}\right)^\circ = {H_1}^\circ \cup {H_2}^\circ$

13209b93-5107-4dd5-bf28-64832163eeda.text:
Let $\mathbf P$ and $\mathbf Q$ be orthogonal matrices.
Let $\mathbf P \mathbf Q$ be the (conventional) matrix product of $\mathbf P$ and $\mathbf Q$.
Then $\mathbf P \mathbf Q$ is an orthogonal matrix.

60a31245-af84-48a5-b796-f13855e9e27a.text: The Ring of Quaternions is Ring is a subring of the matrix space $\mathcal M_\C \left({2}\right)$.

b211791b-f5b4-4788-a311-e8cdba42c010.text:
Let $f: S \to T$ be a mapping.
Let $F$ be defined as:
:$F = \set {\map {f^{-1} } x: x \in T}$
where $\map {f^{-1} } x$ is the preimage of $x$.
Then $F$ is a partition of $S$.

0525b155-3751-4da7-be7d-355dc0a56859.text:
Let $S$ and $T$ be sets.
Let $\RR = S \times T$ be the trivial relation in $S$ to $T$.
Then $\RR$ is a mapping {{iff}} either:
:$(2): \card S = 0$
or:
:$(1): \card T = 1$
where $\card {\, \cdot \,}$ denotes cardinality.

99af02ef-4376-47ab-97ce-1ba480f6ad1f.text:
Let $\left({S, \preceq}\right)$ be an ordered set.
Let $I$ be a ray, either open or closed.
Then $I$ is convex in $S$.

8d85d7bb-e32c-4d6d-8f53-e316135343a5.text:
Let $f$ and $g$ be real functions which are continuous on the closed interval $\closedint a b$ and differentiable on the open interval $\openint a b$.
Suppose that $\forall x \in \openint a b: \map {g'} x \ne 0$.
Suppose that $\map f x \to \infty$ and $\map g x \to \infty$ as $x \to a^+$.
Then:
:$\ds \lim_{x \mathop \to a^+} \frac {\map f x} {\map g x} = \lim_{x \mathop \to a^+} \frac {\map {f'} x} {\map {g'} x}$
provided that the second limit exists.

778900b5-4f3a-457c-a9ce-db3dc4349a71.text:
Let $\struct {S_1, +_1, \circ_1, \preccurlyeq_1}, \struct {S_2, +_2, \circ_2, \preccurlyeq_2}, \struct {S_3, +_3, \circ_3, \preccurlyeq_3}$ be ordered rings.
Let $\phi: S_1 \to S_2$ and $\psi: S_2 \to S_3$ be ordered ring isomorphisms.
Then the composite mapping $\psi \circ \phi: S_1 \to S_3$ is also an ordered ring isomorphism.

40c1937d-a8f1-4330-9eea-6a955836c5b3.text: There is a disjoint decomposition of the sphere $\mathbb S^2$ into four sets $A, B, C, D$ such that $A, B, C, B \cup C$ are all congruent and $D$ is countable.

03a40192-5e1e-40f4-82f1-d48c869a820d.text:
:$\ds \sum_{1 \mathop < k \mathop \le n} \dfrac 1 {k \paren {k - 1} } H_k = 2 - \dfrac {H_n} n - \dfrac 1 n$
where $H_n$ denotes the $n$th harmonic number.

6cdbb84a-56e7-4f0d-9a10-9efab2c9ef18.text:
Let $\Omega$ denote the first uncountable ordinal.
Let $\closedint 0 \Omega$ denote the closed ordinal space on $\Omega$.
Then $\closedint 0 \Omega$ is not a perfectly normal space.

90f58149-5b41-4d82-a88d-98d8ce50fbb2.text:
Let $a, b \in \N$ be numbers such that $a$ and $b$ are coprime:
:$a \perp b$
Let $c > 1$ be a divisor of $a$:
:$c \divides a$
Then $c$ and $b$ are coprime:
:$c \perp b$
{{EuclidPropStatement|book=VII|prop=23|body=If two numbers be prime to one another, the number which measures the one of them will be prime to the remaining number.}}

fbdd1184-3ddf-4e9a-8190-31fd6cef76d4.text:
Let:
:$\struct {S_1, \circ_1, \circ_2, \ldots, \circ_n}$
:$\struct {S_2, *_1, *_2, \ldots, *_n}$
:$\struct {S_3, \oplus_1, \oplus_2, \ldots, \oplus_n}$
be algebraic structures.
Let:
:$\phi: \struct {S_1, \circ_1, \circ_2, \ldots, \circ_n} \to \struct {S_2, *_1, *_2, \ldots, *_n}$
:$\psi: \struct {S_2, *_1, *_2, \ldots, *_n} \to \struct {S_3, \oplus_1, \oplus_2, \ldots, \oplus_n}$
be epimorphisms.
Then the composite of $\phi$ and $\psi$ is also an epimorphism.

66b5c0a4-19d3-4a04-ba75-74e1997aef2f.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be an ordered set.
Let $\succeq$ denote the dual ordering of $\preceq$.
Then $\succeq$ is an ordering on $S$.

ffcc98ae-296c-4c92-a215-e4a942c261a2.text:
Let $A = z_1$, $B = z_2$, $C = z_3$ and $D = z_4$ represent on the complex plane the vertices of a quadrilateral.
Then $ABCD$ is a parallelogram {{iff}}:
:$z_1 - z_2 + z_3 - z_4 = 0$

d7015f85-f99a-4736-871b-40f45b0f8397.text:
Let $I_1$ and $I_2$ be real intervals.
Then $I_1 \cap I_2$ is also a real interval.

ddeaab3f-9cd0-4b69-be07-84565c9763a1.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau_{\bar p} }$ be an uncountable excluded point space.
Then $T$ is not separable.

91f7ca0a-73ca-43c5-ab09-a878074da921.text:
Every non-null relation has exactly one of these properties: it is either:
:symmetric,
:asymmetric or
:non-symmetric.

c3c69a09-4f76-4fdc-9b17-778b6b872ec2.text:
Let $u$ be a differentiable real function of $x$.
Then:
:$\map {\dfrac \d {\d x} } {\coth u} = -\csch^2 u \dfrac {\d u} {\d x}$
where $\coth x$ denotes the hyperbolic cotangent and $\csch x$ denotes the hyperbolic cosecant.

29c31ed0-0275-4fac-a50f-7c05a7cfe5ea.text:
Let $n$ be an even perfect number, but not $6$.
Then:
:$n \equiv 1 \pmod 9$

d471f405-d414-40cf-a30e-4c94c628c817.text: If two rows of a square matrix over a commutative ring $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ are the same, then its determinant is zero.

e203f25f-bacb-47f4-8f63-54a949011ec1.text:
:$\ds \int \arsech \frac x a \rd x = x \arsech \dfrac x a + a \arcsin \dfrac x a + C$
where $\arsech$ denotes the real area hyperbolic secant.

330ed97d-b3ec-476c-b1db-e9b18db78cb5.text:
:$\cosh 2 x = 1 + 2 \sinh^2 x$
where $\cosh$ and $\sinh$ denote hyperbolic cosine and hyperbolic sine respectively.

0e4beb92-92db-4b69-89f1-1ff98ef080cf.text:
Let $T_A = \struct {S_A, \tau_A}$ and $T_B = \struct {S_B, \tau_B}$ be topological spaces.
Let $\phi: T_A \to T_B$ be a surjective open mapping which is also continuous.
If $T_A$ is second-countable, then $T_B$ is also second-countable.

8ece18eb-c85e-48ef-8830-a1d21ac51c5a.text:
Let $n \in \Z: n > 0$.
There are finitely many reduced quadratic irrationals which are associated to $n$.

2a7e414e-e9ca-4acf-a17b-d5b34a6a0e48.text:
Let $\struct {R, \norm {\, \cdot \,}_R }$ be a normed division ring.
Let $\CC$ be the ring of Cauchy sequences over $R$.
Let $\NN$ be the set of null sequences.
Let $Q = \CC  / \NN$ where $\CC  / \NN$ denotes a quotient ring.
Let $\norm {\, \cdot \,}_Q: Q \to \R_{\ge 0}$ be the norm on the quotient ring $Q$ defined by:
:$\ds \forall \sequence {x_n} + \NN: \norm {\sequence {x_n} + \NN }_Q = \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} \norm{x_n}_R$
Then:
:$\struct {Q, \norm {\, \cdot \,}_Q}$ is a normed division ring completion of $\struct {R, \norm {\, \cdot \,}_R }$

a8132a25-605f-427d-94a4-195fc0956692.text:
Let $n$ be a positive integer.
Then $n$ can be expressed as:
:$n = a^2 - b^2$
{{iff}} $n$ has at least two distinct divisors of the same parity.

f7b0619c-3fee-4458-ae9a-35e0f9f9e1fa.text:
Let $T = \struct {A, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $\O \subseteq H \subseteq A$ and so let $T_H = \struct {H, \tau_H}$ be a subspace of $T$.
Let $\BB$ be a (synthetic) basis for $T$.
Let $\BB_H$ be defined as:
:$\BB_H = \set {U \cap H: U \in \BB}$
Then $\BB_H$ is a (synthetic) basis for $H$.

dff26e04-9845-44fc-b15f-8b716d8383ed.text:
Let $\struct {X, \Sigma}$ be a measurable space.
Let $\sequence {\mu_n}_{n \mathop \in \N}$ be a sequence of measures on $\left({X, \Sigma}\right)$.
Let $\sequence {a_n}_{n \mathop \in \N} \subseteq \R_{\ge 0}$ be a sequence of positive real numbers.
Then the series of measures $\mu: \Sigma \to \overline \R$, defined by:
:$\ds \map \mu E := \sum_{n \mathop \in \N} a_n \map {\mu_n} E$
is also a measure on $\struct {X, \Sigma}$.

8a0ef35b-2d20-4bc9-8966-ed2dd9fc9ee4.text: Every homogeneous system of linear equations is consistent.

999f384d-613b-445b-a380-e676907bfa07.text:
Let $T$ be a parabola.
Consider the parabolic segment bounded by an arbitrary chord $AB$.
Let $C$ be the point on $T$ where the tangent to $T$ is parallel to $AB$.
Let
Then the area $S$ of the parabolic segment $ABC$ of $T$ is given by:
:$S = \dfrac 4 3 \triangle ABC$

f949854d-a97c-4303-a668-5db8b00e0b8b.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a commutative ring with unity.
Let $\mathbf A \in R^{n \times n}$ be an invertible square matrix of order $n$.
Let $\mathbf B = \mathbf A^{-1}$ be the inverse of $\mathbf A$.
Let $\map \det {\mathbf A}$ be the determinant of $\mathbf A$.
Then:
:$\map \det {\mathbf B} = \dfrac 1 {\map \det {\mathbf A} }$

db0c9937-d7a7-4e52-8719-bb3bada565c1.text:
Let $T_A = \struct {S_A, \tau_A}$ be a topological space which is weakly countably compact.
Let $T_B = \struct {S_B, \tau_B}$ be another topological space.
Let $\phi: T_A \to T_B$ be a continuous mapping.
Then $T_B$ is not necessarily weakly countably compact.

b51be4ad-a04b-4984-b9b5-3f054b6cacd5.text:
The group of Gaussian integer units under complex multiplication:
:$\struct {U_\C, \times} = \struct {\set {1, i, -1, -i}, \times}$
forms a subgroup of the multiplicative group of complex numbers.

4c864d84-e4c5-477f-9a49-981aa4e1dfcc.text:
Let $f: D \to \R$ be a real function where $D \subseteq \R$.
Let $x$ be a point in $D$.
Let $S_x$ be a set of real sets that contain (as an element) $x$.
Let:
:$\map {\omega_f} x = \ds \inf \set {\map {\omega_f} I: I \in S_x}$
where $\map {\omega_f} I$ is the oscillation of $f$ on a real set $I$:
:$\map {\omega_f} I = \ds \sup \set {\size {\map f y - \map f z}: y, z \in I \cap D}$
Let $\epsilon \in \R_{>0}$.
Let $\map {\omega_f} x \in \R$.
Then an $I \in S_x$ exists such that:
:$\map {\omega_f} I - \map {\omega_f} x < \epsilon$

afb0dbca-f5f2-4ab5-9ec6-b74fad07d0f1.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a discrete topological space.
Then $T$ is fully normal.

fbac95bc-a2c2-4641-ad5d-80c9e36b0fbc.text:
Let $n \in \Z$ be an integer such that $n \ge 2$.
Let $G$ be a group whose order is $2^n$.
Let $x \in G$ be of order $2^{n - 1}$ in $G$.
Then $x^{2^{n - 2} }$ is an element of the center of $G$.

d241da6b-f159-4148-8890-1570b914a950.text:
The number $N = 191 \, 918 \, 080 \, 818 \, 091 \, 909 \, 090 \, 909 \, 190 \, 818 \, 080 \, 819 \, 191$ has the property that:
:$N$ is a palindromic Sophie Germain prime
:$2 N + 1$ is also a palindromic Sophie Germain prime
:$2 \left({2 N + 1}\right) + 1$ is also a palindromic prime, but not a Sophie Germain prime.

09a702b0-9024-4b55-b6a1-320a86cd3b7a.text:
There are only two congruence relations on the field of rational numbers $\struct {\Q, +, \times}$:
:$(1): \quad$ The diagonal relation $\Delta_\Q$
:$(2): \quad$ The trivial relation $\Q \times \Q$.

8a6d67ec-a737-4b17-a17b-ecabcadc1edc.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $T \subseteq S$.
Suppose that $f: S \to T$ is an injection.
Then there is a bijection $g: S \to T$.

a5921992-4563-4bb7-8bdd-f7f3dd9d0b40.text:
Let $c \in \R$ be a constant.
Let $\sequence {a_n}$ be the sequence defined as:
:$\forall n \in \Z_{\ge 0}: a_n = c^n$
That is:
:$\sequence {a_n} = 1, c, c^2, c^3, \ldots$
Then the generating function for $\sequence {a_n}$ is given as:
:$\map G z = \dfrac 1 {1 - c z}$

973d4ad9-31ec-4969-b054-917f9f57eff8.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $H \subseteq S$ be a clopen set of $T$.
Let $\relcomp S H$ be the complement of $H$ relative to $S$.
Then $H$ and $\relcomp S H$ form a separation of $T$.

39f94b30-e897-43a7-a266-c983ae7459ee.text:
Everywhere that the function is defined:
:$\map \arctan {\dfrac 1 x} = \arccot x$
where $\arctan$ and $\arccot$ denote arctangent and arccotangent respectively.

398d45a6-8347-4605-80b4-325f0bf58070.text:
Let $\mathbf u, \mathbf v$ be vectors in the vector space $\R^n$.
Then:
:$\mathbf u \cdot \mathbf v = \mathbf v \cdot \mathbf u$

e4218233-d5f7-4822-83be-4997e0cbcca4.text:
:$\ds \int x \tan a x \rd x = \frac 1 {a^2} \paren {\frac {\paren {a x} ^ 3} 3 + \frac {\paren {a x}^5} {15} + \frac {2 \paren {a x}^7} {105} + \cdots + \frac {\paren {-1}^{n - 1} 2^{2 n} \paren {2^{2 n} - 1} B_{2 n} \paren {a x}^{2 n + 1} } {\paren {2 n + 1}!} + \cdots} + C$
where $B_{2 n}$ denotes the $2 n$th Bernoulli number.

317f73f4-b85c-44d4-976c-2e071a34a3d4.text:
Let $A$ and $B$ be commutative rings with unity.
Let $f : A \to B$ be a ring homomorphism.
Let $\mathfrak p \subseteq B$ be a prime ideal.
Then its preimage $\map {f^{-1} } {\mathfrak p}$ is a prime ideal of $A$.

67beefce-e2f4-4eec-b694-66a7088ae188.text:
:$\ds \sum_{k \mathop = 0}^n \binom m k \paren {k - \dfrac m 2} = -\dfrac m 2 \binom {m - 1} n$
where $\dbinom m k$ etc. are binomial coefficients.

6bd1a93c-8831-4bb9-beb9-af7b2496c8ce.text:
Let $R: \Z \to \set {\T, \F}$ be a propositional function on the set of integers.
Let the fiber of truth of $R$ be finite.
Then:
:$\ds \prod_{\map R j} a_j = \prod_{\map R {\map \pi j} } a_{\map \pi j}$
where:
:$\ds \prod_{\map R j} a_j$ denotes the product over $a_j$ for all $j$ that satisfy the propositional function $\map R j$
:$\pi$ is a permutation on the fiber of truth of $R$.

f27b0a0c-10c8-4c36-aa7f-29adeb556571.text:
Let $\struct {F, +, \times}$ be a field whose zero is $0_F$.
Let $a \in F$.
Then:
:$a \times 0_F = 0_F$
That is, $0_F$ acts as a zero element of $F$, which justifies its name.

bbc156cd-895e-4cbb-ab94-f0b89efaa508.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Let $F$ be a closed set of $M$.
Let $H \subseteq F$ be a subset of $F$.
Let $H^-$ denote the closure of $H$.
Then $H^- \subseteq F$.

1c84c291-928a-461a-8c07-75fa0f7fdac8.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=X|prop=15|body=If two commensurable magnitudes be added together, the whole will also be commensurable with each of them; and, if the whole be commensurable with one of them, the original magnitudes will also be commensurable.}}

ec541ce6-14cc-4c40-9d5f-1c4e6cb090c1.text: :$\dfrac {x^2} {x^4 + a^4} = \dfrac x {2 a \sqrt 2 \paren {x^2 - a x \sqrt 2 + a^2} } - \dfrac x {2 a \sqrt 2 \paren {x^2 + a x \sqrt 2 + a^2} }$

9253eb61-cec9-4096-8d9b-5c71d356ed22.text:
Let $\C$ denote the complex numbers.
Let $f$ and $g$ be complex functions which are continuous on an open subset $S \subseteq \C$.
Let $\lambda \in \C$ be an arbitrary complex number.
Then:
:$\lambda f$ is continuous on $S$.

cf9493e4-f847-43e3-b4c4-77f95c1bcad7.text:
Let $\sequence {s_n}$ be a real sequence.
Let the subsequences $\sequence {s_{2 n} }$ and $\sequence {s_{2 n + 1} }$ both converge to the same limit $l$.
Then $\sequence {s_n}$ also converges to the same limit $l$.

f2b59c4b-aa3b-4ddd-affd-29595446699d.text:
Let $\gamma$ be a closed contour.
Let $D$ be the region enclosed by $\gamma$. 
Let $f$ and $g$ be complex-valued functions which are holomorphic in $D$. 
Let $\cmod {\map g z} < \cmod {\map f z}$ on $\gamma$.
Then $f$ and $f + g$ have the same number of zeroes in $D$ counted up to multiplicity.

ef5343c2-82cc-4003-8130-169b360f2d5e.text:
Let $f: S \to T$ be a mapping.
Let $r: S / \RR_f \to \Img f$ be the renaming mapping, defined as:
:$r: S / \RR_f \to \Img f: \map r {\eqclass x {\RR_f} } = \map f x$
where:
:$\RR_f$ is the equivalence induced by the mapping $f$
:$S / \RR_f$ is the quotient set of $S$ determined by $\RR_f$
:$\eqclass x {\RR_f}$ is the equivalence class of $x$ under $\RR_f$.
The renaming mapping is a bijection.

7b7bc3c3-fe5e-4aa9-b355-250508fd5e70.text:
Let $\left({S_1, \preceq_1}\right)$, $\left({S_2, \preceq_2}\right)$ be ordered sets.
Let $f:S_1 \to S_2$ be an order embedding.
Then $f$ is increasing mapping.

0cee6057-8e1c-4cf6-ad42-8d7a8a356c90.text:
Let $S$ and $T$ be sets.
Let $\family {T_i}_{i \mathop \in I}$ be a family of subsets of $T$.
Let $f: S \to T$ be a mapping.
Then:
:$\ds f^{-1} \sqbrk {\bigcup_{i \mathop \in I} T_i} = \bigcup_{i \mathop \in I} f^{-1} \sqbrk {T_i}$
where:
:$\ds \bigcup_{i \mathop \in I} T_i$ denotes the union of $\family {T_i}_{i \mathop \in I}$
:$f^{-1} \sqbrk {T_i}$ denotes the preimage of $T_i$ under $f$.

b725938f-fda0-4755-ab18-289b0be0e611.text:
Let $k$ be a field.
Let $\map {\operatorname O} {n, k}$ be the $n$th orthogonal group on $k$.
Let $\map {\operatorname {SO} } {n, k}$ be the $n$th special orthogonal group on $k$.
Then $\map {\operatorname {SO} } {n, k}$ is a subgroup of $\map {\operatorname O} {n, k}$.

382b2557-9f46-45bd-b352-fa9d94d46596.text:
Let $\lambda^n$ be the Lebesgue pre-measure on the half-open $n$-rectangles $\JJ_{ho}^n$.
Then Lebesgue measure, the extension of $\lambda^n$ to the Borel $\sigma$-algebra $\BB \left({\R^n}\right)$, exists and is unique.

295770c2-2f06-43b5-956a-356c86ca20b6.text:
Let $G_1$ and $G_2$ be groups.
Let $H_1$ and $H_2$ be subgroups of $G_1$ and $G_2$ respectively.
Let $G_1$ be such that $H_1$ is the unique Sylow $p$-subgroup of $G_1$.
Let $G_2$ be such that $H_2$ is the unique Sylow $p$-subgroup of $G_2$.
Then $H_1 \times H_2$ is the unique Sylow $p$-subgroup of $G_1 \times G_2$.

5e981449-2eec-467e-9d96-de42470c7b9a.text:
Let $T$ be a topological space.
Then:
:$T$ is separable {{iff}} $d \left({T}\right) \leq \aleph_0$
where
:$d \left({T}\right)$ denotes the density of $T$,
:$\aleph$ denotes the aleph mapping.

ae93571e-9e3e-4334-8215-e164db90417d.text:
Let $K$ be an ellipse whose major axis is $2 a$ and whose minor axis is $2 b$.
Let $c$ be the distance of the foci of $K$ from the center.
Then:
:$a^2 = b^2 + c^2$

e467342c-a9e3-454e-9903-5fa23a7fd750.text:
Let $R$ be a ring with unity.
Let $J$ be an ideal of $R$.
If $J$ is a maximal right ideal then the quotient ring $R / J$ is a division ring.

64e41ed9-aa37-46f0-bc94-5e83d8a22a78.text:
Let $\left({G, \circ}\right)$ be a group whose identity element is $e$.
Then $\left({G, \circ}\right)$ is also a $B$-algebra {{iff}}:
:$\forall g \in G: g = g^{-1}$
That is, {{iff}} all elements of $G$ are self-inverse.

d688da4a-d454-420c-aaff-44a075d7a2e1.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Then $M$ is weakly countably compact {{iff}} $M$ is countably compact.

0ccec014-1794-435d-a916-baf4ee0d1dea.text:
$\aleph_0 < \mathfrak c$
where
:$\aleph$ denotes the aleph mapping,
:$\mathfrak c$ denotes continuum, the cardinality of real numbers.

f8c8ee82-ff3e-4b5f-975c-fed4f0f7a98e.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space on a set $S$.
Let $A_1, A_2, \ldots, A_n$ be a finite set of subsets of $S$:
:$\forall i \in \closedint 1 n: A_i \subseteq S$
Let $\forall i \in \closedint 1 n: \map T {A_i} = \struct {S, \tau_{A_i} }$ be the included set spaces on $S$ by $A_i$.
Let:
:$\forall i \in \closedint 1 n: \map T {A_i} \le T$
where $\map T {A_i} \le T$ denotes that $\map T {A_i}$ is coarser than $T$.
Then:
:$\ds \map T {\bigcap A_i} \le T$
where $\ds \map T {\bigcap A_i}$ is the included set space on $S$ by $\ds \bigcap_{i \mathop = 1}^n A_i$.

0b0103b9-c72b-43f3-8293-6ad97ddae56c.text:
Suppose there exists some integer $x$ such that $x^2$ ends in some $m$-digit pattern ending in an odd number not equal to $5$ and is preceded by another odd number, i.e.:
:$\exists x \in \Z: x^2 \equiv \sqbrk {1 a_1 a_2 \cdots a_m} \pmod {2 \times 10^m}$
where $a_m$ is odd, $a_m \ne 5$ and $m \ge 1$.
Then for any $n \ge 1$, there exists some integer with not more than $m n$-digits such that its square ends in $n$ occurrences of the $m$-digit pattern.

52bade4c-c944-484c-84b3-a8c5e64b2a9b.text:
The tangent to the cycloid whose locus is given by:
:$x = a \paren {\theta - \sin \theta}$
:$y = a \paren {1 - \cos \theta}$
is vertical at the cusps.

d73b0229-84e9-4ec6-9fe9-6d7d02a1becb.text:
Let $M$ be a metric space.
Let $C \subseteq M$ be a subspace of $M$ which is sequentially compact in $M$.
Then $C$ is sequentially compact in itself {{iff}} $C$ is closed in $M$.

0da95fe8-f4ec-4bd1-99af-673a725ee380.text:
Let $\sigma_1: \Z \to \Z$ be the divisor sum function.
Then $\map {\sigma_1} n$ is odd {{iff}} $n$ is either square or twice a square.

f4cbbf5c-0f8d-42f8-9700-a5f24f139880.text:
Let $U$ be a set.
Let $\FF$ and $\GG$ be sets of subsets of $U$.
Then $\FF \subseteq \GG \implies \bigcup \FF \subseteq \bigcup \GG$.
That is, $\bigcup$ is an increasing mapping from $\struct {\powerset {\powerset U}, \subseteq}$ to $\struct {\powerset U, \subseteq}$, where $\powerset U$ is the power set of $U$.

a75f0294-3c6b-41b6-8ee2-4454ff34f743.text:
Let $R$ be a commutative ring with unity.
Let $M$ be a maximal ideal of $R$.
Then $M$ is a prime ideal of $R$.

68c51878-1757-4abf-916f-d953f430a1f6.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=X|prop=24|body=The rectangle contained by medial straight lines commensurable in length is medial.}}

f64901b2-8f7b-4c7a-a510-372021fe790d.text:
Let $\phi: \struct {G, \circ} \to \struct {H, *}$ be a group isomorphism.
Let:
:$e_G$ be the identity of $\struct {G, \circ}$
:$e_H$ be the identity of $\struct {H, *}$.
Then:
: $\forall g \in G: \map \phi {g^{-1} } = \paren {\map \phi g}^{-1}$

a0c26829-ca53-46ae-8212-0dadc511ee90.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a countable discrete topological space.
Then $T$ is a Lindelöf space.

06a7932e-cc84-412d-9cb4-32494bcd22a3.text:
Let $m \in \Z_{\ge 0}$.
The unsigned Stirling number of the first kind $\ds {n \brack n - m}$ is a polynomial in $n$ of degree $2 m$.

32741306-1a53-4584-8ff8-d276f466b6a5.text:
Let $x, y, m \in \Z$ be integers where $m \ne 0$.
Let:
:$x \equiv y \pmod m$
where the notation indicates congruence modlo $m$.
Let $a_0, a_1, \ldots, a_r$ be integers.
Then:
:$\ds \sum_{k \mathop = 0}^r a_k x^k \equiv \sum_{k \mathop = 0}^r a_k y^k \pmod m$

1e39dab0-df9e-42b6-a97b-8c20427aefb6.text:
Let $A, B, S, T$ be sets such that $A \subseteq B$ and $S \subseteq T$.
Then:
:$A \times S \subseteq B \times T$
In addition, if $A, S \ne \O$, then:
:$A \times S \subseteq B \times T \iff A \subseteq B \land S \subseteq T$

97b3823a-0159-4983-95fe-ae733e7c8014.text:
Let $A$ be a commutative ring with unity.
Let $S \subseteq A$ be a multiplicatively closed subset.
Let $\struct {A_S, \iota}$ and $\struct {\tilde A_S, \tilde \iota}$ both satisfy the definition of the localization of $A$ at $S$.
Then there is a canonical isomorphism $\phi: A_S \to \tilde A_S$.

3987e850-d0c9-4a02-9e45-b1a944fcee28.text:
The roots of the polynomial:
:$z^5 + 1 = 0$
are:
:$\set {\cos \dfrac \pi 5 \pm i \sin \dfrac \pi 5, \cos \dfrac {3 \pi} 5 \pm i \sin \dfrac {3 \pi} 5, -1}$

f5d234d7-a121-4fb6-ad84-d14b7b8a97f9.text:
Let $\struct {X, \Sigma}$ be a measurable space. 
Let $f : X \to \overline \R$ be a $\Sigma$-measurable function.
Then: 
:$\size f$ is a $\Sigma$-measurable function.

4dfb6888-6b3a-421a-a6db-d78b9312c4cc.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $T$ have a generic point $g \in S$.
Then $T$ is path-connected.

b24206ad-a4f6-4131-a0a8-b8d428b56907.text:
Let $\tuple {X, d}$ be a metric space.
Let $\tuple {Y, d'}$ be a complete metric space.
Let $A \subseteq X$. 
Let $f : A \to Y$ be a uniformly continuous function.
Then there exists a unique continuous function $g : A^- \to Y$ such that:
:$\map g a = \map f a$
for all $a \in A$, where $A^-$ denotes the topological closure of $A$. 
Furthermore, $g$ is uniformly continuous.

d6e64db3-3303-455e-987e-aa8993b9905e.text:
Let $G$ be a group whose identity is $e$.
Let $X$ be a set.
Let $\phi: G \times X \to X$ be a group action.
Let $G_0$ denote the kernel of $\phi$.
Then $G_0$ is a normal subgroup of $G$.

baf707af-20bf-4795-8c14-d422fec232fe.text:
The function $f: \C \to \C$, defined as:
:$\map f z = z \times c$
is a superfunction for any complex number $c$.

db26236e-e37b-4f8f-9d25-fe714b5d211b.text:
Let $r \in \R_{> 0}$ be a positive real number.
Let $n, m \in \Z$ be integers.
Let $r^n$ be defined as $r$ to the power of $n$.
Then:
:$r^{n + m} = r^n \times r^m$

101523cf-7789-4431-8864-61a4f370bfbc.text:
Let $u$ be a differentiable real function of $x$.
Let $a \in \R_{>0}$.
Let $a^u$ be $a$ raised to the power of $u$.
Then:
:$\map {\dfrac \d {\d x} } {a^u} = a^u \ln a \dfrac {\d u} {\d x}$

6bb8a140-04c5-4ac0-b2b0-e26a5379fc40.text:
Let $J$ be a non-empty subset of the set of integers $\Z$.
Then:
:$J$ is an integral ideal
{{iff}}:
:$J$ is an ideal of the ring of integers $\struct {\Z, +, \times}$.

7b35ae6d-4e05-4a35-9d18-bd64ff950e92.text:
Let $X$ be a set on which there is a pseudometric $d: X \times X \to \R$.
For any $x, y \in X$, let $x \sim y$ denote that $\map d {x, y} = 0$.
Then $\sim$ is an equivalence relation, and the equivalence classes consist of sets of elements of $X$ at zero distance from each other.

4b52bf6d-c89a-4a36-b32d-223e5fba8abc.text:
Let:
:$\struct {X_1, d_1}$
:$\struct {X_2, d_2}$
:$\struct {X_3, d_3}$
be metric spaces.
Let:
:$\phi: \struct {X_1, d_1} \to \struct {X_2, d_2}$
:$\psi: \struct {X_2, d_2} \to \struct {X_3, d_3}$
be distance-preserving mappings.
Then the composite of $\phi$ and $\psi$ is also a distance-preserving mapping.

4dc5499f-ddbe-4e50-95b1-f94b6e23e753.text:
Let $n \in \Z: n > 0$.
Let $F_n$ be the set of all polynomials in $n$ variables $x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n$:
:$F = \set {\map f {x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n}: f \text{ is a polynomial in $n$ variables} }$
Let $S_n$ denote the symmetric group on $n$ letters.
Let $*: S_n \times F \to F$ be the mapping defined as:
:$\forall \pi \in S_n, f \in F: \pi * \map f {x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n} = \map f {x_{\map \pi 1}, x_{\map \pi 2}, \ldots, x_{\map \pi n} }$
Then $*$ is a group action.

de3a0d44-967c-4daf-9b52-13d4d40e68c7.text:
Let $R_1, R_2$ be commutative rings with unity.
Let $D$ be an integral subdomain of both $R_1$ and $R_2$.
Let $X_1, X_2 \in R$ be transcendental over $D$.
Let $D \sqbrk {X_1}, D \sqbrk {X_2}$ be the rings of polynomials in $X_1$ and $X_2$ over $D$.
Then $D \sqbrk {X_1}$ is isomorphic to $D \sqbrk {X_2}$.

11873502-bf62-4d8f-976d-813b82991bda.text:
Let $\struct {\R^3, d}$ be the Euclidean space.
Let $S_C \subseteq \R^3$ be the surface of revolution.
Let the smooth local parametrization of $C$ be:
:$\map \gamma t = \tuple {\map x t, \map y t}$
Then the induced metric on $S_C$ is:
:$g = \paren {\map {x'} t^2 + \map {y'} t^2} d t^2 + \map y t^2 d \theta^2$

739c1f37-8ae6-4f90-b20f-a2e75a2925a2.text:
Let $r_\alpha: \R^2 \to \R^2$ denote the rotation of the Euclidean plane about the origin through an angle of $\alpha$.
Let $d_\infty$ denote the Chebyshev distance on $\R^2$.
Then it is not necessarily the case that:
:$\forall x, y \in \R^2: \map {d_\infty} {\map {r_\alpha} x, \map {r_\alpha} y} = \map {d_\infty} {x, y}$

6987a6f0-26d9-4919-9b05-081ec5d1e869.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book = VII|prop = 2|body = Given two (natural) numbers not prime to one another, to find their greatest common measure.}}

3a70fa43-4c8d-48f4-a0f8-d5660f5c3a7f.text:
Let $S$ and $T$ be sets.
Let $\FF$ be a family of relations from $S$ to $T$.
Let $\ds \RR = \bigcup \FF$, the union of all the elements of $\FF$.
 
Then $\RR$ is a relation from $S$ to $T$.
{{expand|Binary case}}

e4d499c4-6676-41c4-8ce4-0ba40eabc9f3.text:
Let $n \in \Z_{> 0}$ be a positive integer.
Let $I_n$ be defined as:
:$\ds I_n = \int_0^{\frac \pi 2} \cos^n x \rd x$
Then $\sequence {I_n}$ is a decreasing sequence of real numbers which satisfies:
:$n I_n = \paren {n - 1} I_{n - 2}$
Thus:
:$I_n = \dfrac {n - 1} n  I_{n - 2}$
is a reduction formula for $I_n$.

f66b302f-4013-42de-84b2-09930bb7b837.text:
Let $S$ be the set of straight lines in the plane.
For $l_1, l_2 \in S$, let $l_1 \parallel l_2$ denote that $l_1$ is parallel to $l_2$.
Then $\parallel$ is a symmetric relation on $S$.

471b9b1c-d00f-4f89-94dc-de6344d1872e.text:
Let $\mathbb S = \family {\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha} }_{\alpha \mathop \in I}$ be an indexed family of topological spaces for $\alpha$ in some indexing set $I$.
Let $\ds T = \struct {S, \tau} = \prod_{\alpha \mathop \in I} \struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha}$ be the product space of $\mathbb S$.
Let $T$ be a $T_5$ space.
Then each of $\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha}$ is a $T_5$ space.

6883041c-08d4-4b48-aa18-6cef22f722fd.text:
Let $f: S \to T$ be a mapping.
Then $f$ is an injection {{iff}}:
:$\forall A \subseteq S: f \sqbrk A \cap f \sqbrk {\relcomp S A} = \O$

5dea4ee0-c57f-4ec6-b29e-2b4d727cdc52.text:
Let $\RR$ be a trichotomy.
Then $\RR$ is an antireflexive relation.

ad35394b-de04-407a-b457-17b1503248ed.text:
:$\dbinom 1 m_q = \delta_{0 m} + \delta_{1 m}$
That is:
:$\dbinom 1 m_q = \begin{cases} 1 & : m = 0 \text { or } m = 1 \\
0 & : \text{otherwise} \end{cases}$
where $\dbinom 1 m_q$ denotes a Gaussian binomial coefficient.

f918472d-57a4-4f29-bdd2-4540d5b5bd02.text:
Let $\left({X, \Sigma, \mu}\right)$ be a measure space.
Let $\mu$ be a finite measure.
Let $\Sigma'$ be a sub-$\sigma$-algebra of $\Sigma$.
Then the restricted measure $\mu \restriction_{\Sigma'}$ is also a finite measure.

e93b0ca2-61b0-4618-9f76-9b3aa475fd39.text:
Let $T_1$ and $T_2$ be topological spaces.
Let $f$ be a homeomorphism from $T_1$ to $T_2$.
Then $f$ may not necessarily be unique.

0fca3095-1837-403f-9f40-85b9ec8bebc2.text:
Let $G$ be a group.
Let $\Inn G$ be the inner automorphism group of $G$.
Let $\map Z G$ be the center of $G$.
Let $G / \map Z G$ be the quotient group of $G$ by $\map Z G$.
Then $G / \map Z G \cong \Inn G$.

03225687-40ff-4558-8910-3ad94bdc5dfb.text:
Let $x, y$ be distinct objects.
Then the power set of the doubleton $\set {x, y}$ is:
:$\powerset {\set {x, y} } = \set {\O, \set x, \set y, \set {x, y} }$

71a1688c-6723-4b75-b52e-217f8a8b3063.text:
The smallest $22$ primes in arithmetic sequence are:
:$11 \, 410 \, 337 \, 850 \, 553 + 4 \, 609 \, 098 \, 694 \, 200 n$
for $n = 0, 1, \ldots, 21$.

9d3fe0f0-1b23-4eaf-ba00-56e07cf67d9a.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $S^*$ be its Kleene closure, and let $i: S \to S^*$ be the insertion of generators.
Then $\struct {S^*, i}$ is a free monoid over $S$.

01dffde0-d4bc-4a76-b842-9bfae9206df6.text:
Let $T_1 = \struct {S_1, \tau_1}$ and $T_2 = \struct {S_2, \tau_2}$ be topological spaces.
Let $H \subseteq S_1$ be a subset of $S_1$.
Let $\map \cl H$ denote the closure of $H$.
Let $f: T_1 \to T_2$ be a continuous mapping.
Then it is not necessarily the case that:
:$f^{-1} \sqbrk {\map \cl H} = \map \cl {f^{-1} \sqbrk H}$

f3040eea-4a18-43e6-82d0-e846b1283b64.text:
:$7^{510} \approx 1 \cdotp 00000 \, 09377 \, 76536 \ldots \times 10^{431}$
This is the closest known approximation of a power of $7$ by a power of $10$.

bec6fe48-3dd1-4389-9d6c-47ebd269693a.text:
Let $\struct {R, + , \circ}$ be a ring.
For all $y \in R$, let $\lambda_y$ and $\rho_y$ denote the left and right regular representations of $\struct {R, \circ}$ with respect to $y$.
Let $I_{_R} : R \to R$ be the identity mapping on $R$.
For all $y \in R$, let $y * I_{_R} : R \to R$ be the mapping defined by:
:$\forall z \in R: \map {\paren{y * I_{_R}}} z = y * \map {I_{_R}} z$
For all $y \in R$, let $I_{_R} * y : R \to R$ be the mapping defined by:
:$\forall z \in R: \map {\paren{I_{_R} * y}} z = \map {I_{_R}} z * y$
Then:
:$\forall y \in R: \lambda_y = y * I_{_R} \text { and } \rho_y = I_{_R} * y$

fedf0086-d97f-4880-9aa3-390b4dff2a2f.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be the Arens-Fort space.
Then $T$ is not a compact space.

8ff429c0-e1ad-4e27-a47f-5366f26c7431.text:
Let $M = \struct {\R, d}$ denote the real number line with the usual (Euclidean) metric.
Let $a \in \R$ be a point in $M$.
Then the set of all open intervals containing $a$ is a basis for the neighborhood system of $a$.

5e3a45c5-068d-41f6-8956-3f26349bb346.text:
Let $\struct {T, \tau}$ be a compact Hausdorff space. 
Let $f : T \to T$ be a continuous function.
Define a sequence of sets $\sequence {X_i}_{i \mathop \in \N}$ by:
:$X_i = \begin{cases}X & : i = 1 \\ f \sqbrk {X_{i - 1} } & : i \ge 2\end{cases}$
Define:
:$\ds A = \bigcap_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty X_n$
Then: 
:$A \subseteq f \sqbrk A$

3a9e89ac-f619-43bc-b1c6-14b0ccb9675c.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a ring with unity whose zero is $0_R$ and whose unity is $1_R$.
Let $A$ be a set.
For each $a \in A$, let $f_a: A \to R$ be defined as:
:$\forall x \in A: \map {f_a} x = \begin{cases}
1 & : x = a \\
0 & : x \ne a
\end{cases}$
Then $B = \set {f_a: a \in A}$ is a basis of the Finite Submodule of Function Space $R^{\paren A}$.

9c8c4feb-a04d-41ac-81fa-5af2cfddcd46.text:
Let $F_m$ and $F_n$ be Fermat numbers such that $m \ne n$.
Then $F_m$ and $F_n$ are coprime.

fd40484c-be11-4f12-be73-d10f9f0d2701.text:
Let $P = \struct {S, \vee, \preceq}$ be a join semilattice.
Let $X$ be a non-empty subset of $S$.
Then
:$\map {\operatorname{finsups} } X^\preceq$ is ideal in $P$.
where
:$\map {\operatorname{finsups} } X$ denotes the finite suprema set of $X$,
:$X^\preceq$ denotes the lower closure of $X$.

457797ef-1ebc-46c7-996f-8a6806edf7c8.text:
Let $M$ be a Möbius Strip.
Then:
:$\map \chi M = 0$
where $\map \chi M$ denotes the Euler characteristic of the graph $M$.

063c9aa5-7810-4cb8-b1de-9a22a9ea20b6.text:
Let $\struct {S, \leftarrow}$ be an algebraic structure in which the operation $\leftarrow$ is the left operation.
Then no matter what $S$ is, $\struct {S, \leftarrow}$ is a semigroup all of whose elements are left zeroes.
Thus it can be seen that any left zero in a semigroup is not necessarily unique.

7a64ccd8-6f23-41c8-9262-943bb0a276e8.text:
Let $\R$ be the set of real numbers considered as a Euclidean space.
Let $S \subseteq \R$ be unbounded in $\R$.
Then $S$ is not a compact subspace of $\R$.

606a5fdd-b661-4050-acde-d7b5d5d88d97.text:
:$\ds \int_0^{2 \pi} \frac {\d x} {a + b \cos x} = \frac {2 \pi} {\sqrt {a^2 - b^2} }$
where $a$ and $b$ are real numbers with $a > b > 0$.

3d2d3c08-9ffb-416f-b370-01ece13d09f8.text:
Let $L / K$ be a finite Galois extension.
Let $\Gal {L / K}$ denote the Galois group of the extension $L / K$.
Let $H$ denote a subgroup of $\Gal {L / K}$ and $F$ denote an intermediate field.
The mappings:
:$H \mapsto L_H$, and
:$F \mapsto \Gal {L / F}$
are inclusion-reversing and inverses.
Moreover, these maps induce a bijection between the normal subgroups of $\Gal {L / K}$ and the normal, intermediate extensions of $L / K$.

a5cfa7d8-a1c4-471c-9439-69a3d7f8079f.text:
Let $S_n$ denote the symmetric group on $n$ letters.
Every finite group is isomorphic to a subgroup of $S_n$ for some $n \in \Z$.
Let $\struct {G, \cdot}$ be a group.
Then there exists a permutation group $P$ on some set $S$ such that:
:$G \cong P$
That is, such that $G$ is isomorphic to $P$.
'''Cayley's Representation Theorem''' is also known as the '''Representation Theorem for Groups'''.
Some present it as the '''Cayley's representation theorem'''.
Some sources refer to it as just '''Cayley's theorem''', but as there is more than one result so named, it is better to use the more specific form.

f40bd35f-a1d1-4c9f-b1ca-1962e2e03e10.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {\paren {1 - \cos a x}^2} = \frac {-1} {2 a} \cot \frac {a x} 2 - \frac 1 {6 a} \cot^3 \frac {a x} 2 + C$

f525a434-71bf-4f8c-bfc4-e7fc875b8957.text:
Let $S = \set {x \in \R: 0 < x < 1}$.
Then an operation $\circ$ can be found such that $\struct {S, \circ}$ is a group such that the inverse of $x \in S$ is $1 - x$.

b6413e36-da5c-4a2d-a2bd-ae3c6102700c.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be the internal group direct product of $H_1, H_2, \ldots, H_n$.
Let $h_i$ and $h_j$ be elements of $H_i$ and $H_j$ respectively, $i \ne j$.
Then $h_i \circ h_j = h_j \circ h_i$.

cc4c3a90-873d-4999-a57d-6f1e0b3fdcba.text:
In a group of order $28$, there exists exactly $1$ Sylow $7$-subgroup.
This Sylow $7$-subgroup is normal in $G$.

f0236d40-0004-438b-9e0d-2a2a49f59570.text:
Let $\R$ be the real number line under the Euclidean metric.
Let $\Bbb I := \closedint 0 1$ be the closed unit interval.
Let $\mathsf L \subseteq \R^2$ denote the letter $L$:
:$\mathsf L := \closedint 0 1 \times \set 0 \cup \set 0 \times \closedint 0 1$
Then $\Bbb I$ and $\mathsf L$ are homeomorphic.

c578f84f-6572-47a9-b668-e6c3af230d3c.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be an algebraic structure.
Let $\circ$ be right cancellable and also commutative.
Then $\circ$ is also left cancellable.

52885dda-55bc-41dc-a9a9-01a14b00fb0e.text:
Let $\left({S, \circ}\right)$ be a group.
Let $\left({S, *}\right)$ be the $B$-algebra described on Group Induces $B$-Algebra.
Let $\left({S, \circ'}\right)$ be the group described on $B$-Algebra Induces Group.
Then $\left({S, \circ'}\right) = \left({S, \circ}\right)$.

117c9239-ee21-4476-aac4-0ff5de61e396.text:
Let $A$, $B$, $C$ and $D$ be sets.
Let:
:$f: A \to B$
:$g: B \to C$
:$h: C \to D$
be mappings.
Let $g \circ f$ and $h \circ g$ be bijections.
Then $f$, $g$ and $h$ are all bijections.

c3b16535-7895-497c-81ac-d667f010b3fa.text:
:$\ds \int_0^\infty e^{-a x} \sin b x \rd x = \frac b {a^2 + b^2}$
 
where $a$ and $b$ are real numbers with $a > 0$.

caa88671-7a50-4034-804b-3cf4843e7740.text:
Let $f \in L^1$.
Then:
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} \int \map f x e^{i n x} \rd x = 0$
That is, the Fourier transform of an $L^1$ function vanishes at infinity.

b458e329-0eee-4dc9-9c1d-e8392ee8dc35.text:
Let $a, b \in \Z$ be integers such that $a \ne 0$ or $b \ne 0$.
Then the greatest common divisor of $a$ and $b$ exists.

ed477dc1-e74a-47d1-963c-5e697ca654f1.text:
Let $x, y, z$ be ordinals.
Then:
:$x \le y \implies \left({z \cdot x}\right) \le \left({z \cdot y}\right)$

364d3be8-4093-4053-8245-0e68123a9dfd.text:
Let $x$ be an ordinal.
Suppose $x$ satisfies $\omega \subseteq x$.
Then $x$ has a unique representation as $\paren {y + z}$ where $y$ is a limit ordinal and $z$ is a finite ordinal.

e69a8f11-8b40-4165-a33e-55335db82906.text:
Let $\sequence {a_n}$ and $\sequence {b_n}$ be sequences in $\R$ such that $\sequence {b_n}$ is strictly increasing and $\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} b_n = \infty$.
If:
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} \frac {a_n - a_{n - 1} } {b_n - b_{n - 1} } = L \in \R$
then also:
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} \frac {a_n} {b_n} = L$

5eeba9c3-85c8-4446-b09e-963f5ea2c6c1.text: The operation of order type addition is not commutative.

12a1f44d-2f7e-4a24-9c12-821154731d6b.text:
Let $\sequence {a_n}$ be the sequence defined as:
:$\forall n \in \N: a_n = \begin{cases}
\dbinom m n & : n = 0, 1, 2, \ldots, m \\
0 & : \text{otherwise}\end{cases}$
where $\dbinom m n$ denotes a binomial coefficient.
Then the generating function for $\sequence {a_n}$ is given as:
:$\ds \map G z = \sum_{n \mathop = 0}^m \dbinom m n z^n = \paren {1 + z}^m$

1336306e-142b-4e17-bdc7-f4de744853fd.text:
Let $x, y \in \R$ be real numbers.
Let $\map \Beta {x, y}$ be the Beta function:
:$\ds \map \Beta {x, y} := \int_{\mathop \to 0}^{\mathop \to 1} t^{x - 1} \paren {1 - t}^{y - 1} \rd t$
Then $\map \Beta {x, y}$ exists provided that $x, y > 0$.

50b7b34c-2656-4679-98cd-e6f9cbacbb8c.text:
Consider the folium of Descartes $F$, given in parametric form as:
:$\begin {cases} x = \dfrac {3 a t} {1 + t^3} \\ y = \dfrac {3 a t^2} {1 + t^3} \end {cases}$
The straight line whose equation is given by:
:$x + y + a = 0$
is an asymptote to $F$.

2d3e38b2-b120-4119-b105-c9ad9ae1a8d5.text:
Let $f: \R \to \R$ be a real function which is injective.
Let its graph be embedded in the Cartesian plane $\mathcal C$:
:520px
Let $\mathcal L$ be a horizontal line through a point $b$ in the codomain of $f$.
Then $\mathcal L$ intersects the graph of $f$ on at most one point $P = \tuple {a, b}$ where $b = \map f a$.

a29d2059-0559-4161-a26b-c93e4f04391a.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a non-empty topological space.
Let $p$ be a new element not in $S$.
Let $S^* := S \cup \set p$.
Let $T^* = \struct {S^*, \tau^*}$ be the Alexandroff extension on $S$.
Then $\tau^*$ is a topology on $S^*$.

4f55d87a-d07c-4beb-be2d-c70c4e3f46ae.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space, where $S$ is a countable set.
Then $T$ is $\sigma$-compact.

17265f2f-268e-47cd-9926-ca12746b4360.text:
The set of polynomial forms has an additive identity.
{{explain|Context}}

02519fad-933f-48aa-8f59-47ee2b9d23a4.text:
Let $f$ be a real function which is twice differentiable on the open interval $\openint a b$.
Then $f$ is concave on $\openint a b$ {{iff}} its second derivative $f'' \le 0$ on $\openint a b$.

cd031666-93c5-4b2e-9c06-e9d6b44c6e84.text:
Let $S$ and $T$ be sets such that $S \ne \O$.
Let $f: S \to T$ be a injection.
Then there exists a surjection $g: T \to S$ such that:
:$g \circ f = I_S$

3e13019b-85f1-4279-a8f7-6fbbb3986f69.text:
Let $\mathbb K \in \set {\C, \R}$.
Let $n$ be a positive integer.
Let $\map {\mathfrak {sp}_{2 n} } {\mathbb K}$ be the Lie algebra of the symplectic group $\map {\operatorname {Sp} } {2 n, \mathbb K}$.
