Let $\paren +$ be the pointwise addition of real-valued functions.
Let $\paren {\, \cdot \,}$ be the pointwise scalar multiplication of real-valued functions.
Then $\struct {\map {\CC^1} I, +, \, \cdot \,}_\R$ is a vector space.

7cfeff2a-c677-4623-886d-89c114d155aa.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Let $\struct {\Q_p, \norm {\,\cdot\,}_p}$ be the $p$-adic numbers.
Let $x \in \Q_p$.
Then $x$ is the limit of a unique $p$-adic expansion.

31d60f7f-777c-4f6a-bb90-2c028870032d.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau_p}$ be a Fortissimo space.
Let $T \times D$ be the double pointed topology on $T$.
Then $T \times D$ is weakly countably compact.

de6b60d8-002f-4565-94a1-106f2b1bcd30.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Let $\struct {\Q_p, \norm {\,\cdot\,}_p}$ be the $p$-adic numbers.
Let $\Z_p$ be the $p$-adic integers.
Let $a \in \Q_p$.
For all $\epsilon \in \R_{>0}$, let $\map {B_\epsilon} a$ denote the open ball of $a$ of radius $\epsilon$. 
Then:
:$\forall n \in Z : \map {B_{p^{-n} } } a = a + p^{n + 1} \Z_p$

efd23bd0-0c6e-43d9-bf57-41c82557366d.text:
Let $z_1, z_2, \ldots, z_n \in \C$ be complex numbers.
Let $z_j = \polar {r_j, \theta_j}$ be $z_j$ expressed in polar form for each $j \in \set {1, 2, \ldots, n}$.
Then:
:$z_1 z_2 \cdots z_n = r_1 r_2 \cdots r_n \paren {\map \cos {\theta_1 + \theta_2 + \cdots + \theta_n} + i \map \sin {\theta_1 + \theta_2 + \cdots + \theta_n} }$

0b73e76a-ba53-48fa-ad91-8867b1266b27.text:
Let $S$ and $T$ be sets.
Let $\RR \subseteq S \times T$ be a relation from $S$ to $T$.
Let $C, D \subseteq T$.
Then:
:$C \subseteq D \implies \RR^{-1} \sqbrk C \subseteq \RR^{-1} \sqbrk D$
where $\RR^{-1} \sqbrk C$ is the preimage of $C$ under $\RR$.

d3a89fe3-4648-4c56-a8a2-26a373aad729.text:
Let $\alpha$ be a multiindex, indexed by $\set {1, \ldots, n}$ such that $\alpha_j \ge 0$ for $j = 1, \ldots, n$.
Let $x = \tuple {x_1, \ldots, x_n}$ and $y = \tuple {y_1, \ldots, y_n}$ be ordered tuples of real numbers.
Then:
:$\ds \paren {x + y}^\alpha = \sum_{0 \mathop \le \beta \mathop \le \alpha} \dbinom \alpha \beta x^\beta y^{\alpha - \beta}$
where $\dbinom n k$ is a binomial coefficient.

6f6083e5-6036-412c-b5e2-95706ed62665.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let:
:$\symdif$ denote the symmetric difference operation
:$\cup$ denote the set union operation
:$\powerset S$ denote the power set of $S$.
Then $\struct {\powerset S, \symdif, \cup}$ does not form a ring.

d6921f87-24a8-42d1-986b-645f6acc0721.text:
Let $\mathbf v, \mathbf w$ be two non-zero vectors in $\R^2$, and let $p$ be a point in $\R^2$.
Suppose that the angle between $\mathbf v$ and $\mathbf w$ is a convex angle.
Then the set 
:$U = \left\{ {p + st \mathbf v + \left({1-s}\right) t \mathbf w : s \in \left({0\,.\,.\,1}\right) , t \in \R_{>0} }\right\}$
is a convex set.
{{expand|It'd be really nice to have a picture of $U$ to support intuition and connect with the page title}}

9b02a0ae-1612-4cd2-b8d7-9eaca9128b9e.text:
Let $0 \le t \le m$.
Then:
:$0 \le e^{-t} - \left({1 - \dfrac t m}\right)^m \le t^2 \dfrac {e^{-t} } m$

7e80eed8-bbdc-493f-8490-5e8bb451947d.text:
Let $X$ be a set.
Let $I$ be an indexing set.
Let $\family {\struct {Y_i, \tau_i} }_{i \mathop \in I}$ be an indexed family of topological spaces indexed by $I$.
Let $\family {f_i: Y_i \to X}_{i \mathop \in I}$ be an indexed family of mappings indexed by $I$.
Let:
:$\tau = \set{U \subseteq X: \forall i \in I: \map {f_i^{-1}} U \in \tau_i} \subseteq \powerset X$
Then:
:$\tau$ is the finest topology on $X$ such that each $f_i: Y_i \to X$ is $\tuple{\tau_i, \tau}$-continuous.

bc043915-a99d-4ebb-8c9e-42ac3ade98e8.text:
Let $\gen a = \struct {G, \circ}$ be a cyclic group.
Let $f: \Z \to G$ be a mapping defined as:
$\forall n \in \Z: \map f n = a^n$.
Then $f$ is a (group) epimorphism from $\struct {\Z, +}$ onto $\gen a$.

fa0245d4-36a6-4d07-8f55-125c566a0ef4.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be an ring.
For each $x, y \in R$ let $x - y$ denote the subtraction of $x$ and $y$ in $R$.
Let $\struct {S, + {\restriction_S}, \circ {\restriction_S}}$ be a subring of $R$.
For each $x, y \in S$ let $x \sim y$ denote the subtraction of $x$ and $y$ in $S$.
Then:
:$\forall x, y \in S: x \sim y = x - y$

e2c4eb0a-4066-4095-9509-02a0f486bcea.text:
Let $M$ be a unitary $R$-module.
Let $S = \family {m_i}_{i \mathop \in I}$ be a family of elements of $M$.
Let $\Psi: R^{\paren I} \to M$ be the morphism given by Universal Property of Free Module on Set.
Then $S$ is a spanning set of $M$ {{iff}} $\Psi$ is surjective.

26ac5bc4-b687-46eb-b13e-8bd4795e7aed.text:
Let $S$ and $T$ be sets.
Let $f: S \to T$ be a mapping.
Let $\powerset T$ be the power set of $T$.
Let $\mathbb T \subseteq \powerset T$.
Then:
:$\ds f^{-1} \sqbrk {\bigcap \mathbb T} = \bigcap_{X \mathop \in \mathbb T} f^{-1} \sqbrk X$

fa94a8cc-ccc6-46c5-b27f-298fafdb4034.text:
Let $\Z_{>0}$ be the set of (strictly) positive integers.
Let $d: \Z_{>0} \times \Z_{>0} \to \R$ be the usual (Euclidean) metric on $\Z_{>0}$.
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ be a Cauchy sequence in $\struct {\Z_{>0}, d}$.
Then:
:$\exists m, n \in \Z_{>0}: \forall r > n: x_r = m$
That is, $\sequence {x_n}$ is eventually constant.

3dcd890e-b648-40f6-8db9-d8adf81aecc0.text:
Let $x$ be an ordinal.
Let $x^+$ denote the successor of $x$.
Then:
:$\ds \map \bigcup {x^+} = x$

efbe729e-802c-402d-bf20-e24c7eb26ccf.text:
Let $R$ be a set.
Let:
: $\left({R, +_1, \circ_1}\right)$
: $\left({R, +_2, \circ_2}\right)$
: $\left({R, +_3, \circ_3}\right)$
be rings.
Let:
: $\phi: \left({R, +_1, \circ_1}\right) \to \left({R, +_2, \circ_2}\right)$
: $\psi: \left({R, +_2, \circ_2}\right) \to \left({R, +_3, \circ_3}\right)$
be (ring) endomorphisms.
Then the composite of $\phi$ and $\psi$ is also a (ring) endomorphism.

4ea7a0ac-7e0a-4b21-bea8-88285184800c.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Let $\struct {\Q_p, \norm {\,\cdot\,}_p}$ be the $p$-adic numbers.
Let $\Z_p$ be the $p$-adic integers.
Then:
:$Q_p = \Z_p \sqbrk {1 / p}$
where $\Z_p \sqbrk {1 / p}$ denotes the ring extension generated by $1 / p$.

8f765d96-3223-44d8-bac2-b3f0b4d0038e.text:
Let $M_a = \struct {X, 
orm {\, \cdot \, }_a}$ and $M_b = \struct {X, 
orm {\, \cdot \,}_b}$ be normed vector spaces.
Let $\sequence {x_n}_{n \mathop \in \N}$ be a Cauchy sequence in $M_a$.
Suppose, $
orm {\, \cdot \, }_a$ and $
orm {\, \cdot \,}_b$ are equivalent norms, i.e. $
orm {\, \cdot \, }_a \sim 
orm {\, \cdot \,}_b$.
Then $\sequence {x_n}_{n \mathop \in \N}$ is also a Cauchy sequence in $M_b$.

eb478475-c23c-4154-a05c-33ec0ed30412.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a ring
Let $\mathbb L$ be a non-empty set of ideals of $R$.
Then the intersection $\bigcap \mathbb L$ of the members of $\mathbb L$ is the largest ideal of $R$ contained in each member of $\mathbb L$.

1fdf68b1-85f1-452e-98e2-c2ee254a56f4.text:
Every non-empty subset of $\N$ has a smallest (or '''first''') element.
That is, the relational structure $\struct {\N, \le}$ on the set of natural numbers $\N$ under the usual ordering $\le$ forms a well-ordered set.
This is called the '''well-ordering principle'''.

a84724cc-e57c-457f-8f0e-311c6dc6fbdd.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a Hausdorff space.
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ be a convergent sequence in $T$.
Then $\sequence {x_n}$ has exactly one limit.

8a08e436-543b-4261-88d5-86306f72885d.text:
Let $f: D \to \R$ be a real function where $D \subseteq \R$.
Let $x$ be a point in $D$.
Let $N_x$ be the set of neighborhoods of $x$.
Let $\map {\omega_f} x$ be the oscillation of $f$ at $x$ as defined by:
:$\map {\omega_f} x = \ds \inf \set {\map {\omega_f} I: I \in N_x}$
where $\map {\omega_f} I$ is the oscillation of $f$ on a real set $I$:
:$\map {\omega_f} I = \ds \sup \set {\size {\map f y - \map f z}: y, z \in I \cap D}$
Let $\map {\omega^L_f} x$ be the oscillation of $f$ at $x$ as defined by:
:$\map {\omega^L_f} x = \ds \lim_{h \mathop \to 0^+} \map {\omega_f} {\openint {x - h} {x + h} }$
Let $\map {\omega^L_f} x \in \R$.
Let $\map {\omega_f} x \in \R$.
Then $\map {\omega^L_f} x = \map {\omega_f} x$.

69b68a44-580f-4b60-b4a4-56e18cd8a5ad.text:
Let $M_1 = \struct {A_1, d_1}$ and $M_2 = \struct {A_2, d_2}$ be metric spaces.
Let $\phi: M_1 \to M_2$ be a distance-preserving mapping.
Then $\phi$ is an injection.

39454709-1091-4c2e-a9ac-44b75dbfd52a.text:
{{EuclidPropStatement|book=V|prop=22|body=If there be any number of magnitudes whatever, and others equal to them in multitude, which taken two and two together are in the same ratio, they will also be in the same ratio ''ex aequali''.}}
That is, if:
:$a : b = d : e$
:$b : c = e : f$
then:
:$a : c = d : f$

bc0de06f-be3f-4ac9-b529-71682bd64813.text: :$\ds \int \cot a x \rd x = \frac {\ln \size {\sin a x} } a + C$

1ef3f220-5de2-4760-80ac-6547080ea691.text:
Let $\struct {\R, \tau_d}$ be the real numbers under the usual (Euclidean) topology.
Let $\struct{\R \setminus \Q, \tau_d}$ be the irrational number space under the same topology.
Let $a, b \in \R$ such that $a < b$.
Let $\Bbb I \subseteq \R$ be an interval of $\R$
Then the closure of the set:
:$\Bbb I \cap \paren {\R \setminus \Q}$
is the closed real interval $\closedint a b$.

c969a17d-2b6b-49aa-8a45-7e07044ec9b8.text:
Let $\struct {R, \norm {\, \cdot \,} }$ be a normed division ring.
Let $\CC$ be the ring of Cauchy sequences over $R$
Let $\NN$ be the set of null sequences.
Then:
:$\NN$ is a maximal left ideal.
:$\NN \subsetneq \CC$.
{{qed|lemma}}
:There is no left ideal $\JJ$ of $\CC$ such that $\NN \subsetneq \JJ \subsetneq \CC$ 
{{qed|lemma}}
The result follows by definition of maximal left ideal.
{{qed}}

b9a9efeb-d072-46e9-93aa-4714ae36e8d2.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $\map {\operatorname{rank} } S$ denote the rank of $S$.
Then:
:$\map {\operatorname{rank} } S = \bigcap \set {x \in \On: \forall y \in S: \map {\operatorname{rank} } y < x}$

d4a5c823-1e17-4ec3-b78e-ddfcbef880c6.text:
Let $S$ and $T$ be sets.
Let $f: S \to T$ be a bijection.
Let $f^{-1}: T \to S$ be the inverse of $f$.
Then the domain of $f^{-1}$ equals the codomain of $f$.

ad011f17-7518-4f20-bd8a-a54057441338.text:
Let $\map P \R$ be the vector space of all polynomial functions on the real number line $\R$.
Let $S$ be the mapping defined as:
:$\ds \forall p \in \map P \R: \forall x \in \R: \map S {\map p x} = \int_0^x \map p t \rd t$
Then $S$ is a linear operator on $\map P \R$.

145e9a3c-a3e6-4b6d-b268-aed3f6671a44.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be a group.
Let $\RR$ be a relation compatible with $\circ$.
Let $x, y \in G$.
Then:
:$x \mathrel \RR y \iff y^{-1} \mathrel \RR x^{-1}$

7c4dd985-0586-432d-8bf2-b1631fa5f118.text:
Let $n$ be an integer.
Suppose that $\sqrt n$ is a rational number.
Then $\sqrt n$ is an integer.

013db151-b545-4b7b-915e-41d60d02484d.text:
Let $c$ and $n$ be coprime integers, that is:
:$c \perp n$
Then:
:$c a \equiv c b \pmod n \implies a \equiv b \pmod n$

98248b7f-de05-4345-b8c2-2f8ad767b59d.text:
The set of non-zero real numbers is closed under multiplication:
:$\forall x, y \in \R_{\ne 0}: x \times y \in \R_{\ne 0}$

45bf9cd6-3a4f-42b8-bce3-fb97ac744889.text:
Let $p^n$ be a prime power for some prime number $p > 1$.
Let $a$ be an integer not divisible by $p: p \nmid a$.
Then:
: $a^{\paren {p - 1} p^{n - 1} } \equiv 1 \pmod {p^n}$

0f89a65d-5a83-46be-9c81-f46f35441cd1.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $f, g: S \to S$ be mappings.
Let $x \in S$ be a fixed point of both $f$ and $g$.
Then $x$ is also a fixed point of $f \circ g$, the composition of $f$ and $g$.

13d34bb9-a858-40de-a30c-613c9ff63cba.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be an uncountable discrete topological space.
Then $T$ is not a Lindelöf space.

6dd5e06f-c864-4615-a411-8c0bf2fac918.text:
Let $G$ be a subgroup of the additive group of real numbers.
Let $G$ be discrete.
Then $G$ is closed.

c126922c-9ae9-442d-b094-67c8a49aa875.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau_{a, b} }$ be a modified Fort space.
Then $T$ is not a $T_3$ space, $T_4$ space or $T_5$ space.

85f40997-8a02-4af6-a8d3-3a3f03f26cfd.text:
Let $M$ be a locally Euclidean space of dimension $d$.
Let $\AA$ be an atlas on $M$.
Then there exists a unique differentiable structure $\FF$ on $M$ with $\AA \in \FF$.

934b62f7-fbf6-4286-b567-827b30ea2a6c.text:
Let $G$ be a group.
Let $H$ be a central subgroup of $G$.
Then $H$ is a normal subgroup of $G$.

d503cdfe-d05c-42f9-9426-f3921af2f27d.text:
Let $\Omega$ denote the minimal uncountable well-ordered set.
The cardinality of $\Omega$ satisfies:
:$\operatorname{card} \left({\N}\right) < \operatorname{card} \left({\Omega}\right) \le \mathfrak c$
where $\operatorname{card}\left({\N}\right)$ is the cardinality of the natural numbers and  $\mathfrak c$ is the cardinality of the continuum.

36b0aecb-3de7-47d4-88ec-ed0c5f6bd6bb.text:
Let $\Z$ be the set of integers.
Let $\le$ be the usual ordering on the real numbers $\R$.
Let $\O \subset S \subseteq \Z$ such that $S$ is bounded below in $\struct {\R, \le}$.
Then $S$ has a smallest element.

98e7c812-fe18-4f27-a75c-9cdf7c983e38.text: The $p$-adic norm forms a non-Archimedean norm on the rational numbers $\Q$.

9f62bc1e-51fb-4c74-a63a-6a1247c18029.text:
Let $\RR$ be a congruence relation on an algebraic structure $\struct {S, \circ}$.
Then the quotient mapping from $\struct {S, \circ}$ to the quotient structure $\struct {S / \RR, \circ_\RR}$ is an epimorphism:
:$q_\RR: \struct {S, \circ} \to \struct {S / \RR, \circ_\RR}: \forall x, y \in S: \map {q_\RR} {x \circ y} = \map {q_\RR} x \circ_\RR \map {q_\RR} y$
This is sometimes called the '''canonical epimorphism''' from $\struct {S, \circ}$ to $\struct {S / \RR, \circ_\RR}$.

f30cff94-d321-428e-aedc-859f72bd2b69.text: {{TFAE|def = Unsigned Stirling Numbers of the First Kind}}

2388cb18-e020-42f3-b8b1-40628e9b058d.text: The $2$nd column and $2$nd diagonal of Pascal's triangle consists of the set of triangular numbers.

32e84f62-607d-459f-b2d6-693c3de2913b.text:
Let $x$, $y$, and $z$ be ordinals.
Let $<$ denote membership $\in$, since $\in$ is a strict well-ordering on the ordinals.
Then:
:$x < y \implies \paren {z + x} < \paren {z + y}$

1b12ad93-4c99-4488-9dff-30648dfaba1a.text:
Let $R$ be a ring with unity.
Let $F$, $G$ and $H$ be free $R$-modules of finite dimension $p,n,m>0$ respectively.
Let $\sequence {a_p}$, $\sequence {b_n}$ and $\sequence {c_m}$ be ordered bases 
Let $\map {\LL_R} {G, H}$ denote the set of all linear transformations from $G$ to $H$.
Let $\map {\MM_R} {m, n}$ be the $m \times n$ matrix space over $R$.
Let $\sqbrk {u; \sequence {c_m}, \sequence {b_n} }$ be the matrix of $u$ relative to $\sequence {b_n}$ and $\sequence {c_m}$.
Let $M: \map {\LL_R} {G, H} \to \map {\MM_R} {m, n}$ be defined as:
:$\forall u \in \map {\LL_R} {G, H}: \map M u = \sqbrk {u; \sequence {c_m}, \sequence {b_n} }$
Then $M$ is a module isomorphism.

fcdd654e-4382-4286-a90f-ae9279ff8171.text:
:$\ds \int_0^\infty \frac {e^{-a x} - e^{-b x} } x \rd x = \ln \frac b a$
 
where $a$ and $b$ are strictly positive real numbers.

065ecc3e-357c-4ee8-9d26-547c7f6e73f5.text:
Let $\C$ denote the set of complex numbers.
Let $N: \C \to \R_{\ge 0}$ denote the field norm on complex numbers:
:$\forall z \in \C: \map N z = \cmod z^2$
where $\cmod z$ denotes the complex modulus of $z$.
Then $N$ is a multiplicative function on $\C$.

8fd8d317-69f5-4413-bec4-3f53f69414d4.text: :$\ds \int \ln x \rd x = x \ln x - x + C$

5d1b2b71-332b-4d06-892e-96215d7e6a29.text:
Let $\struct {S_1, \preccurlyeq_1}$ and $\struct {S_2, \preccurlyeq_2}$ be ordered sets.
Let $\struct {S_1, \preccurlyeq_1} \otimes^s \struct {S_2, \preccurlyeq_2}$ denote the '''simple (order) product''' of $\struct {S_1, \preccurlyeq_1}$ and $\struct {S_2, \preccurlyeq_2}$.
Then $\struct {S_1, \preccurlyeq_1} \otimes^s \struct {S_2, \preccurlyeq_2}$ is also an ordered set.

2e07fbc8-6cca-4b68-8b7e-77976be31b95.text:
:$\ds \int \map \Ci x \rd x = x \map \Ci x + \sin x + C$
where:
:$\Ci$ denotes the cosine integral function
:$x$ is a strictly positive real number.

af028d26-9f93-4de9-8a0b-3db448133250.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a Baire space (in the context of topology).
Then $T$ is non-meager in $T$.

fa0af390-47d1-4a37-8ca0-80d26bf834db.text:
Let $\struct {I, \preceq}$ be a well-ordered set.
For each $i \in I$, let $\struct {S_i, \preccurlyeq_i}$ be an ordered set.
Let $\ds D = \prod_{i \mathop \in I} S_i$ be the Cartesian product of the family $\family {\struct {S_i, \preccurlyeq_i} }_{i \mathop \in I}$ indexed by $I$.
Let $\preccurlyeq_D$ be the lexicographic order on $D$, defined as:
:$\forall u, v \in D: u \preccurlyeq_D v \iff \begin {cases} u = v \\ \map u i \preccurlyeq_i \map v i & \text {for the $\preceq$-smallest $i \in I$ such that $\map u i \ne \map v i$} \end {cases}$
Then $\struct {D, \preccurlyeq_D}$ is an ordered set.

247fd23e-3da1-4132-a349-3564835ded5d.text:
Consider the digits that form the recurring part of the reciprocal of $7$:
:$\dfrac 1 7 = 0 \cdotp \dot 14285 \dot 7$
Take the digits in ordered pairs, and treat them as coordinates of a Cartesian plane.
It will be found that they all lie on an ellipse:
:400px

0be0da38-6794-47c3-adbd-2933b2781fff.text:
Let $X$ be a set.
Let $I$ be an indexing set.
Let $\family {\struct {Y_i, \tau_i} }_{i \mathop \in I}$ be an indexed family of topological spaces indexed by $I$.
Let $\family {f_i: Y_i \to X}_{i \mathop \in I}$ be an indexed family of mappings indexed by $I$.
{{TFAE|def = Final Topology}}

6a9627c7-c529-4db7-abb1-55b5de4b2003.text:
Let $\tuple {\HH, \innerprod \cdot \cdot_\HH}$ be a Hilbert space.
Let $I_\HH$ be the identity transformation on $\HH$.
Then: 
:${I_\HH}^* = I_\HH$
where ${I_\HH}^*$ denotes the adjoint of $I_\HH$.

af9bebb8-3aab-4d0e-8910-be79c084abb6.text:
:$\forall x \in \R_{>0}: 1 - \dfrac 1 x \le \ln x$
where $\ln x$ denotes the natural logarithm of $x$.

f51486bd-8a9a-4c37-bbf4-b6e417850f7f.text: On any set $S$, the identity mapping $I_S: S \to S$ is an injection.

fcc2b5f0-68a8-4110-ba3c-c16eafd75044.text:
Let $f: S \to T$ be a mapping.
The image of the set difference of two subsets of $S$ is not necessarily equal to the set difference of the images.
That is:
Let $S_1$ and $S_2$ be subsets of $S$.
Then it is not always the case that:
:$f \sqbrk {S_1} \setminus f \sqbrk {S_2} = f \sqbrk {S_1 \setminus S_2}$
where $\setminus$ denotes set difference.

a208914c-b99c-4303-b77c-44b7b7b0ec80.text:
:$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {x^3 \paren {x^2 - a^2}^2} = \frac {-1} {2 a^4 x^2} - \frac 1 {2 a^4 \paren {x^2 - a^2} } + \frac 1 {a^6} \map \ln {\frac {x^2} {x^2 - a^2} } + C$
for $x^2 > a^2$.

3be3d606-b308-47f6-b3c2-5674d4226a7e.text:
Let $M$ be a class which is minimally inductive under a progressing mapping $g$.
Let $x \in M$.
Let $S$ be the set of all $y \in M$ such that $y \subseteq x$.
Then $S$ is finite.

088ff6c4-ea97-4a76-8ead-b69b7973b635.text:
Let $\omega$ denote the minimal infinite successor set.
:$\omega = \aleph_0$
where $\aleph$ denotes the aleph mapping.

08b57be0-b29c-4d0b-8f7c-fb4df2cbcf67.text:
Let $\mathcal F = \sequence {a_n}$ be a general Fibonacci sequence generated by the parameters $r, s, t, u$:
:$a_n = \begin{cases}
r & : n = 0 \\
s & : n = 1 \\
t a_{n - 2} + u a_{n - 1} & : n > 1
\end{cases}$
Let:
:$d = \gcd \set {r, s}$
where $\gcd$ denotes greatest common divisor.
Then:
:$\forall n \in \Z_{>0}: d \divides a_n$

b1908f71-005c-4c89-b673-b9eb11727fca.text: The completed Riemann zeta function $\xi$ has order at most $1$.

ef568570-cd4d-43a7-a099-bd9008272bc3.text:
:$\sin^5 x = \dfrac {10 \sin x - 5 \sin 3 x + \sin 5 x} {16}$
where $\sin$ denotes sine.

bb069b4a-bab2-482d-ad8e-a3276e71735b.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Let $\ds \sum_{n \mathop = m}^\infty d_n p^n$ be a $p$-adic expansion.
Let $\struct {\Q_p, \norm {\,\cdot\,}_p}$ be the $p$-adic Numbers.
Then the sequence of partial sums of the series:
:$\ds \sum_{n \mathop = m}^\infty d_n p^n$
represents a $p$-adic number of $\struct {\Q_p,\norm {\,\cdot\,}_p}$.

95d34acf-e99e-49d0-b048-e3c3d719fe5d.text:
Let $\left({D, +, \circ}\right)$ be a principal ideal domain.
Let $\left({p}\right)$ be the principal ideal of $D$ generated by $p$.
Let $\left({p}\right)$ be a maximal ideal of $D$.
Then $p$ is irreducible.

676b09b3-9a18-4c52-97fa-78df7b3b79f6.text:
:$\dfrac \pi 4 = 4 \arctan \dfrac 1 5 - \arctan \dfrac 1 {239} \approx 0 \cdotp 78539 \, 81633 \, 9744 \ldots$
{{OEIS|A003881}}
The calculation of $\pi$ (pi) can then proceed using the Gregory Series:
:$\arctan \dfrac 1 x = \dfrac 1 x - \dfrac 1 {3 x^3} + \dfrac 1 {5 x^5} - \dfrac 1 {7 x^7} + \dfrac 1 {9 x^9} - \cdots$
which is valid for $x \le 1$.

3f5fa5a4-e65f-4b8d-b0c3-0166fcad1d11.text:
Let $L = \struct {S, \preceq}$ be an ordered set.
Let $x, y \in S$ such that
:$x^\preceq = y^\preceq$
where $x^\preceq$ denotes the lower closure of $x$.
Then $x = y$

a0fd7d00-64da-48e0-8dea-b56c351b77b8.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Let $\R$ denote the real numbers.
Let $f: M \to \R$ and $g: M \to \R$ be real-valued functions from $M$ to $\R$ which are continuous on $M$.
Then:
:$f + g$ is ‎continuous on $M$.

221aa3b4-86e6-4729-b72f-1170aa3451ab.text:
Let $\tuple {\mathbf i, \mathbf j, \mathbf k}$ be the standard ordered basis of Cartesian $3$-space $S$.
Then:
:$\mathbf i \cdot \mathbf j = \mathbf j \cdot \mathbf k = \mathbf k \cdot \mathbf i = 0$
where $\cdot$ denotes the dot product.

d187a75e-a917-4317-b4b6-0da7a97f9b74.text:
Let $x, y, z$ be ordinals.
Then:
:$\left({z + x}\right) = \left({z + y}\right) \implies x = y$
That is, ordinal addition is left cancellable.

a1afab77-f419-4382-901d-c3611f9a7931.text:
Let $m, n, q \in \Z_{>0}$.
Let:
:$m \divides n$
where $\divides$ denotes divisibility.
Then:
:$\paren {q^m - 1} \divides \paren {q^n - 1}$
Let $m, n, q \in \Z_{>0}$.
Let
:$\paren {q^m - 1} \divides \paren {q^n - 1}$
where $\divides$ denotes divisibility.
Then:
:$m \divides n$

5c028f5f-0f7b-4657-b373-392ad0e51a8f.text:
Let $S$ and $T$ be sets.
Let $f: S \to T$ be a mapping.
Let the inverse $f^{-1} \subseteq T \times S$ itself be a mapping.
Then $f$ is an injection.

04a6a91e-05e2-46f7-9843-0abe1020aaf9.text:
Let $\struct {\Z, -}$ denote the algebraic structure formed by the set of integers under the operation of subtraction.
Then $\struct {\Z, -}$ is not a semigroup.

4a97d946-fbb5-49bb-9377-7b89f4111a5a.text:
Let $\struct {X, \tau}$ be a compact Hausdorff space. 
Let $f : X \to X$ be a continuous function.
Define a sequence of sets $\sequence {X_i}_{i \mathop \in \N}$ by:
:$X_i = \begin{cases} X & : i = 1 \\ \map f {X_{i - 1} } & : i \ge 2 \end{cases}$
Then, for each $i \in \N$:
:$X_i$ is closed
:$X_i$ is non-empty
:$X_{i + 1} \subseteq X_i$.

40a4aed0-58ca-4030-903a-b63a0c84276d.text:
Let $\struct {\Z_m, +_m, \times_m}$ be the ring of integers modulo $m$.
Then $\eqclass k m \in \Z_m$ has an inverse in $\struct {\Z_m, \times_m}$ {{iff}} $k \perp m$.

1a373a8d-5698-4f8d-ade6-ba7c08498c3f.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\cos a x \rd x} {\map \sin {a x + \phi} } = \frac {\ln \size {\map \sin {a x + \phi} } } {a \cos \phi} + \tan \phi \int \frac {\sin a x \rd x} {\map \sin {a x + \phi} } + C$

7aa46deb-03b0-4b07-9dfe-534c3fb3cccb.text:
Let $T_A = \struct {S_A, \tau_A}$ and $T_B = \struct {S_B, \tau_B}$ be topological spaces.
Let $\phi: T_A \to T_B$ be a homeomorphism.
If $T_A$ is a $T_{2 \frac 1 2}$ (completely Hausdorff) space, then so is $T_B$.

28f5a2a1-ac00-4ac3-bc1a-5d663cf4bba8.text:
Let $\R$ denote the real number line with the usual (Euclidean) metric.
Let $a \in \R$ be a point in $\R$.
Let $k \in \Z$ be some fixed integer.
Let $\BB_a$ be defined as:
:$\BB_a := \set {\map {B_\epsilon} a: \epsilon \in \set {\dfrac 1 n: n \in \N, n > k} }$
that is, the set of all open $\epsilon$-balls of $a$ for $\epsilon$ which are reciprocals of integers greater than $k$.
Then the $\BB_a$ is a basis for the neighborhood system of $a$.

6c7864e6-c922-494e-8f09-8acd93c7fade.text:
:$\gcd \set {a, b} = \gcd \set {\size a, b} = \gcd \set {a, \size b} = \gcd \set {\size a, \size b}$
Alternatively, this can be put:
:$\gcd \set {a, b} = \gcd \set {-a, b} = \gcd \set {a, -b} = \gcd \set {-a, -b}$
 
which follows directly from the above.

d4fc10d6-c003-48cf-a064-d7abe6d1912e.text:
Consider the lemniscate of Bernoulli $M$ embedded in a Cartesian plane such that its foci are at $\tuple {a, 0}$ and $\tuple {-a, 0}$ respectively.
Let $O$ denote the origin.
The area of one lobe of $M$ is $a^2$.

f72d6568-08f8-47aa-ad9e-e44fa42c8492.text:
Let $\struct {\Z \sqbrk {i \sqrt 5}, +, \times}$ denote the $5$th cyclotomic ring.
There are no elements of $\struct {\Z \sqbrk {i \sqrt 5}, +, \times}$ whose field norm is either $2$ or $3$.

8d071b6e-94c0-40dc-b861-fd609354aa7d.text:
Let $\struct {K, \times}$ be the circle group, that is:
:$K = \set {z \in \C: \cmod z = 1}$
under complex multiplication.
Let $f: \R \to K$ be the mapping from the real numbers to $K$ defined as:
:$\forall x \in \R: \map f x = \cos x + i \sin x$
Then $f: \struct {\R, +} \to \struct {K, \times}$ is a group epimorphism.
Its kernel is:
:$\map \ker f = \set {2 \pi n: n \in \Z}$

b5281035-2026-406c-a63a-5d7a91178a53.text: The smallest integer greater than $1$ which is not the sum of two Ulam numbers is $23$.

a15b674c-0d27-4009-98d5-bf21e85e0a8e.text:
Let $A$ be a commutative ring with unity.
Let $S \subseteq A$ be a multiplicatively closed subset with $0 \notin S$.
Then there exists a localization $\struct {A_S, \iota}$ of $A$ at $S$.

02124ef2-907d-4a86-a5e1-2b74a9b646d7.text:
Let $A, B \subseteq S$.
Let $\chi_{A \mathop \cap B}$ be the characteristic function of their intersection $A \cap B$.
Then:
:$\chi_{A \mathop \cap B} = \chi_A \chi_B$

9a90e60d-e479-4f59-8c76-984d237a7a8e.text:
Let $S$ be a set such that $S$ is equivalent to its cardinal.
If the axiom of choice holds, then this condition holds for any set.
Then:
:$\card {\paren {\card S} } = \card S$
where $\card S$ denotes the cardinal number of $S$.

e8698eff-38b6-4b99-ab4e-b033ce2e0431.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau_{\bar p} }$ be an excluded point space.
Then $T^*_{\bar p}$ is path-connected.

bb40e9d2-cfa5-44b4-80b7-f9b27c939263.text:
:$\forall m, n \in \Z: -m \equiv n - m \pmod n$
where $\bmod n$ denotes congruence modulo $n$.

d473df90-0155-498e-8716-276aa006847e.text:
Let $x$, $y$ be real numbers.
Let $x^y$, $x$ to the power of $y$, be real.
Then:
:$\size {x^y} = \size x^y$

091abd45-fedd-4e65-a59b-2987a5f77998.text:
Let $\exp x$ be the exponential of $x$.
Then:
:$\exp 1 = e$
where $e$ is Euler's number: $e = 2.718281828\ldots$

645f372a-b679-4bf6-9e7b-1b9714bb3a0e.text:
Let $V$ be a vector space over $\R$ or $\C$, and let $v \in V$.
Then the singleton $S = \set v$ is a convex set.

d7072f5b-73b1-4b99-8ad9-60f730c2637e.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be an ordered set.
Let $T \subseteq S$ be an upper set.
Then $T$ is convex in $S$.

34fa90c7-bbb5-49c2-9dbb-82ef83a8db04.text:
A mapping $f: S \to T, S \ne \O$ is a surjection {{iff}}:
:$\exists g: T \to S: f \circ g = I_T$
where:
:$g$ is a mapping
:$I_T$ is the identity mapping on $T$.
That is, {{iff}} $f$ has a right inverse.

3dd215e4-55de-448c-975d-c3e80f674d99.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \set {\O, S} }$ be an indiscrete topological space which has more than one element.
Then $T$ is not a $T_0$ (Kolmogorov) space.

2c32aa79-5132-4791-bdfc-2d938254d1bf.text: There exists at least one example of a paracompact topological space which is not also a compact topological space.

6375a5e0-183d-4755-b0a5-349b5282d5f2.text:
Let $n$ be a perfect number.
Then:
:$\ds \sum_{d \mathop \divides n} \dfrac 1 d = 2$
That is, the sum of the reciprocals of the divisors of $n$ is equal to $2$.

badac5f4-ab80-4c06-a772-b0a4c6dd5df6.text:
Let $\struct {\SS, \circ}$ be the external direct product of the algebraic structures $\struct {S_1, \circ_1}, \struct {S_2, \circ_2}, \ldots, \struct {S_k, \circ_k}, \ldots, \struct {S_n, \circ_n}$.
Then:
:for each $j \in \closedint 1 n$, $\pr_j$ is an epimorphism from $\struct {\SS, \circ}$ to $\struct {S_j, \circ_j}$
where $\pr_j: \struct {\SS, \circ} \to \struct {S_j, \circ_j}$ is the $j$th projection from $\struct {\SS, \circ}$ to $\struct {S_j, \circ_j}$.

a918ce33-ce1e-4955-a840-08752ef0b3b1.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a ring with unity.
Let the zero of $R$ be $0_R$ and the unity of $R$ be $1_R$.
Let the characteristic of $R$ be $n$.
Then:
:$\forall a \in R: n \cdot a = 0_R$

1d2e916a-5235-49b1-8dc4-4eae5fc301bb.text:
Let $R$ be a ring.
Let $n \in \Z_{>0}$ be a (strictly) positive integer.
Let $\struct {\map {\MM_R} n, +, \times}$ denote the ring of square matrices of order $n$ over $R$.
Then $\struct {\map {\MM_R} n, +, \times}$ is a ring.

6b833a76-6406-4202-830a-e45b2341d2a2.text:
Let $\R$ denote the real numbers.
Let $f$ and $g$ be real functions defined on an open subset $S \subseteq \R$, except possibly at the point $c \in S$.
Let $f$ and $g$ tend to the following limits:
:$\ds \lim_{x \mathop \to c} \map f x = l$
:$\ds \lim_{x \mathop \to c} \map g x = m$
Then:
:$\ds \lim_{x \mathop \to c} \paren {\map f x \map  g x} = l m$

a9315853-0c80-4f1c-991e-2547ab83df71.text:
Let $\struct {D, +, \times}$ be a Euclidean domain.
Then $\struct {D, +, \times}$ is a unique factorization domain.

f5cc6cca-ba58-4b15-b069-84ef60b68c24.text:
Let $x, y \in \Z$ such that $x > y$.
Then:
:$-x < -y$

7176ae98-c123-4239-abd2-8335a7e83280.text:
Let $S_n$ denote the symmetric group on $n$ letters.
Let $\rho, \sigma \in S_n$ such that $\rho$ and $\sigma$ are disjoint.
Then $\rho \sigma = \sigma \rho$.

b20e7b52-08e6-4525-8ff3-0eb78369ee50.text:
Let $k$ and $a$ be positive real numbers. 
Then: 
:$\ds \lim_{x \mathop \to \infty} x^k e^{-a x} = 0$

4b28cbd0-a5dc-47f7-82de-0c57a007bdf6.text:
Let the following conditions hold:
:$(1): \quad$ Let $\struct {S, \circ, \preceq}$ and $\struct {T, *, \preccurlyeq}$ be ordered semigroups.
:$(2): \quad$ Let $\phi: S \to T$ be a mapping.
:$(3): \quad$ Let $\preceq$ be a total ordering on $S$.
Then $\phi \struct {S, \circ, \preceq} \to \struct {T, *, \preccurlyeq}$ is a (structure) monomorphism {{iff}}:
:$(1): \quad \phi$ is strictly increasing from $\struct {S, \preceq}$ into $\struct {T, \preccurlyeq}$
:$(2): \quad \phi$ is a homomorphism from $\struct {S, \circ}$ into $\struct {T, *}$.

6785f57b-7bdd-4e08-bf81-9f276a6135d4.text:
Let $\mathscr S = \struct {S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}$ be a meet-continuous lattice.
Let $x \in S$.
Let $f: S \to S$ be a mapping such that:
:$\forall y \in S: \map f y = x \wedge y$
Then:
:$f$ preserves directed suprema.

2ed97fd6-8c06-4feb-92c6-9a0f8a730ae7.text:
Let $\struct {G, +_G, \circ}_R$ be an unitary $R$-module.
Let $\struct {H, +_H, \circ}_R$ be an $R$-algebraic structure.
Let $\phi: G \to H$ be an epimorphism.
Then $H$ is a unitary $R$-module.

7c32f020-9308-4be2-bd74-5161c527dd46.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be an ordered set.
Let $\cl$ be a closure operator on $S$.
Let $x \in S$.
{{TFAE|def = Closed Element}}

e91db16f-c493-4702-8fc2-f61a60c89504.text:
Let $x$ be a real number.
Then there exists an integer less than $x$:
:$\forall x \in \R: \exists n \in \Z: n < x$

4951959f-5cc2-42c0-8df8-e888afc80de4.text:
:$\ds \int x^2 \sqrt {x^2 - a^2} \rd x = \frac {x \paren {\sqrt {x^2 - a^2} }^3} 4 + \frac {a^2 x \sqrt {x^2 - a^2} } 8 - \frac {a^4} 8 \ln \size {x + \sqrt {x^2 - a^2} } + C$
for $\size x \ge a$.

19359e57-8c64-4996-a50f-1cccf7e548be.text:
Let $n$ be a perfect number.
Let $n = r s$ where $r$ and $s$ are positive integers such that $r > 1$ and $s > 1$.
Then $r$ and $s$ are both deficient.

4e94d0da-4fe2-406b-b3e6-4de57e04f43e.text:
Let $R$ be a commutative ring with unity.
Let $G$ be a unitary $R$-module whose dimension is finite.
Then the evaluation linear transformation $J: G \to G^{**}$ is an isomorphism.

a1b232e9-f636-46f6-8278-05d558b30597.text:
Let $n \in \N$ be a natural number.
Let $2^n + 1$ be prime.
Then $n = 2^k$ for some natural number $k$.

a414b6de-91a0-4d2a-8e76-0939a5e1fd86.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be an uncountable discrete topological space.
Then $T$ is not second-countable.

2b239c98-2e1c-4d06-bd41-0a1251074a2a.text:
Let $\struct {S, \RR_1}$ and $\struct {T, \RR_2}$ be relational structures.
Let $\struct {S, \RR_1}$ and $\struct {T, \RR_2}$ be (relationally) isomorphic.
Then $\RR_1$ is a transitive relation {{iff}} $\RR_2$ is a transitive relation.

ae8a518b-e406-48c4-bb23-c6870851cd78.text:
Let $P_1$ and $P_2$ be compactness properties and let:
:$P_1 \implies P_2$
mean:
:If a metric space $M$ satsifies property $P_1$, then $M$ also satisfies property $P_2$.
Then the following sequence of implications holds:
{|
|-
| align="center" | Sequentially Compact ||
| align="center" | $\implies$ ||
| align="center" | Weakly $\sigma$-Locally Compact ||
| align="center" | $\implies$ ||
| align="center" | Weakly Locally Compact ||
|-
| align="center" | $\Big\Updownarrow$ ||
| align="center" | ||
| align="center" | $\Big\Downarrow$ ||
| align="center" | ||
| align="center" | $\Big\Updownarrow$ ||
|-
| align="center" | Countably Compact ||
| align="center" | ||
| align="center" | $\sigma$-Compact ||
| align="center" | ||
| align="center" | Strongly Locally Compact ||
|-
| align="center" | $\Big\Updownarrow$ ||
| align="center" | ||
| align="center" | $\Big\Downarrow$ ||
|-
| align="center" | Compact ||
| align="center" | ||
| align="center" | Separable ||
|-
| align="center" | $\Big\Updownarrow$ ||
| align="center" | ||
| align="center" | $\Big\Updownarrow$ ||
|-
| align="center" | Weakly Countably Compact ||
| align="center" | ||
| align="center" | Lindelöf ||
|-
| align="center" | ||
| align="center" | ||
| align="center" | $\Big\Updownarrow$ ||
|-
| align="center" | ||
| align="center" | ||
| align="center" | Second-Countable ||
|}

9fdc94aa-a4d2-4268-a55f-fe903ae82a39.text: For every even integer $n$ such that $n > 1$, if $n$ can be expressed as the product of one or more even-times odd integers, it is not necessarily the case that this product is unique.

26a3abb8-7fdf-4ec4-a1fa-a4ba7c7c2790.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Then:
:$0 \le k \le p - 1 \implies \dbinom {p - 1} k \equiv \left({-1}\right)^k \pmod p$
where $\dbinom {p - 1} k$ denotes a binomial coefficient.

0327cc0e-7f74-4d3c-8dc8-ef989f30bad5.text:
Let $n \in \Z$ be an integer such that $n > 3$.
Then $n$, $n + 2$, $n + 4$ cannot all be prime.
That is, the only prime triplet is $\set {3, 5, 7}$.

fd06de75-9b8b-473e-a29c-ddf2af86aae5.text:
Let $\theta$ be an angle such that $\cos \theta \ne 0$.
Then:
:$\tan \theta = \dfrac {\sin \theta} {\cos \theta}$
where $\tan$, $\sin$ and $\cos$ mean tangent, sine and cosine respectively.

4661c65b-e4be-427c-bb57-2ee9dada4512.text:
Let $p, p_1, p_2, \ldots, p_n$ be primes such that:
:$p \divides \ds \prod_{i \mathop = 1}^n p_i$
Then:
:$\exists i \in \closedint 1 n: p = p_i$

0ee6c1c8-b6ae-4e2c-8289-09054ddc8efc.text:
Let $X$ be a subset of $\powerset \R$ such that:
:$(1): \quad X$ is pairwise disjoint:
::::$\forall A, B \in X: A \ne B \implies A \cap B = \O$.
:$(2): \quad$ every element of $X$ contains an open interval:
::::$\forall A \in X: \exists x, y \in \R: x < y \land \openint x y \subseteq A$.
Then $X$ is countable.

d4fed22d-068c-4856-8895-14547eee5650.text: {{TFAE|def = Limit Inferior of Sequence of Sets}}

729c4d33-2bd9-4539-b3ad-313a79924418.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space where $S$ is a finite set.
Then $T$ is compact.

29cabe17-a564-4a14-bce0-420c6c12c803.text:
Let $L = \left({S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}\right)$ be a continuous complete lattice.
Let $X = \mathit{IRR}\left({L}\right) \setminus \left\{ {\top}\right\}$
where $\mathit{IRR}\left({L}\right)$ denotes the set of all meet irreducible element of $S$,
:$\top$ denotes the top of $L$.
Then $X$ is order generating.

cae00a89-881f-4eeb-8bc8-e754879ac2c3.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be a totally ordered set.
Let $I$ be an interval: be it open, closed, or half-open in $S$.
Then $I$ is convex in $S$.

ce00434f-1c5d-446a-b17e-623e69a0fc35.text:
Let $T = \struct {\R, \tau}$ be the compact complement topology on $\R$.
Then $T$ is a compact space.

0c493059-00e8-4ec7-b5d9-ef97ee884a54.text:
For any real number $x \in \R$:
: $\sin x = \dfrac {e^{i x} - e^{-i x} } {2 i}$
where:
: $e^{i x}$ denotes the exponential function
: $\sin x$ denotes the real sine function
: $i$ denotes the inaginary unit.

136d87b6-d0ea-48c2-8912-bdcdc6a7c111.text:
Let $S$ be a set such that $\card S > 1$, that is, such that $S$ is not a singleton.
Let $\mathbb F$ be the set of all mappings from the natural numbers $\N$ to $S$:
:$\mathbb F = \set {f: \N \to S}$
Then $\mathbb F$ is uncountably infinite.

fedcd5bc-d037-433a-a329-78089803139a.text:
Let $S$ be a finite set with $n$ elements.
There are $2^{n \paren {n - 1} / 2}$ commutative binary operations on $S$ which are closed on all subsets of $S$.

85c92b71-3db9-4dda-bc9a-a71d9a054d8a.text:
Let $A$ be a commutative ring with unity.
Let $\mathfrak a, \mathfrak b \subseteq A$ be ideals.
Then for the radical of their sum we have:
:$\map \Rad {\mathfrak a + \mathfrak b} = \map \Rad {\map \Rad {\mathfrak a} + \map \Rad {\mathfrak b} }$

0edcd15c-1917-42cf-a36c-69319fdba860.text:
Let $a \in \R_{\ne 0}$.
Then:
:$\ds \int x^2 \sqrt {a x^2 + b x + c} \rd x = \frac {6 a x - 5 b} {24 a^2} \paren {\sqrt {a x^2 + b x + c} }^3 + \frac {5 b^2 - 4 a c} {16 a^2} \int \sqrt {a x^2 + b x + c} \rd x$

b9a30315-45b0-49f0-8016-5ba470902645.text:
Let $M_1 = \struct {A_1, d_1}$ and $M_2 = \struct {A_2, d_2}$ be metric spaces.
Let $S \subseteq M_1$ be a subset of $M_1$.
Let $f: M_1 \to M_2$ be a mapping which is continuous at a point $\alpha \in S$.
Let $f \restriction_S = g: S \to M_2$ be the restriction of $f$ to $S$.
Then $g$ is continuous at $\alpha$.

d1c16bc8-ab4e-4d38-a30e-b91a98d4da87.text:
Let $a \in \N$ be an even perfect number.
Then $a$ is in the form:
:$2^{n - 1} \paren {2^n - 1}$
where $2^n - 1$ is prime.
{{AuthorRef|René Descartes}} stated in $1638$ that he had a proof that every even perfect number is of the form $2^{p - 1} \paren {2^p - 1}$, but failed to actually produce it.
The first actual published proof was made by {{AuthorRef|Leonhard Paul Euler}}.
This result was achieved by {{AuthorRef|Leonhard Paul Euler}}.

087a807e-50ae-4463-a973-5c9f3350c2ee.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\paren {\sqrt {a^2 - x^2} }^3} {x^2} \rd x = \frac {-\paren {\sqrt {a^2 - x^2} }^3} x - \frac {3 x \sqrt {a^2 - x^2} } 2 - \frac {3 a^2} 2 \arcsin \frac x a + C$

4e97c38d-45c2-4193-9061-4b2f6913e770.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, *, \norm {\,\cdot\,} }$ be a normed division ring.
Let $d$ be the metric induced by the norm $\norm {\,\cdot\,}$.
Let $p \in \R_{\ge 1} \cup \set \infty$.
Let $d_p$ be the $p$-product metric on $R \times R$.
Then the mapping:
:$+ : \struct {R \times R, d_p} \to \struct{R,d}$ 
is continuous.

94f42eb7-f076-4564-b19e-9ff8da3e1908.text:
Let $\R$ be the real number line.
Let $\struct {\R, d_1}$ be the metric space such that $d_1$ be the Euclidean metric on $\R$.
Let $\struct {\R, d_2}$ be the metric space such that $d_2$ be the standard discrete metric on $\R$.
Let $f: \tuple {\R, d_2} \to \tuple {\R, d_1}$ be a real function.
Then $f$ is $\tuple {d_2, d_1}$-continuous on $\R$.

a134c184-7a3b-436c-84a8-5fe2f4f6a1c9.text:
Let $a \in \R_{\ne 0}$.
Then:
:$\ds \int x \paren {a x^2 + b x + c}^{n + \frac 1 2} \rd x = \frac {\paren {a x^2 + b x + c}^{n + \frac 3 2} } {a \paren {2 n + 3} } - \frac b {2 a} \int \paren {a x^2 + b x + c}^{n + \frac 1 2} \rd x$

8c3f387f-cab8-4d84-a8cf-29b3fa1f7040.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ, \preceq}$ be a naturally ordered semigroup.
Let $1$ be the one of $S$.
Let $n \in S$.
Then $n \circ 1$ is the immediate successor of $n$.
That is, for all $m \in S$:
:$n \prec m \iff n \circ 1 \preceq m$

5569c86b-5051-4f2f-914c-ea617664b28b.text:
Let $e$ be an elementary row operation.
Let $\mathbf E$ be the elementary row matrix corresponding to $e$.
Let $e'$ be the inverse of $e$.
Then the elementary row matrix corresponding to $e'$ is the inverse of $\mathbf E$.

3faf2b6d-a36c-406a-bef9-e5306edeca5e.text:
Let $n \in \Z_{\ge 0}$.
Then:
:$\map s {n + 1, 1} = \paren {-1}^n n!$
where $\map s {n + 1, 1}$ denotes a signed Stirling number of the first kind.

aee9b6d6-0766-4971-a4cd-1955379d4a24.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a separable topological space.
Then $T$ satisfies the countable chain condition.

30cc0dd4-3f64-4163-8c3b-dc42b6a84ed6.text:
Let Schanuel's Conjecture be true.
Then Euler's number $e$ to the power of itself:
:$e^e$
is transcendental.

22c9c2d7-f38f-43ee-b58a-3a8cf221a080.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Let $C$ be a subspace of $M$.
If $C$ is compact, then it is bounded.

4ff8e901-1e88-4ba7-95ca-6e56308e263a.text:
{{Cross-Relation Quotient Structure Inverse Completion Context Definition}}
Let the mapping $\psi: S \to T'$ be defined as:
:$\forall x \in S: \map \psi x = \eqclass {\tuple {x \circ a, a} } \boxtimes$
Let $S'$ be the image $\psi \sqbrk S$ of $S$.
Then $\struct {S', \oplus'}$ is a subsemigroup of $\struct {T', \oplus'}$.

fb1bc7d7-5e18-4a0a-beb2-ba310a814ad0.text:
A sequence of best rational approximations to the square root of $2$ starts:
:$\dfrac 1 1, \dfrac 3 2, \dfrac 7 5, \dfrac {17} {12}, \dfrac {41} {29}, \dfrac {99} {70}, \dfrac {239} {169}, \dfrac {577} {408}, \ldots$
where:
:the numerators are half of the Pell-Lucas numbers, $\dfrac 1 2 Q_n$
:the denominators are the Pell numbers $P_n$
starting from $\dfrac {\tfrac12 Q_1} {P_1}$.
{{OEIS-Numerators|A001333}}
{{OEIS-Denominators|A000129}}

4330d4d5-def2-46be-9c46-5c7a24f98aee.text:
Let $P$ be the polynomial equation:
:$a_n z^n + a_{n - 1} z^{n - 1} + \cdots + a_1 z + a_0 = 0$
such that $a_n \ne 0$.
The product of the roots of $P$ is $\dfrac {\paren {-1}^n a_0} {a_n}$.

15ca04dc-7989-4ff8-bef8-1e51a18123a2.text:
Let $\map f x$ be the real function defined on $\openint 0 2$ as:
:600px
:$\map f x = 4 - x^2$
Then its Fourier series can be expressed as:
:$\map f x \sim \ds \frac 8 3 - \frac 4 {\pi^2} \sum_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty \frac {\cos n \pi x} {n^2} + \frac 4 \pi \sum_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty  \frac {\sin n \pi x} n$

2bf72f6a-67e2-47b5-8a38-f889262e7a1d.text:
Let $\struct {\C, +}$ be the additive group of complex numbers.
Let $\struct {\R, +}$ be the additive group of real numbers.
Let $f: \C \to \R$ be the mapping from the complex numbers to the real numbers defined as:
:$\forall z \in \C: \map f z = \map \Re z$
where $\map \Re z$ denotes the real part of $z$.
Then $f: \struct {\C, +} \to \struct {\R, +}$ is a group epimorphism.
Its kernel is the set:
:$\map \ker f = \set {i x: x \in \R}$
of wholly imaginary numbers.

ea770282-cf72-400c-a208-ab3fc1a8aae2.text:
:$\ds \map {\frac \d {\d x} } {\map \erf x} = \frac 2 {\sqrt \pi} e^{-x^2}$
where $\erf$ denotes the error function.

928b200d-c56b-4173-a505-186672ecd5e3.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ and $\struct {T, *}$ be algebraic structures.
Let $\phi: \struct {S, \circ} \to \struct {T, *}$ be a homomorphism.
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ have an identity $e_S$.
Let $\struct {T, *}$ also have an identity $e_T = \map \phi {e_S}$.
If $x^{-1}$ is an inverse of $x$ for $\circ$, then $\map \phi {x^{-1} }$ is an inverse of $\map \phi x$ for $*$.
That is:
:$\map \phi {x^{-1} } = \paren {\map \phi x}^{-1}$

e44b5795-7048-4177-8f4a-4694e994ef4e.text:
Let $a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n, b_1, b_2, \ldots, b_n \in \R_{\ge 0}$ be non-negative real numbers.
Let $p \in \R$, $p \ne 0$ be a real number.
If $p < 0$, then we require that $a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n, b_1, b_2, \ldots, b_n$ be strictly positive.
If $p > 1$, then:
:$\ds \paren {\sum_{k \mathop = 1}^n \paren {a_k + b_k}^p}^{1/p} \le \paren {\sum_{k \mathop = 1}^n a_k^p}^{1/p} + \paren {\sum_{k \mathop = 1}^n b_k^p}^{1/p}$
If $p < 1$, $p \ne 0$, then:
:$\ds \paren {\sum_{k \mathop = 1}^n \paren {a_k + b_k}^p}^{1/p} \ge \paren {\sum_{k \mathop = 1}^n a_k^p}^{1/p} + \paren {\sum_{k \mathop = 1}^n b_k^p}^{1/p}$

8d1a0c0d-35dd-4c69-ad40-dd83696909c7.text:
Let $S$ and $T$ be sets.
Let $f: S \to T$ be a mapping.
The image of $S$ is the image set of $f$:
:$f \sqbrk S = \Img f$

5c36cd7b-b23a-4156-95ad-7d999b0b706d.text:
The only solutions of the Ljunggren equation:
:$x^2 + 1 = 2 y^4$
are:
:$x = 1,  y = 1$
:$x = 239,  y = 13$
{{OEIS|A229384}}

57f70c78-7b85-4e1d-86c0-4ddf1a80c77a.text:
Let $r \in \R_{\ge 0}$ be a positive real number.
Then:
:$\exists y_1 \in \R_{\ge 0}: {y_1}^2 = r$
:$\exists y_2 \in \R_{\le 0}: {y_2}^2 = r$

62f83932-4456-4c1f-ba38-16f2b21ca985.text:
Let $\mathbf C$ be a metacategory.
Let $f: C \to D$ be an isomorphism.
Then $f: C \rightarrowtail D$ is monic.

17d5574e-9e2e-47ee-a056-16e354a8ff7a.text:
Let $A$ be a class.
Let $P$ be a proper class.
Let $f: P \to A$ be an injection.
Then $A$ is proper.

f7b0ebd3-c894-4a4b-bfcb-58278984ccb8.text:
Let $\struct {G, \cdot}$ be a group.
Let $f: \struct {V, \phi} \to \struct {V', \mu}$ be a $G$-Module Homomorphism.
Then $\Img f$ is a $G$-Submodule of $V'$.

dca6d33b-1556-4db9-8032-76e392acacb0.text:
Let $A$ be a class of natural numbers.
Let $A$ have no greatest element.
Then $A$ is a denumerable class.

442b40ca-f944-4698-a8d7-707e8f42bfb8.text:
Let $M_1 = \struct {A_1, d_1}$ and $M_2 = \struct {A_2, d_2}$ be metric spaces.
Let $M_1$ and $M_2$ be isometric.
Then $M_1$ and $M_2$ are homeomorphic.

8b4a4aa4-38a7-4311-9c0f-426058115816.text:
Let $m \in \Z$ such that $m > 1$.
Then:
:$\ds \prod_{k \mathop = 1}^{m - 1} \sin \frac {k \pi} m = \frac m {2^{m - 1} }$

c6465e91-c856-4dd6-aae4-fa5258dcfb45.text:
Let $L = \struct {S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}$ be a complete lattice.
Let $X, Y$ be subsets of $S$ such that
:$X$ is order generating
and
:$X \subseteq Y$
Then $Y$ is order generating.

53700104-2f08-4e72-9d9b-34cd4e46c290.text:
Let $T$ be a topological space.
Let $n \in \N$.
Let:
:$\forall i \in \set {1, 2, \ldots, n}: H_i \subseteq T$
Then:
:$\ds \bigcup_{i \mathop = 1}^n \map \cl {H_i} = \map \cl {\bigcup_{i \mathop = 1}^n H_i}$
where $\map \cl {H_i}$ denotes the closure of $H_i$.

040be79e-800d-4728-aecf-90a04e7d08a8.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau_p}$ be a particular point space.
Let $x \in S$ such that $x \ne p$.
Then $x$ is a limit point of $p$.

032aeed2-d6aa-4228-abd4-9a54070daf52.text:
Ordinal addition is associative, i.e.:
:$\paren {x + y} + z = x + \paren {y + z}$
holds for all ordinals $x$, $y$ and $z$.

4b5cb5ca-bd3b-485d-947a-177b37b633a9.text:
Let $f_c: \R \to \R$ be the constant mapping:
:$\exists c \in \R: \forall a \in \R: \map {f_c} a = c$
Then $f_c$ is uniformly continuous on $\R$.

a9bd59ce-8052-419d-8ad0-758c3fb7bd2d.text:
Let $\closedint a b$ be a closed real interval.
Let $F, f: \closedint a b \to \C$ be complex functions.
Suppose that $F$ is a primitive of $f$.
Then the complex Riemann integral of $f$ satisfies:
:$\ds \int_a^b \map f t \rd t = \map F b - \map F a$

4a43b96b-471c-42e1-a198-dc7ee4eae862.text:
Let $X$ be a set, and let $Y$ be a countable set.
Let $f: X \to Y$ be an injection.
Then $X$ is also countable.

3efc11dd-a4e5-4dae-ba30-dbfc09ec4475.text:
:$\map \tanh {a - b} = \dfrac {\tanh a - \tanh b} {1 - \tanh a \tanh b}$
where $\tanh$ denotes the hyperbolic tangent.

d063c1bd-b8df-440c-b3f4-41fd62e89984.text:
Consider Gabriel's horn, the solid of revolution formed by rotating about the $x$-axis the curve:
:$y = \dfrac 1 x$
Consider the volume $V$ of the space enclosed by the plane $x = 1$ and the portion of Gabriel's horn where $x \ge 1$.
Then:
:$V = \pi$

ce01abfc-7a5d-41a5-8c86-fad092cda245.text:
Let $n$ be an integer such that $n > 3$.
Then the $n$th alternating group $A_n$ is not abelian.

06c14e4d-033f-4591-8f52-d0503a5cebdd.text: The operation of multplication on the quaternions $H$ is not commutative.

618f0e9d-76d7-4a91-93c8-c1d11925269c.text:
Let $R$ be a ring.
Then $R$ is a subring of itself.

75983f55-7211-4f4e-a09a-1a99a77d8349.text:
Let $\ds S := \sum_{n \mathop = 0}^\infty a_n \paren {x - \xi}^n$ be a power series about a point $\xi$.
Let $R$ be the radius of convergence of $S$.
Let $\rho \in \R$ such that $0 \le \rho < R$.
Then $S$ is uniformly convergent on $D = \set {x: \size {x - \xi} \le \rho}$.

8b05eade-e4aa-4ef2-a4c7-c8571fc90526.text:
Let $V$ be a vector space over $\Bbb F \in \left\{{\R, \C}\right\}$.
Let $\left \langle{\cdot, \cdot}\right \rangle$ be a semi-inner product on $V$.
Denote, for $x \in V$, $\left\Vert{x}\right\Vert := \left\langle{x, x}\right\rangle^{1 / 2}$.
Then, $\forall x, y \in V, a \in \Bbb F$:
:$(1): \quad \left\Vert{x + y}\right\Vert \le \left\Vert{x}\right\Vert + \left\Vert{y}\right\Vert$
:$(2): \quad \left\Vert{a x}\right\Vert = \left|{a}\right| \left\Vert{x}\right\Vert$

f5d026d9-58fd-475d-b53c-332fd5f8856a.text:
Let $R$ be a commutative ring with unity.
Let $G$ be an $n$-dimensional unitary $R$-module.
Let $\sequence {a_n}$ be an ordered basis of $G$.
Let $\mathbf P = \sqbrk \alpha_n$ be a square matrix of order $n$ over $R$.
Let $\ds \forall j \in \closedint 1 n: b_j = \sum_{i \mathop = 1}^n \alpha_{i j} a_i$.
Then $\sequence {b_n}$ is an ordered basis of $G$ {{iff}} $\mathbf P$ is invertible.

81d86f44-5878-4eea-ac66-ed90b05bcdba.text:
Let $T = \left({S, \tau_{\bar p}}\right)$ be an excluded point space.
Then $T$ is ultraconnected.

33f62224-a827-4c43-99b0-22fe8a3e6345.text:
Let $\R^2$ denote the real number plane under the Euclidean topology.
Let $\mathsf L \subseteq \R^2$ denote the letter $L$:
:$\mathsf L := \closedint 0 1 \times \set 0 \cup \set 0 \times \closedint 0 1$
Let $\mathsf T \subseteq \R^2$ denote the letter $T$:
:$\mathsf T := \closedint {-1} 1 \times \set 0 \cup \set 0 \times \closedint 0 1$
Then $\mathsf L$ and $\mathsf T$ are not homeomorphic.

232d0050-05f5-4be0-a47b-a96b1ac7ebde.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {x^3 \paren {x^2 + a^2}^2} = -\frac 1 {2 a^4 x^2} - \frac 1 {2 a^4 \paren {x^2 + a^2} } - \frac 1 {a^6} \map \ln {\frac {x^2} {x^2 + a^2} } + C$

e6303faa-9054-4452-95d6-898169381e1b.text:
Let $f, g: \N \to \C$ be multiplicative arithmetic functions.
Then their Dirichlet convolution $f * g$ is again multiplicative.

98396671-934d-4e2f-933c-423212d10fe0.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a finite complement topology on a uncountable set $S$.
If the Continuum Hypothesis is accepted as true, then:
:$T$ is arc-connected
:$T$ is locally arc-connected.

0b0318b0-5e6f-4380-bc33-5e2574e0db80.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Let $a \in A$ be a point in $M$.
Let $N, N'$ be neighborhoods of $a$ in $M$.
Then $N \cap N'$ is a neighborhood of $a$ in $M$.

9b5cff6a-4ecc-4395-8ca1-fc34ce07b1cc.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Let $a \in A$.
Let $S \subseteq A$ be a non-empty subset of $A$.
Then there exists a sequence $\sequence {a_n}$ of points of $S$ such that:
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} \map d {a, a_n} = \map d {a, S}$

9033e14e-829b-4c75-8ab2-203392207a1c.text:
For all $z \in \C$:
:$\map \sin {-z} = -\sin z$
That is, the sine function is odd.

cfffb8ca-207b-455e-a8d9-f2bb3fd2c0bf.text:
:$\ds \int x^2 \arcosh \frac x a \rd x = \dfrac {x^3} 3 \arcosh \dfrac x a - \dfrac {\paren {x^2 + 2 a^2} \sqrt {x^2 - a^2} } 9 + C$
where $\arcosh$ denotes the real area hyperbolic cosine.

40a3d855-81c0-40fd-9265-c211ce595e32.text:
Let $x \in \R_{>0}$ be a (strictly) positive real number.
Let $n \in \Z$ be an integer.
Then:
:$x^n > 0$
where $x^n$ denotes the $n$th power of $x$.

b9d0ea07-1679-4e33-a0f8-6988b639bb6c.text:
Let $f$ be a real function which is continuous on the closed interval $\closedint a b$ and differentiable on the open interval $\openint a b$.
Suppose that:
:$\forall x \in \openint a b: \map {f'} x = 0$
Then $f$ is constant on $\closedint a b$.

e2f3a107-0eaa-42de-842e-c00e38fd2f7a.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be a well-ordered set.
Let $T \subseteq S$ be a subset of $S$ such that:
:$\forall s \in S: \paren {\forall t \in S: t \prec s \implies t \in T} \implies s \in T$
Then $T = S$.

ebba7420-33b1-470d-994e-8aa82a06e9a2.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be a group whose identity is $e$.
Let $\powerset G$ denote the power set of $G$.
Let $\HH \subseteq \powerset G$ denote the set of subgroups of $G$.
Let $*$ be the subset product action on $\HH \subseteq \powerset G$ defined as:
:$\forall g \in G: \forall H \in \HH: g * H = g \circ H$
where $g \circ H$ is the (left) coset of $g$ by $H$.
Then the stabilizer of $H$ in $\powerset G$ is $H$ itself:
:$\Stab H = H$

ddb6ea43-f8e9-4611-b98e-57eec64b116c.text:
Let $L = \left({S, \vee, \preceq}\right)$ be a bounded below continuous join semilattice.
Let $\mathit{Ids}\left({L}\right)$ be the set of all ideals in $L$.
Let $P = \left({\mathit{Ids}\left({L}\right), \precsim}\right)$ be an ordered set where $\mathord \precsim = \subseteq\restriction_{\mathit{Ids}\left({L}\right)\times \mathit{Ids}\left({L}\right)}$
Let $f: \mathit{Ids}\left({L}\right) \to S$ be a mapping such that
:$\forall I \in \mathit{Ids}\left({L}\right): f\left({I}\right) = \sup I$
Then $f$ is an upper adjoint of Galois connection.

d9879640-5d1a-4553-8694-7479a3e39d17.text:
On all the number systems:
* natural numbers $\N$
* integers $\Z$
* rational numbers $\Q$
* real numbers $\R$
* complex numbers $\C$
the zero element of multiplication is zero ($0$).

565c4128-2ce5-4e1f-b87e-59602a4f5bee.text:
Let $f$ be a real function which is continuous on the closed interval $\left[{a \,.\,.\, b}\right]$.
Then the image of $\left[{a \,.\,.\, b}\right]$ under $f$ is also a closed interval.

91a9fe43-49fe-4ab6-9b70-8689143d6605.text:
Let $G = \gen g$ be a cyclic group whose order is $n$ and whose identity is $e$.
Let $d \divides n$, where $\divides$ denotes divisibility.
Then there exists exactly one subgroup $G_d = \gen {g^{n / d} }$ of $G$ with $d$ elements.

ebfc43c9-4122-41e6-ab37-73086f1c6693.text:
Let $R$ be a commutative ring with unity.
Let $f \in R \left[{X}\right]$ be a polynomial.
Let $a \in R$ be a root of $f$ with multiplicity at least $2$.
Let $f'$ denote the formal derivative of $f$.
Then $a$ is a root of $f'$.

e3fc818f-743e-426f-a5c0-13770a7e94af.text:
{{EuclidPropStatement|book=X|prop=42|qual=Lemma|body=Let the straight line $AB$ be set out, let the whole be cut into unequal parts at each of the points $C, D$, and let $AC$ be supposed greater than $DB$;
I say that the squares on $AC, CB$ are greater than the squares on $AD, DB$.}}

3d7a622c-8201-4b44-a52b-9682b3fae492.text:
Let $R, S, T$ be sets.
Then:
: $\left({R \setminus S}\right) \cap T = \left({R \cap T}\right) \setminus S$
where:
: $R \setminus S$ denotes set difference
: $R \cap T$ denotes set intersection.

bb0e9b8d-0287-4435-b230-277dded22312.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be a group.
Let $\struct {H, \circ {\restriction_H} }$ be a subgroup of $G$.
Let $i: H \to G$ be the inclusion mapping from $H$ to $G$.
Then $i$ is a group monomorphism.

8478612e-efbf-4922-ac29-6d8fd47009fa.text:
Let $n \in \N$ be a natural number such that $n \ge 3$.
Let $D_n$ be the dihedral group of order $2 n$, given by:
:$D_n = \gen {\alpha, \beta: \alpha^n = \beta^2 = e, \beta \alpha \beta = \alpha^{−1} }$
Let $\map {N_{D_n} } {\set \beta}$ denote the normalizer of the singleton containing the reflection element $\beta$.
Then:
:$\map {N_{D_n} } {\set \beta} = \begin{cases} \set {e, \beta} & : n \text { odd} \\ \set {e, \beta, \alpha^{n / 2}, \alpha^{n / 2} \beta} & : n \text { even} \end{cases}$

17ac0286-66fc-4288-b56a-2884ccf1edf3.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be the either-or space.
Then $T$ is a locally path-connected space.

7bbeae4c-8bf1-4902-94c1-db2eaf918deb.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space which is totally disconnected.
Then $T$ is a totally pathwise disconnected space.

3f8b197a-480e-4f46-a87e-131bf30bd378.text:
:$\laptrans {\sin \sqrt t} = \dfrac {\sqrt \pi} {2 s^{3/2} } \map \exp {-\dfrac 1 {4 s} }$
where $\laptrans f$ denotes the Laplace transform of the function $f$.

24fe775d-1cbe-431d-8d49-33265bef13a0.text:
Let $\map f x$ be the real function defined on $\openint 0 4$ as:
:$\map f x = \begin{cases}
x & : 0 < x \le 2 \\
x - 2 & : 2 < x < 4 \end{cases}$
Then its Fourier series can be expressed as:
:$\map f x \sim \displaystyle 1 + \frac 4 \pi \sum_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty \frac {\paren {-1}^{r - 1} } {2 r - 1} \paren {1 + \frac {4 \paren {-1}^r} {\paren {2 r - 1} \pi} } \cos \frac {\paren {2 r - 1} \pi x} 4$

a92f25c0-c653-437a-9aac-0ad9bdd3a3cd.text:
Let $F$ be a closed and bounded real set.
Let $C$ be a set of open real sets.
Let $C$ be a cover of $F$.
Then there is a finite subset of $C$ that covers $F$.

17beb3aa-16bf-495e-adc6-13e8fc369e68.text:
Let $\log_8 x$ be the logarithm base $8$ of $x$.
Let $\lg x$ be the binary (base $2$) logarithm of $x$.
Then:
:$\log_8 x = \dfrac {\lg x} 3$

72df7725-d0ef-4c25-b8ba-a41131a03563.text:
Let $\Z$ be the set of integers.
Let $\RR$ be the relation on $\Z$ defined as:
:$\forall x, y \in \Z: \tuple {x, y} \in \RR \iff \size x = \size y$
where $\size x$ denotes the absolute value of $x$.
Then $\RR$ is not a congruence relation for integer addition.

ab1ba534-d9c5-4ea5-adab-285101500b27.text:
Consider the Pell numbers $P_0, P_1, P_2, \ldots$
:$0, 1, 2, 5, 12, 29, \ldots$
$P_n$ has the same parity as $n$.
That is:
:if $n$ is odd then $P_n$ is odd
:if $n$ is even then $P_n$ is even.

491ebc91-9b30-4bc1-a697-46514b6ad7bd.text:
Let $\struct {G, \cdot}$ be a group.
Let $f: \struct {V, \phi} \to \struct {V', \mu}$ be a homomorphism of $G$-modules.
Then its kernel $\map \ker f$ is a $G$-submodule of $V$.

e1bb92c3-e615-4caf-9655-a9c3475db98d.text:
Let $a$ and $n$ be integers.
Let $a \perp n$, that is, let $a$ and $b$ be coprime.
Let $c \in \Z_{>0}$ be the multiplicative order of $a$ modulo $n$.
Then $a^k \equiv 1 \pmod n$ {{iff}} $k$ is a multiple of $c$.

b2fa4f71-f6a4-405a-b937-d776c04535d8.text:
Let $f$ be the real function defined as:
:$\map f x = \floor x$
where $\floor{\, \cdot \,}$ denotes the floor function.
Let $n \in \Z$ be an integer.
Then $\map f x$ is not continuous on the left at $n$.

1a32db81-23eb-4041-8974-db315275c871.text:
Let $\mathbb S$ be the set of all real intervals.
Then $\mathbb S$ is a semiring of sets, but is '''not''' a ring of sets.

c2653a30-f936-403e-90d6-43579ab32062.text:
Let $K$ be a division ring.
Let $G$ be a finitely generated $K$-vector space.
Let $H$ be a linearly independent subset of $G$.
Let $F$ be a finite generator for $G$ such that $H \subseteq F$.
Then there is a basis $B$ for $G$ such that $H \subseteq B \subseteq F$.

f0dd58c6-92a2-4dfa-9342-bc2760473a41.text:
Let $T = \struct {A, \tau}$ and $T' = \struct {A', \tau'}$ be topological spaces.
Let $H \subseteq A$.
Let $T_H = \struct {H, \tau_H}$ be a topological subspace of $T$.
Let $i: H \to A$ be the inclusion mapping.
Let $f: A \to A'$ be a mapping.
If $f$ is $\tuple {\tau, \tau'}$-continuous, then $f \circ i$ is $\tuple {\tau_H, \tau'}$-continuous

ad61278e-d8fe-4db6-ae7b-5ba3b3034699.text:
The common logarithm of $2$:
:$\log_{10} 2 \approx 0.30102 \, 99956 \, 63981 \, 19521 \, 37389 \ldots$
is irrational.

0fd3ff73-eb0a-4ba5-af1e-507599ada743.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be an ordered set.
The identity mapping $I_S$ is an order isomorphism from $\struct {S, \preceq}$ to itself.

974438b5-9904-48a4-aadc-f6903c336c9a.text:
Let $\struct {\R^2, d}$ be the real number plane with the usual (Euclidean) topology.
Let $\rho: \R^2 \to \R$ be the first projection on $\R^2$ defined as:
:$\forall \tuple {x, y} \in \R^2: \map \rho {x, y} = x$
Then $\rho$ is not a closed mapping.
The same applies with the second projection on $\R^2$.

ef22fffe-3e20-4b9c-ae1a-9d3d871e428d.text:
Let $T$ be a connected topological space.
Let $f: T \to \R$ be a continuous real-valued mapping.
Then $f \sqbrk T$ is a real interval.

08c3618e-3211-4514-9d46-b2cc492fa414.text: The taxicab metric is a metric.

b0306740-9222-4a73-ada7-43eaca0a7f92.text:
Let $p \in\ Q$ and $q \in \Q$ be rational numbers.
Let $p^*$ and $q^*$ denote the rational cuts associated with $p$ and $q$.
Then:
:$p^* < q^* \iff p < q$
where $p^* < q^*$ denotes the strict ordering on cuts defined as:
:$\beta < \gamma \iff \exists p \in \Q: p \in \beta, p \notin \gamma$

ebd7f06f-50ce-47ed-a2b7-c5f3a5145630.text:
The only positive integers which are simultaneously tetrahedral and square are:
:$1, 4, 19 \, 600$

05c92811-3848-4397-83e1-4a36a249d572.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $B \subseteq A \subseteq S$.
Then:
:$B' \subseteq A'$
where $A'$ and $B'$ are the derived sets in $T$ of $A$ and $B$ respectively.

f6829005-e2f7-4e3f-a47d-a9333a1f52b7.text:
Let $\left({S, \preceq}\right)$, $\left({T, \precsim}\right)$ be ordered sets.
Let $d: T \to S$ be an lower adjoint of Galois connection.
Then $d$ preserves all suprema.

26701c93-d613-4d9c-b9ae-81daf2b7dfbe.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a fully normal space.
Then $T$ is paracompact.

a20587bc-2cc1-41a2-bfb0-d6bc7bdca7e7.text:
Consider a pentagram.
:400px
Let $AC$ be the length of one of the lines which span the pentagram and define it.
Let $B$ be one of the points where $AC$ intersects one of the other such lines such that $AB > AC$.
Then:
:$\dfrac {AC} {AB} = \phi$
where $\phi$ denotes the golden mean.

7bcee91a-08dd-4d8f-a56b-f486c7862e1d.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Let $\struct {\Q_p, \norm {\,\cdot\,}_p}$ be the $p$-adic numbers.
Let $\Z_p$ be the $p$-adic integers.
Let $x \in \Z_p$.
Let $\sequence {\alpha_n}$ be a sequence of integers:
:$\norm {x -\alpha_n}_p \le p^{-\paren {n + 1} }$
Then:
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} \alpha_n = x$

28a0a596-a4da-49ae-9aee-1eca30e77c2e.text:
Let $\KK$ be a central conic.
Let $C$ be the center of $\KK$.
Then $C$ is a center of symmetry for $\KK$.

a055946f-a2cb-4174-8d08-b838cef7959e.text:
Let $J_1, J_2, \ldots, J_n$ be ideals of a ring $\struct {R, +, \circ}$.
Let $J = J_1 + J_2 + \cdots + J_n$ be an ideal of $R$ where $J_1 + J_2 + \cdots + J_n$ is as defined in subset product.
$J$ is contained in every subring of $R$ containing $\ds \bigcup_{k \mathop = 1}^n {J_k}$.

c4785084-19ad-4dbe-9060-54203f75c692.text:
The closed-form expression for the $n$th heptagonal pyramidal number is:
:$Q_n = \dfrac {n \paren {n + 1} \paren {5 n - 2} } 6$

a9fd2c7e-1b9d-4943-9301-ba1330e6e372.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a division ring.
Let $\norm {\,\cdot\,}$ be a norm on $R$.
Let $x, y \in R$.
Then:
:$\norm {x - y} \le \norm x + \norm y$

aa32cfa5-f61e-468a-b9ae-fc2b6bf0b968.text:
$7$ is the smallest prime number the period of whose reciprocal, when expressed in decimal notation, is maximum:
:$\dfrac 1 7 = 0 \cdotp \dot 14285 \dot 7$

ec5df94e-4270-42e3-a71e-ee6fde6ff776.text:
Let $A \subseteq \R$ be a subset of the real numbers.
Let $c \in A$.
Let $f : A \to \R$ be a real function.
Then if $f$ is continuous at $c$:
:for each sequence $\sequence {x_n}$ in $A$ that converges to $c$, the sequence $\sequence {\map f {x_n} }$ converges to $\map f c$.

e9585bca-c3f9-405d-bb98-27a851fcf85a.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be a monoid whose identity is $e_S$.
Let $a \in S$ be invertible for $\circ$.
Let $n \in \N$.
Let $a^n = \map {\circ^n} a$ be defined as the power of an element of a monoid:
:$a^n = \begin{cases}
e_S : & n = 0 \\
a^x \circ a : & n = x + 1
\end{cases}$
That is:
:$a^n = \underbrace {a \circ a \circ \cdots \circ a}_{\text {$n$ instances} } = \map {\circ^n} a$
For each $n \in \N$ we define:
:$a^{-n} = \paren {a^{-1} }^n$
Then:
:$\forall m, n \in \Z: a^{n + m} = a^n \circ a^m$

36eecb4f-c70f-47f7-8b7a-3c4f1194b7e0.text:
Let $w, z \in \C$ be complex numbers.
$(1)$ If $w$ is wholly real, then:
:$\map \Re {w z} = w \, \map \Re z$
and:
:$\map \Im {w z} = w \, \map \Im z$
$(2)$ If $w$ is wholly imaginary, then:
:$\map \Re {w z} = -\map \Im w \, \map \Im z$
and:
:$\map \Im {w z} = \map \Im w \, \map \Re z$
Here, $\map \Re z$ denotes the real part of $z$, and $\map \Im z$ denotes the imaginary part of $z$.

3e9ab5bf-c525-490a-a3fd-ebeff749ec4f.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau_p}$ be a Fortissimo space.
Then $T$ is not a pseudocompact space.

c5dc5943-7d00-4130-9910-8b8c93034d93.text:
Let $M_1 = \struct {A_1, d}$ and $M_2 = \struct {A_2, d'}$ be metric spaces.
Let $\AA := A_1 \times A_2$ be the cartesian product of $A_1$ and $A_2$.
Let $\MM = \struct {\AA, d_p}$ denote the metric space on $\AA$ where $d_p: \AA \to \R$ is one of the $p$-product metrics on $\AA$:
:$\map {d_p} {x, y} := \begin {cases}
\paren {\paren {\map d {x_1, y_1} }^p + \paren {\map {d'} {x_2, y_2} }^p}^{1/p} & : p \in \Z_{>0} \\
\ds \max_{i \mathop = 1}^n \set {\map d {x_1, y_1}, \map {d'} {x_2, y_2} } & : p = \infty
\end {cases}$
where:
:$x = \tuple {x_1, x_2}$
:$y = \tuple {y_1, y_2}$
Let $a \in A_1$ and $b \in A_2$ be fixed and arbitrary.
Let:
:$i_b: A_1 \to \AA$ be the mapping defined as:
::$\forall x \in A_1: \map {i_b} x = \tuple {x, b}$
:$i_a: A_2 \to \AA$ be the mapping defined as:
::$\forall y \in A_2: \map {i_a} y = \tuple {a, y}$
Then $i_b$ and $i_a$ are continuous in $M_1$ and $M_2$ respectively.

120ae803-8fe3-4617-a97a-74165c516e03.text:
Let $\struct {\R \setminus \Q, \tau_d}$ be the irrational number space under the Euclidean topology $\tau_d$.
Then $\struct {\R \setminus \Q, \tau_d}$ is paracompact.

d2029a77-343e-4558-afc4-7fb77d91a115.text:
Let $c, d, n \in \Z$.
Then:
:$\ds \sum_{d \mathop \divides n} \sum_{c \mathop \divides d} \map f {c, d} = \sum_{c \mathop \divides n} \sum_{d \mathop \divides \paren {n / c} } \map f {c, c d}$
where $c \divides d$ denotes that $c$ is a divisor of $d$.

0fa12869-9ee5-4e49-8f98-d3aed5cd25ae.text:
Let $\struct {\Q, \tau_d}$ be the rational number space under the Euclidean metric $d$.
Then $\struct {\Q, \tau_d}$ is not a complete metric space.

836e3004-7760-4ef8-80d9-0a96f52b5ec4.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be a Brouwerian lattice.
Then $\struct {S, \preceq}$ is a distributive lattice

7270ea9a-6685-43cb-920d-459c24ed8bd5.text:
:$\map \tanh {a + b} = \dfrac {\tanh a + \tanh b} {1 + \tanh a \tanh b}$
where $\tanh$ denotes the hyperbolic tangent.

e551a33f-19d6-420c-a2e4-b1a90de418f2.text:
Let $M$ be a class which is minimally inductive under a progressing mapping $g$.
Then for all $x, y \in M$:
:$x \subseteq y \subseteq \map g x \implies x = y \lor y = \map g x$

7a74fd93-979d-4520-bce3-1f580789dfd4.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be a group.
Let $\RR$ be a relation on $G$ that is compatible with $\circ$.
Then $\RR$ is reflexive or antireflexive.

5c21e67e-1f06-4757-a729-11e7f804874f.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be an algebraic structure.
Let $T \subseteq S$.
Let the operation $\circ$ be commutative on $\struct {S, \circ}$.
Then the restriction $\circ {\restriction_T}$ of $\circ$ to $T$ is also commutative.

3c159428-ca59-408c-8606-41044a216f3c.text:
Let $a$ be a point on an open real interval $I$.
Let $f$, $g$ and $h$ be real functions defined at all points of $I$ except for possibly at point $a$.
Suppose that:
:$\forall x \ne a \in I: \map g x \le \map f x \le \map h x$
:$\ds \lim_{x \mathop \to a} \map g x = \lim_{x \mathop \to a} \map h x = L$
Then:
:$\ds \lim_{x \mathop \to a} \ \map f x = L$
This result is also known, in the UK in particular, as the '''sandwich theorem''' or the '''sandwich rule'''.
In that culture, the word '''{{WP|Sandwich|sandwich}}''' traditionally means specifically enclosing food between two slices of bread, as opposed to the looser usage of the '''{{WP|Open_sandwich|open sandwich}}''', where the there is only one such slice.
Hence, in idiomatic British English, one can refer to the (often uncomfortable) situation of being between two entities as being '''sandwiched''' between them.
As the idiom is not universal globally, the term '''squeeze theorem''' is preferred on {{ProofWiki}}, for greatest comprehension.

54c32ccd-af06-480b-b2a9-759d28be2822.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $H \subseteq S$ be both closed and open in $T$.
Then $H$ contains the components of all of its points.

ce640f00-1619-4b3f-b573-aa4aa67d21e8.text:
The symmetric group on $n$ letters $\struct {S_n, \circ}$ is isomorphic to the symmetric group on the $n$ elements of any set $T$ whose cardinality is $n$.
That is:
:$\forall T \subseteq \mathbb U, \card T = n: \struct {S_n, \circ} \cong \struct {\Gamma \paren T, \circ}$

3b0a29a5-6de3-4315-8e2d-d7d07f4b5eae.text:
Let $S$ be a set and let $\PP$ be a partition on $S$ which is not the (trivial) partition of singletons.
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be the partition space whose basis is $\PP$.
Then:
:$T$ is a $T_4$ space.

108b7117-cab7-4942-b5a4-83ad635d7635.text:
Let $a \in \C$ be a complex number.
Let $r > 0$ be a real number.
Let $f$ be a function holomorphic on some open ball $D = \map B {a, r}$. 
Then $f$ is complex analytic on $D$.

e83d2a3d-cf39-4908-8e5e-9cfe76c7227d.text:
Let $\mathbb T = \set {T_i: i \mathop \in I}$, where each $T_i$ is a set and $I$ is some finite indexing set.
Then:
:$\ds S \setminus \bigcup_{i \mathop \in I} T_i = \bigcap_{i \mathop \in I} \paren {S \setminus T_i}$

f5c11442-ed9d-43b7-82ab-ba346640123e.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq_1}$ and $\struct {T, \preceq_2}$ be well-ordered sets.
Let $\phi: S \to T$ be a bijection such that $\phi: S \to T$ is order-preserving:
:$\forall x, y \in S: x \preceq_1 y \implies \map \phi x \preceq_2 \map \phi y$
Then:
:$\forall x, y \in S: \map \phi x \preceq_2 \map \phi y \implies x \preceq_1 y$
That is, $\phi: S \to T$ is an order isomorphism.

7dc57af6-6e80-4e39-acc6-8a9edd66b25b.text:
Let $X$ be a subset of $\R$.
The set:
:$\leftset {x \in X: x}$ is local minimum in $\rightset X$
is countable.

1543c1b1-e442-4593-acc3-fc6805f64790.text:
Let $s \in \R, r \in \Z_{\ge 0}, n \in \Z$.
Then:
:$\ds \sum_k \binom r k \binom {s + k} n \paren {-1}^{r - k} = \binom s {n - r}$
where $\dbinom r k$ etc. are binomial coefficients.

ca9c041b-5595-48de-a91c-1fe3c13e501c.text:
Let $\RR$ be a relation on a set $S$.
If $\RR$ is non-reflexive, then so is $\RR^{-1}$.

b0073557-9654-4d03-b3be-acae0e165b4b.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
The '''$p$th cyclotomic polynomial''' is:
:$\map {\Phi_p} x = x^{p - 1} + x^{p - 2} + \cdots + x + 1$

b8cb2acc-22b9-4404-ad2e-e863d712c048.text:
Let $L_k$ be the $k$th Lucas number, defined as the sum of two Fibonacci numbers:
:$L_n = F_{n - 1} + F_{n + 1}$
Then $L_n$ can be defined as the $n$th element of the recursive sequence:
:$L_n = \begin{cases}
2 & : n = 0 \\
1 & : n = 1 \\
L_{n - 1} + L_{n - 2} & : \text{otherwise} \end{cases}$

bbee16da-b029-4fb8-ab84-43ed89c727fa.text:
Let $T = \struct{S, \tau}$ be a locally compact topological space.
Then $T$ is weakly locally compact.

1bc13e92-317d-41ce-a87d-b391a82a73a6.text:
Let $S_1, S_2, S_3$ be sets.
Let $f_1: S_1 \to S_2$ and $f_2: S_2 \to S_3$ be mappings such that the domain of $f_2$ is the same set as the codomain of $f_1$.
Let $f_2 \circ f_1$ be the composite of $f_1$ and $f_2$.
Let $f_1$ and $f_2$ be considered as relations on $S_1 \times S_2$ and $S_2 \times S_3$ respectively.
Then $f_2 \circ f_1$ defined as the composition of relations coincides with the definition of $f_2 \circ f_1$ as the composition of mappings.

3a8bd33f-3cdc-4eae-8407-5f61df626479.text:
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ be any ordinal-valued sequence.
Then $\sequence {x_n}$ is bounded above.

817b6867-9b75-4594-8359-1ad3c34bf4e5.text: :$\ds \int x \arccos \frac x a \rd x = \paren {\frac {x^2} 2 - \frac {a^2} 4} \arccos \frac x a - \frac {x \sqrt {a^2 - x^2} } 4 + C$

29f40546-694c-4cf0-8af5-345e17536dd4.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a Hausdorff space.
Let $f: T \to T$ be a continuous mapping on $T$.
Let $W$ be the set defined as:
:$W = \set {x \in T: \map f x = x}$
Then $W$ is closed in $T$.

2cdf3527-f416-43c7-bfce-351c837f35e5.text:
Let $\left({S, \preceq}\right)$ be an ordered set.
Let $x \in S$.
Then the singleton $\left\{{x}\right\}$ is convex.

6637db92-d632-4713-82b8-1b1175b0347a.text:
The integers have no zero divisors:
:$\forall x, y, \in \Z: x \times y = 0 \implies x = 0 \lor y = 0$
This can equivalently be expressed:
:$\forall x, y, \in \Z: x \ne 0 \land y \ne 0 \implies x \times y \ne 0$

a3b79cc3-2563-4bea-91e4-913b08be89b0.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\paren {\sqrt {x^2 + a^2} }^3} {x^2} \rd x = \frac {-\paren {\sqrt {x^2 + a^2} }^3} x + \frac {3 x \sqrt {x^2 + a^2} } 2 + \frac {3 a^2} 2 \map \ln {x + \sqrt {x^2 + a^2} } + C$

6a7009ec-8162-44d1-8140-65bd44c33117.text: The big dipper semigroup is a commutative semigroup.

a6cdf902-f00a-41c7-b96e-5b07598bc9b3.text:
Let $\RR \subseteq S \times T$ be a relation.
Let $X \subseteq S$.
Then the restriction of $\RR$ to $X$ is a subset of $\RR$.

42f70df5-18ff-4020-a297-96ca6665f0d7.text:
Let $G$ be an infinite abelian group.
Let $H \subseteq G$ be the subset of $G$ defined as:
:$H := \set {x \in G: x \text { is of finite order in } G}$
All the elements of the quotient group $G / H$ are of infinite order except the identity.

e2c634df-9491-42bb-ac24-7fc5e4dc2e08.text:
Let $a$ be a natural number greater than $1$.
Then either:
:$a$ is a prime number
or:
:there exists a prime number $p \ne a$ such that $p \divides a$
where $\divides$ denotes '''is a divisor of'''.
{{EuclidPropStatement|book=VII|prop=32|body=Any number either is prime or is measured by some prime number.}}

b309d99a-1af3-42cd-b79e-c4ceda267098.text:
Let $n \in \Z_{>0}$ be a (strictly) positive integer.
Let $T_1$ and $T_2$ be sets whose cardinality $\card {T_1}$ and $\card {T_2}$ are both $n$.
Let $\struct {\map \Gamma {T_1}, \circ}$ and $\struct {\map \Gamma {T_2}, \circ}$ be the symmetric group on $S$ and $T$ respectively.
Then $\struct {\map \Gamma {T_1}, \circ}$ and $\struct {\map \Gamma {T_2}, \circ}$ are isomorphic.

90a49db2-deb2-48c8-8a9c-2f33c7b20f5d.text:
Let $A$ be a commutative ring with unity.
Let $M$ be a finitely generated $A$-module.
Let $\mathfrak a$ be an ideal of $A$.
Let $\phi$ be an endomorphism of $M$ such that $\map \phi M \subseteq \mathfrak a M$.
Then $\phi$ satisfies an equation of the form:
:$\phi^n + a_{n - 1} \phi^{n-1} + \cdots + a_1 \phi + a_0 = 0$
with the $a_i \in \mathfrak a$.

3940fe82-f0eb-4b62-a5ba-2ce6ffc49072.text:
Let $f: S \to T$ be a mapping.
Then:
:$B \subseteq \Img S \implies \paren {f \circ f^{-1} } \sqbrk B = B$

e29f910b-f6eb-4c42-ad1b-845bb6399b3f.text:
Let $G_1$ and $G_2$ be isomorphic graphs.
Then the degrees of the vertices of $G_1$ are exactly the same as the degrees of the vertices of $G_2$.

76ac758a-4111-473d-8ca9-170e27dad21d.text:
For every pair of integers $a, b$ where $b > 0$, the integers $q, r$ such that $a = q b + r$ and $0 \le r < b$ are unique:
:$\forall a, b \in \Z, b > 0: \exists! q, r \in \Z: a = q b + r, 0 \le r < b$

023f6bde-7267-4ce5-8271-ed1c491f464c.text:
The area inside an astroid $H$ constructed within a circle of radius $a$ is given by:
:$\AA = \dfrac {3 \pi a^2} 8$

9e7469bf-9492-431a-9818-613e247e19e5.text:
Let $I$ be an indexing set.
Let $S_\alpha, T_\alpha$ be sets, for all $\alpha \in I$.
Then:
:$\ds \bigcup_{\alpha \mathop \in I} S_\alpha \symdif \bigcup_{\alpha \mathop \in I} T_\alpha \subseteq \bigcup_{\alpha \mathop \in I} \paren {S_\alpha \symdif T_\alpha}$
where $S \symdif T$ is the symmetric difference between $S$ and $T$.

1b7aaa05-bd4b-441f-a6f6-856337d36fd1.text:
Let $z_1$ be a non-zero wholly real number.
Let $z_2$ be a non-zero wholly imaginary number.
Then, $z_1$ and $z_2$ are linearly independent over the rational numbers $\Q$, where the group is the complex numbers $\C$.

87641a5f-c7eb-4ada-92fa-603438d52400.text:
Let $x$ and $y$ be small classes.
Then $x \cup y$ is also small.

b2150358-6660-4eb5-a9e1-f9f1383990f8.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be the either-or space.
Then $T$ is a $T_4$ space.

b97dbf27-cffc-4d0c-aba2-2c15aff88a35.text:
Let $\map {\operatorname{Af}_1} \R$ be the $1$-dimensional affine group on $\R$.
Let $\R^+$ be the additive group of real numbers.
Let $\R^\times$ be the multiplicative group of real numbers.
Let $\phi: \R^\times \to \Aut {\R^+}$ be defined as:
:$\forall b \in \R^\times: \map \phi b = \paren {a \mapsto a b}$
Let $\R^+ \rtimes_\phi \R^\times$ be the corresponding semidirect product.
Then:
:$\map {\operatorname {Af}_1} \R \cong \R^+ \rtimes_\phi \R^\times$
where $\cong$ denotes (group) isomorphism.

b67b059c-a323-4970-961b-8664e5f63383.text:
The empty set can be characterised as:
:$\O := \set {x: x \in E \text { and } x \notin E}$
where $E$ is an arbitrary set.

292593b3-8c76-4756-a603-a8306eaccdd9.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a countable complement topology.
Then $T$ is a $T_1$ (Fréchet) space.

6ff885d6-2cfd-4420-8672-d1e1401b6e59.text:
Any abelian group $\struct {G, +}$ may be turned into a trivial ring by defining the ring product to be:
:$\forall x, y \in G: x \circ y = e_G$

fa9d4e6a-650a-40a5-ac7a-e64e29cf37df.text:
Let $A$ be the set of all real sequences $\sequence {x_i}$ such that the series $\ds \sum_{i \mathop \ge 0} x_i^2$ is convergent.
Let $\ell^2 = \struct {A, d_2}$ be the Hilbert sequence space on $\R$.
Let $H$ be a compact subset of $\ell^2$
Then $H$ is closed in $\ell^2$.

02009447-aa98-42a6-94da-52a6f2b9dbe3.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\sin^m a x} {\cos^n a x} \rd x = \frac {-\sin^{m - 1} a x} {a \paren {m - n} \cos^{n - 1} a x} + \frac {m - 1} {m - n} \int \frac {\sin^{m - 2} a x} {\cos^n a x} \rd x + C$

16ee0d6b-bd22-4ea1-8355-0ac2238767ba.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $T$ have a basis $\BB$ consisting of path-connected sets in $T$.
Then
:each point of $T$ has a local basis consisting entirely of path-connected sets in $T$.

54cf4682-62df-4c0e-9c8c-2ed981a24c19.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $I_S: S \to S$ be the identity mapping on $S$.
Then the inverse of $I_S$ is itself:
:$\paren {I_S}^{-1} = I_S$

440e1450-2a7a-45ad-bac5-2be9b6c7342e.text:
Let $\struct {\R \setminus \Q, \tau_d}$ be the irrational number space under the Euclidean topology $\tau_d$.
Then $\struct {\R \setminus \Q, \tau_d}$ is not a locally compact Hausdorff Space.

2129f06a-129a-4d6e-ab5f-e62c53ad19a7.text:
Let $G$ be a group.
Let $a, b, c \in G$.
Then the following hold:
;Right cancellation law
:$b a = c a \implies b = c$
;Left cancellation law
:$a b = a c \implies b = c$

6839dbb8-263d-4578-b4ea-c633f0ed015e.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be an algebraic structure.
Then $a \in S$ is right cancellable {{iff}} the right regular representation $\map {\rho_a} x$ is injective.

f4b67ed3-c689-4047-8e9a-29a034c3d9f7.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \preceq, \tau}$ be a transitive relational structure with lower topology.
Let $A \subseteq S$ such that
:$A$ is open.
Then $A$ is lower.

c30165c5-80f0-40be-a38d-696b267c3180.text:
Every bounded sequence of real numbers has a convergent subsequence.
Every infinite bounded space in a real Euclidean space has at least one limit point.
The Bolzano-Weierstrass Theorem is a crucial property of the real numbers discovered independently by both {{AuthorRef|Bernhard Bolzano}} and {{AuthorRef|Karl Weierstrass}} during their work on putting real analysis on a rigorous logical footing.
It was originally referred to as '''Weierstrass's Theorem''' until {{AuthorRef|Bernhard Bolzano|Bolzano}}'s thesis on the subject was rediscovered.

5691810b-745c-4788-878e-002d6bad6330.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Let $\struct {\Q_p, \norm {\,\cdot\,}_p}$ be the $p$-adic numbers.
Let $\sequence {x_n} $ be a sequence in $\Q_p$.
Then $\sequence {x_n}$ can have at most one limit.

ebc2371d-d779-4744-afed-4e91f7845b41.text:
Let $z \in \C$ be a complex number.
Then $z$ is algebraic over $\R$.

90ffdcbe-3e94-4de5-af2a-f044ed877e0d.text:
Let $x$ be an ordinal.
Let $x^+$ denote the successor of $x$.
Then:
:$x \in x^+$
:$x \subset x^+$

2a19d647-9b86-49bf-9d1b-cbaa51eeb1e3.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\cos a x \rd x} {p + q \sin a x} = \frac 1 {a q} \ln \size {p + q \sin a x} + C$

ab9b2f4a-cf1d-4ea6-be42-aa872c1858a4.text:
:$\ds \sum_{k \mathop = 1}^n \paren {\dfrac {\ds \prod_{\substack {1 \mathop \le r \mathop \le n \\ r \mathop \ne m} } \paren {x + k - r} } {\ds \prod_{\substack {1 \mathop \le r \mathop \le n \\ r \mathop \ne k} } \paren {k - r} } } = 1$
where $1 \le m \le n$ and $x$ is arbitrary.

12e6366e-dcde-4da4-911b-5483bb09ad41.text:
Let $\sequence {a_n}_{n \mathop \in \N} \in \C$ be a sequence of complex numbers such that:
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to +\infty}a_n = 0$
Then:
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to +\infty} \paren {1 + \dfrac {a_n} n}^n = 1$
